If you are asking about death, why not just call it death? It is the one thing that we all have in common. If it is organic, it WILL die.\nThe Laws of Thermodynamics tell us that closed systems will eventually fall apart because of Entropy.\nEverything that began, WILL END. That includes you and me and everything else.\nThere are two answers to your question:\n1. Something. or 2. Nothing.\nThat is, SOMETHING of who you are will remain. It may be something of your consciousness and personality will survive without a body\nOr: When you\u2019re dead, you\u2019re dead\u2014 the end, finis, you are a mere memory, curtains.\nI tend to believe in the \u201cSomething.\u201d category. It feels logical to me. It feels to me that a lifetime of study and insights and questions and answers, known. or unknowns, perceptions, service, understanding , and mystery simply were not for nothing.\nI am a person of faith, and my faith tells me that life goes on in some form after the physical. {"ans_list": ["The interstate highway system was an attempt to improve the transportation infrastructure of the US. The new roads made it much easier, faster, and cheaper to transport goods from one part of the country to another. This benefited the overall economy. It also helped tie different regions of the country together by making travel between them easier.", "To stimulate the economy via the huge public works project\nTo be able to mobilize military and civilians more efficiently as a Cold War function and a mass mobility function e.g. loops around major cities", "It was sold to the public as a civil defense project as in time of war it would be needed to move men and supplies efficiently. The fact was that the car companies (GM in particular) and the oil companies (Standard Oil) had formed a corporation whose express purpose was to buy up public transit systems and scrap them. By eliminating public transportation and building better roads, the sale of cars and gasoline skyrocketed. It also helped trucking companies to put railroads out of business. And of course, when suburbanization started, owning a car became a necessity as most public transportation no longer existed.\nIn the 19th century the government gave the railroads land grants to finance the construction of rail lines. However, once the lines were built, the railroads had to maintain them. In the 20th century, the government built roads that were used by the trucking companies but then the government continued to maintain those roads,\nHad the government continued to subsidize the railroads, I think the true economic cost of moving goods would have been less and that the railroads would have been far less destructive to the environment than the massive amount of trucks on the roads.\nThe other side of the coin is that companies like GM made huge amounts of money in increased car and truck sales while the oil companies made a fortune selling fuel for those cars and trucks.", "Many.\nThe stated reason to sell it to the taxpayers was as a military program to allow the US Military to move troops and equipment around the country rapidly, in addition although this is not obvious every ~ 10 or so miles on a US Interstate is specific length required to be straight and ~ level. Those are intended as emergency fighter strips for the USAF so that in the event of a nuclear war an enemy could not kill all our fighter bases\u2014 or at least would have a harder time doing so.\nEvacuation routes for citizens in emergencies.\nTo upgrade commercial transport.", "Defense is the short answer. Eisenhower was impressed by the German Autobahn. He also saw the need to have a system that could moved war goods and me nrapidly across the country.\nThen there was how it would boost the economy.\nAfter WW 1, Ike and Patton did the first coast to coast in gas vehicles. It took them a little over a month. This is when he saw the need to improve the road system.\nIt also gave the army requirements for its trucks", "Ike led a cross country expedition while he was still a green lieutenant, tasked with how to transport equipment across the US on the road system. He was appalled at how inadequate US roads were for trucks and large convoys.\nAs he was military, there was not much he could do about it. In Germany he saw the Autobahn system and how efficiently material could be transported.\nWhen he became President, he wanted to modernize the US road system and pattern it after the Autobahn. The primary reason was civilian commerce, but the cost of the program was sold to Congress and the people as national defense. This era was the Cold War with the USSR, and you could fund anything you want if you called it necessary for defense.", "Road transportation across the continent was inadequate for both civilian and military needs. The German autobahn roadways served as an example of how to improve this greatly. It proved to be correct and enabled greatly improved transportation for personal and commercial travel by roads.", "Eisenhower wanted the interstate system so that materiel could be more easily moved around during a war. The generals are always fighting the last war."], "topic_list": ["U.S. Highways", "Dwight D. Eisenhower", "Interstate Highway System", "Highways", "Education in the United States of America", "History of the United States of America", "History", "The United States of America"], "view_list": [51, 41, 85, 150, 100, 120, 90, 53], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Tallon Olivas", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 6, 0, 0, 1, 0], "question_title": "What were the underlying reasonings for the United States creating the Eisenhower interstate system?", "respond_collected": 8, "no_of_view": "1,173", "name_list": ["Michael Troy", "Hank Beel", "Robert Martin Pollack", "Alfred Montestruc", "Joe Rich", "David Sandbrook", "Eric Bostrom", "Ernie Harrison"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "274": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["2020s", "Black Lives Matter (movement)", "2018 (year)", "Future Scenarios", "Trends", "Black People", "2020 (year)", "Race and Ethnicity", "History", "The United States of America"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Shubham Singh", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Is 2020 really going to be a 'black year' of the decades?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "163", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "537": {"ans_list": ["The vast majority of Britons loved FDR because his policies helped save their country during the darkest days of WWII. FDR's lend-lease program eventually sent 31 billion dollars worth of aid to the UK.", "The British thought he was idealistic and sophomoric in his world views. They thought FDR was scheming and could not be trusted. They believed he had communist leanings as reflected by his New Deal. But he was a necessary evil. But most of all they saw him as a hypocrite.\n\u201cIt was against this backdrop that Roosevelt prepared for a confrontation on the colonial question with Churchill at the February 1943 Allied conference in Casablanca, Morocco. \u201c\n\u201cIt was apparently Roosevelt's own idea that he should make a stop in Liberia on his trip to the meeting. Roosevelt made brief public remarks highlighting the fact that Liberia had been founded by American slaves and was a free nation, but he was outraged at what he saw: substandard living conditions; he privately blamed the State Department for having no policy on economic development for Liberia or for anywhere else in the ``poor'' world, and saw this as undermining his foreign policy. \u201c\n\u201cAs embarrassed as FDR was by what he saw in Liberia, he was, according to first hand accounts, visibly shaken by what he viewed in a brief stop in British Gambia. On his arrival at Casablanca, FDR told his son:\n``The thing is, the colonial system means war. Exploit the resources of a India, a Burma, a Java, take all the wealth out of those countries, but never put anything back into them, things like education, sanitation, decent standards of living, minimum health requirements--all you are doing is storing up the kind of trouble that leads to war...I must tell Churchill what I found out about his British Gambia today.... This morning at about eight-thirty, we drove through Bathurst to the airfield. The natives were just getting to work. In rags ... glum-looking.... They [his British hosts] told us that the natives would look happier around noontime, when the sun would have burned off the dew and the chill. I was told that the prevailing wages of these men was one and nine. One shilling, nine pence. Less that fifty cents ... a day! Fifty cents a day! Besides which they are given half a cup of rice.... Dirt. Disease. Very high mortality rate. I asked life expectancy. You'd never guess what it is. Twenty six years! These people are treated worse than livestock. Their cattle live longer!... Churchill may have thought I wasn't serious last time [at Argentia]. He'll find out this time.''\n\u201cWe have some idea of what Roosevelt was saying from an account of discussions, at which Churchill was present, with the Sultan of Morocco. Roosevelt, speaking in French, stressed the need for Morocco to develop and control her own resources. To do this, he said, required: ``the elevation of the living standards of Moroccans; only by doing that could Morocco be free of imperial intrigues (Morocco was at the time controlled by the French). The Sultan expressed a desire to obtain modern education and health standards. \u201c\n``Father pointed out,'' Elliot Roosevelt wrote, ``that to accomplish this, the Sultan should not permit outside interests to obtain concessions which would drain off the country's resources.''\n\u201cChurchill was described as growing increasingly furious at these comments, and repreatedly tried to change the subject. Roosevelt persisted, telling the Sultan that the postwar world would differ sharply from the prewar world, ``especially as they related to the colonial question.'' The Sultan asked FDR what he meant by ``differ sharply.'' Roosevelt explained that in the past, French and British financiers combined into self-perpetuating syndicates for the purpose of dredging riches out of the colonies; he then said that there were likely large oil deposits in Morocco that needed development. The Sultan said, that while he would like to pursue such possibilities and use the wealth to develop his nation, he was unable to do so without going to the colonial powers, since his country lacked scientists, engineers, and technicians needed to develop a petroleum industry. Roosevelt suggested that the U.S.A. could establish a reciprocal aid program that would have as its purpose the development of skilled engineers and scientists and technicians, using American universities for the training. Roosevelt then suggested that the Sultan could engage American firms to carry out the development program he had in mind, on a fee or small percentage basis. American aid would not be exploitative, said FDR, nor would it ask for control of resources or political institutions. \u201c\n\u201cChurchill was described as ``glowering'' when he left the room.\u201c\n\u201cA year later, in a speech to the Negro News Publishers Association, Roosevelt gave additional description of the conflict with Churchill, referring to his view of colonial rule in Gambia:\n``I am taking up with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at the present time--I think that he will see the point--the general thought that the United Nations ought to have an inspection committee of all these colonies that are way, way down the line, that are not ready to have anything to say because the owning country has given them no facilities.\n``And if we send a committee from the United Nations, and I used the example of Gambia, to go down to Gambia, `If you Britishers don't come up to scratch--toe the mark--then we will let the world know.\n``Well, the Prime Minister doesn't like that idea. And his comeback was: `All right, the United Nations will send an inspection committee to your own South in America.'' (Laughter)\n``I said, `Winston, that's all right with me. Go ahead and do it. Tell the world. We call it freedom of the press, and you call it `pitiless publicity'--you can right a lot of wrong with `pitiless publicity.'|''\nThrough to the End\n\u201cRunning for an unprecedented fourth term in 1944, Roosevelt used the election campaign to educate Americans about their special responsibility in the creation of the postwar world. It is in the interest of America, he told them in several speeches, to rebuild the world in its image, to give hope and prosperity to millions. The campaign to make the world's population truly free from want, as he had promised in his Four Freedoms speech three years earlier, would mean jobs and prosperity for Americans: It was in our own best interests to see others prosper. \u201c\n\u201cSpeaking at the meeting of the International Labor Organization in May, was broadcast nationally, Roosevelt dsecribed the horrors of the British imperial system in Gambia, he said:\n``I think that we can get somewhere if we keep that idea of being `agin'--as we say in Irish-American--`against' exploitation everywhere. It would be an awfully good thing for all of us....''\n\u201cHowever, Roosevelt balked at enlisting the American people into his fight against Churchill and the British Empire. That would have to wait, he told aides, until after the war was won on the battlefields. \u201c\n\u201cThe British responded to the threat Roosevelt represented through the mouth of GOP candidate Thomas Dewey, who was controlled by John Foster Dulles. Dewey claimed that Roosevelt and the New Deal apparatus responsible for his economic proposals were ``communists'' and that Roosevelt, if elected, would turn the country over to the ``Reds.''\n\u201cChurchill, meanwhile, was prepared to stall. FDR suffered from serious heart problems and hypertension, although his own physicians thought that he could survive through a fourth term. By late 1944, Churchill was in receipt of a secret briefing on the President's health by Churchill's personal physician Lord Moran: Roosevelt had only several months to live, at best, perhaps a year. \u201c\n\u201c(It cannot be ruled out that the British may have had a direct hand in the President's deteriorating health. it is certainly the case that Churchill, through his insistence on two summits in Canada during the height of the campaign, and his delay of the proposed summit with Stalin until it required a precarious, 12,000-mile mid-winter trip to Yalta, deliberately caused strain and helped wear out Roosevelt. Doctors have since stated that the strain of the Yalta trip may have taken several months or even a year from Roosevelt's life.) \u201c\n\u201cAt Yalta in February 1945, Roosevelt continued to doggedly pursue the policies that had guided him since 1941. He sought and won from Stalin an agreement to keep China whole, to allow for a coalition government between the Communists and Chiang, and to make it one of the ``Big Four.'' He also gained specific agreement for Russian entry into the war against Japan; for Roosevelt, who was in possession of secret military briefings from MacArthur's spies in Japan, a Russian invasion of Manchuria and attacks on Korea would mean that an invasion of the Japanese mainland was not necessary. (Immediately upon his return to the United States, Roosevelt, in reviewing invasion plans, with MacArthur's full consent, put them all on hold. His son Elliot, as well as others close to him, say that FDR already believed that the military use of the atomic bomb was unncecessary to gain a victory over Japan and would have never consented to its use on populated areas.) \u201c\n\u201cRoosevelt believed that he would be personally able to force Stalin to abide by his agreements; he expressed more fear about duplicity from the British than from the Soviet leader. \u201c\n\u201cThe records of the February 1945 Yalta meeting, now public, also show that Roosevelt put on the table his plans to place the British Empire under international supervision, as a step toward dismantling it. According to Elliot Roosevelt, Churchill responded with rage:\n``I will never agree to the fumbling fingers of 40 or 50 nations prying into the existence of the British Empire.... While there is life in my body, no transfer of British sovereignty will be permitted.''\n\u201cOn Feb. 23, 1944, during his return from Yalta aboard the U.S.S. Quincy, Roosevelt held an ``off the record'' press briefing for reporters. He told them of his extraordinary plans to make the deserts bloom in the Middle East, using oil resources for vast irrigation programs. Roosevelt explained that, in his mind, this was what the new United Nations was going to be all about. \u201c\n\u201cHe then stated that he was not going to allow the French to reclaim Indochina and that Stalin and Chiang were in agreement with him:\n``With the Indo-Chinese, there is a feeling that they ought to be independent but they are not ready for it. I suggested at the time, that Indo-China be set up under trusteeship--have a Frenchman, one or two Indo-Chinese, a Chinese, and a Russian because they are on the coast, and maybe a Filipino and an American--to educate them for self-government....\n``Stalin liked the idea. Chiang liked the idea. The British don't like it. It might bust up their empire, because if the Indo-Chinese were to work together and eventually get their independence, the Burmese might do the same thing to England. The French have talked about how they expect to recapture Indo-China, but they haven't got any shipping to do it with.\n``It [Roosevelt's idea of trusteeship for Indo-China] would only get the British mad. Chiang would go along. Stalin would go along. As for the British, it would only make the British mad. Better to keep quiet, just now.\n``Is that Churchill's idea on all territory out there, that he wants it back just the way they were?'' Roosevelt was asked. He replied, ``Yes, he is mid-Victorian on all things like that.''\n\u201cA reporter asked FDR whether Churchill's position weren't ``inconsistent with a policy of self-determination [as expressed in the Atlantic Charter, for example]?''\n``Yes, that is true,'' Roosevelt replied. The reporter informed the President that Churchill had just the other day reiterated that the principles in the Atlantic Charter, including the clause that gave all peoples held against their will a fundamental right to freedom, was ``not a rule, just a guide.''\n``Do you remember that speech the prime minister made about the fact that he was not made prime minister of Great Britain to see the empire fall apart?'' a reporter asked the President.\n``Dear old Winston will never learn on that point,'' said Roosevelt. ``He has made his specialty on that point. This, of course, is off the record.''\n\u201cIn his last days, Roosevelt was working on plan, which he had preliminarily dubbed ``Food for Peace,'' which involved the unleashing of American agriculture to feed the world, while deploying American technology to make the hungry nations food self-sufficient. He was also preoccupied with trying to prevent the British, in particular Churchill, from staging provocations that would split the United States from Russia, using territorial disputes in Europe as a pretext; at a cabinet meeting on March 16, one of the last attended by FDR, according to the notes of one participant:\n``The President indicated considerable difficulty with British relations.... He stated that the British were perfectly willing for the United States to have a war with Russia at any time and that, in his opinion, to follow the British program would be to proceed toward that end.''\nConclusion\n\u201cOn April 12, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, 32nd President of the United States, patriot, and enemy of the British Empire, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Warm Springs, Georgia. Almost immediately, British agents moved to obliterate Roosevelt's policies and his postwar plans. \u201c\n\u201cOrders that were being prepared for U.S. ships and marines to take Hong Kong and turn it over to the Chinese, were aborted. Other plans to prevent the French from retaking Indochina were cancelled, and American troops in the area were told to stand aside. The imperial flags went back up, as Churchill had been demanding, all over the world. \u201c\n\u201cLater that same month, in San Francisco, the American delegation to the United Nations conference voted against proposals that were aimed at placing the British and French colonial possessions under international supervision and with a definite timetable for independence. America, said delegation leader Harold Stassen, had but one true ally, the British, and we must always stand by her side. The United Nations, taken over by a pack of British agents, including Julian Huxley, soon became a tool for British imperial interests. \u201c\n\u201cIn August, President Truman, manipulated by the British agent Henry Simpson, dropped atomic bombs that Roosevelt never planned to use on a nation already prepared to surrender, claiming to ``save'' American lives in an invasion of Japan--which FDR and his top military commanders knew was unncessary. \u201c\n\u201cNot one of the economic development projects proposed by Roosevelt and already in planning stages, ever saw the light of day. \u201c\n\u201cRoosevelt had failed to develop a leadership cadre to carry on without him. This was, in part, because of his own leadership style, which tended to centralize important decision-making in himself and which often manipulated even his closest aides against each other. Ultimately, he found that aides, like Hurley, were unable to generate ideas or policy. He groomed no political successor, and within the patriotic faction which had, sometimes reluctantly, been forced to follow his leadership, there was no one who could hold a candle to FDR. \u201c\n\u201cBut, Roosevelt was also unable, because of his own limited comprehension of the history of the ideas that informed his thinking, to explain them in their most profound sense to others. He was a patriot, with great instincts, and human compassion, but he had an imperfect understanding of the history of the conflict that he found himself in the middle of: The battle between the American republican tradition and British oligarchism. Those closest to him, often themselves infected with the disease of anglophilia, failed to understand this fight; and without him present, they were easy pickings for skilled British operatives. \u201c\nFDR was arguably the greatest American President of this century, who understood how to use the power of the presidency as no individual before or since. He was, as President, the best at organizing the American citizenry behind a program. Yet, though at war with the British Empire and all it stood for, Roosevelt never brought the American people fully into that battle, never told them of the depths of his disagreements with Churchill. He said he was waiting to do this until the war's end, but it never happened. In the absence of a population mobilized against the British, the invidious Harry Truman, handled for the British by Simpson and Jimmy Byrnes, could reverse the direction of Roosevelt's policies. We thus continue suffer the consequences from this fatal error of Roosevelt's judgment.\u201c\nAttribution:\nThe Other War: FDR's Battle Against Churchill and the British Empire", "The best-known British tribute to FDR is a statue in Grosvenor Square, London.", "When he was in power, during very dark times, I would think the average Brit soaked up the hype and worshipped the man.\nBUT, with hindsight, while strongly supporting Britain after the late, and forced, entry of USA into the war, he did his duty and as far as he could managed affairs to maximise profit for USA. This required bankruptcy for Britain, while vast economic growth for USA, and the eventual breakup of the entire British Empire, an outcome he pursued with well disguised zeal. USA emerged victorious and wealthy from the war, UK triumphant but economically ruined. In UK eyes this somewhat modifies our view of FDR.", "Gosh, that brings back memories. I was a teenager when FDR ceased to be. I was quite a fan I guess but I think it was much better when FDR and DDR united to become one country again. I remember very clearly when that wall came down, such a happy day, up right there with when Nelson Mandela was released.\n(I hope that's the FDR you mean, I guess there are other things it could stand for, there are so many acronyms these days.)"], "topic_list": ["What Do the British Think Of", "Franklin D. The problem is that he didn\u2019t propose it as a scientific theory but began proclaiming it as truth, though there was no conclusive proof of it at the time. Even so, Galileo would not have been in so much trouble if he had chosen to stay within the realm of science and out of the realm of theology.\nHe argued that some passages were to be taken literally and others weren\u2019t - which, considering he was not a scriptural scholar, was considered as stepping out of his bounds of knowledge.\nThe net result wasn\u2019t torture and / or death - neither happened. His works were condemned for speculation on (theology) that he didn\u2019t have the knowledge or proof for", "Isaiah 40:22 says the Earth is round, sure, but round is not a sphere. But by the Middle Ages all those educated in a probably fairly recondite area of knowledge understood that that was how it was.\nMost people (if they thought much about it) understood that God made the world and that anything not obvious was explained by the Bible. The Bible agreed (maybe not quite explicitly) with the obvious, that the Earth was at the very centre of Creation and that everything, Sun, Moon and stars went round it. The God created Copernicus who demonstrated mathematically that this view was incorrect and that the Earth\u2019s movement had a centre, the Sun (heliocentricity).\nNot too many people find maths straightforward, so God created Galileo Galilei to make an improved telescope by which maths could be escaped and heliocentricity could be observed (well, more or less). So now it is clear to those who have the chance of doing so can see. So what was actually a bit of a theological sideline was actually wrong, which confronted the educated with an embarrassment and some confusion. Actually many senior clerics did actually see by means of Galileo\u2019s telescope, and they were clever, educated and for the day scientifically informed, including most of the Jesuit order, and Cardinal Bellarmine who had himself supported Galileo and had used his telescope.\nUnfortunately Galileo was not the nicest man and enjoyed taking the piss out of the less well informed and found opportunities to do so in the Bible and its beliefs, and with those he made himself very unpopular, especially in one of his writings in which the victim was the Pope. Now even the clever, educated clerics could not support him. Galileo had even made enemies of them.\nAll this took place while the Roman Catholic Church was dealing with a confrontation with a very major revision of conventions that had held for a millennium. Astronomical revisions that served to enlarge doubts that seemed impossible were not welcome, and intellectual balance was not readily at hand. There were plenty of victims, some of them on the strength of their own delusions (Savonalola, Giordiano Bruno). At least Galileo was permitted to quietly retire, so long as he kept his mouth shut.", "They lied to protect the world from greed most likely", "This is a case of urban myths of history and the Middle Ages is the worst era hit by these misconceptions and outright balderdash.\nFlat Earth is one of them. To the best of my knowledge, the Catholic Church never denied that the Earth was round. That had been figured out well back into classical antiquity and remained the intellectual consensus thereafter.\nWhat they didn\u2019t agree with was the heliocentric model. The church bought into the intellectual consensus at the time that the spherical Earth was surrounded by systems of epicycles, invisibly transparent crystalline spheres which carried the stars and planets. distance of the Panama Canal. They had enough fuel to reach Hawaii and return home. They didn\u2019t have the slower fuel tankers accompanying them to provide additional fuel for such a distant secondary target. Admiral Nagumo refused to launch a third strike against the American naval base because he knew they had lost the element of surprise. Attempting to try for a secondary distant target after the alert had been sounded might encounter U.S. warships in that sector of the Pacific. And without knowing where the missing carriers from Pearl Harbor actually were, he could have been sailing into a trap. Hitting Pearl Harbor was enough of a gamble that paid off and it was best to sail back to the Home Islands without tempting \u2018fate.\u2019 Efforts to Cripple the Panama Canal would come later. Not even a flea on a dog\u2019s worth of damage like the other Japanese attacks on the US mainland.", "Logistacally impossible plus the chances of actually inflcting serious damage on the canal would only come about it they knocked out the lock gates at Gatun, an that would be a very difficult task\nThen if somehow they managed to solve the logisitics they would have to get past the carrier group the Americans would have mobilised to intercept from Pearl and California - but the Japanese would be very low on bombs and torpedos and many of the aircraft would be unservicable/lost", "In December 1941, could the Japanese force that attacked Pearl harbour have also attacked the Panama Canal? If so, what effect would this have had on the war if they did?\nNO, the Japanese could not have used the Kido Butai to attack both the Panama Canal and Pearl Harbor. The first impassable obstacle was logistics: it takes fuel to sail from northern Japan, raid an enemy facility, and return home safely. The Japanese did not have the fuel capacity, or sufficient at-sea refueling capacity, to get from Japan to Panama. The second is that they could not have carried out both such raids in secret. Suppose they had somehow devised a way to go all the way to Panama first, and got there without having been discovered first. An attack on the Canal would start the war and alert all of the forces at Pearl Harbor that the Japanese had a large fleet at sea somewhere east of Hawaii that had to get home to Japan. An intense search effort would follow, plus the forces at PH would be on high alert. The success the Japanese achieved at PH was due, in largest part, to having achieved surprise, without that they would have lost a lot of planes and done much less damage, and if the US carrier forces had located them in range of Hawaii they would likely have sunk some of the Japanese carriers. If they tried it the other way, Hawaii first and then on to the Canal, they would have the same problem\u2026lack of surprise at the target, plus intense searches likely to discover them at sea and sink some of the carriers even before they came within range of the Canal. Then they would still have to try to get back to Japan, which would be a long voyage through hostile seas subject to attack by USN submarines, long-range bombers, and USN carrier forces.\nA third problem is that the carriers could only carry a certain quantity of bombs and ammunition for plane guns. They expended a good deal of this in the raid on PH; they would not have enough to do much damage at the Canal, assuming they went there second and had a (magic) way to get there to launch an attack. This problem would be the same if they attacked the Canal first and then tried to attack PH on the way home.\nFinally, the surprise the Japanese achieved in their PH raid was due, in part, to American complacency about Japanese capabilities and intentions in a time of peace. It was also due to their course to PH\u2026they left far northern Japan and traveled through the stormy winter North Pacific, far off normal trade routes, and so avoided detection by any merchant vessels or USN patrols. There is no such route to Panama from Japan, the Canal was then and is now a major hub for shipping coming out of, or headed into, the Atlantic from the Pacific. To remain undetected all the way from Japan to within attack range of Panama would be extremely unlikely."], "topic_list": ["Panama Canal", "Pearl Harbor, HI", "Attack on Pearl Harbor (December 1941)", "Japan in World War II", "Alternate Histories (Hypothetical Historical Scenarios)", "Japan", "World War II", "Warfare", "Military History and Wars", "History"], "view_list": [103, 60, 15, 85, 165, 174], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Randy Topechka", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 2, 2], "question_title": "In December 1941, could the Japanese force that attacked Pearl harbour have also attacked the Panama Canal? He then went on to become the second youngest full professor in history (at the time), at just 24.\nThen World War II broke out. Powell left academia and enlisted in the British Army, as a private. They were competent professionals. But they were not superheroes. They could and sometimes did lose battles to armies we don\u2019t romanticize as we do the Spartans and the Romans. That is, anybody under the right circumstances could beat either of them. There was, for example, nothing particularly special about the Theban troops who smashed the Spartans at Leuctra. Epiminondas came up with a clever tactical innovation which the Spartans weren\u2019t prepared to deal with.\nThe experience and professionalism of both sides gave them an edge over many other armies, made up mostly of part-time troops, but it was always an advantage, not a trump card. And against roughly equivalent troops, it more than usually comes down to other factors: terrain, how tired one side or the other might be after long marches or lack of supply, the skill and determination of the individual leaders, and so on. All other things being equal, I\u2019d give the Romans a slight edge. Classically, the style of fighting the Spartans were trained for was replaced by Macedonian phalanx, which in turn could be countered by Roman manipular formations. The Romans are basically using tactics from a couple of generations on from the Spartans and are arguably better off against the Spartans\u2019 old style of fighting than the Spartans are against the Romans\u2019 newer tactics. But, again, this would be a small statistical advantage, not a guaranteed victory.", "The Roman republic conquered the Greek peninsula in 146 BC. It was essentially a laboratory experiment. It was abandoned even though the German scientific community, what was left after the purges, knew mathematically it was possible. They were on the right track is about all that can be said.\nGoogle Image Result for https://www.history.com/.image/t_share/MTYzMjc0ODgyNTY0NDk4NzM0/haigerloch-germany-hitler-nuclear_ap_987916251618.jpg\nYouTube video:", "Not even close, he wasn\u2019t even interested in the atomic bomb. Rockets, missiles and jet aircraft where going to win the war according to Hitler.\nLike others have said the best nuclear scientists where Jewish and of course they left the country or ended up in a camp.", "Not at all close because the Nazi's were their own worst enemies, and their policies against Jews would lead to their undoing.\nHitler could easily have had the first nuclear weapon in the history of the World, however, the anti Semitism of the Nazi regime ensured he would not have one. The Genocide of Jews also ensured that no negotiated peace would occur with the nations Germany was at war with. The anti -Semitism of the Nazi party was the greatest contributor to the ultimate defeat of the Reich. The opportunity to be liberators of people in the USSR who had suffered under murderous communist policies was squandered and replaced with murderous Nazi policies.\nGerman nuclear weapons program - Wikipedia\n\u201cMax Planck, the father of quantum theory, had been right in assessing the consequences of National Socialist policies. In 1933, Planck, as president of the\nKaiser Wilhelm Gesellschaft\n(Kaiser Wilhelm Society), met with Adolf Hitler. During the meeting, Planck told Hitler that forcing Jewish scientists to emigrate would mutilate Germany and the benefits of their work would go to foreign countries. Hitler responded with a rant against Jews and Planck could only remain silent and then take his leave. The National Socialist regime would only come around to the same conclusion as Planck in the 6 July 1942 meeting regarding the future agenda of the\nReichsforschungsrat\n(RFR, Reich Research Council), but by then it was too late.\n\u201cA meeting was held on 6 July 1942 to discuss the function of the RFR and set its agenda. The meeting was a turning point in National Socialism's attitude towards science, as well as recognition that the policies which drove Jewish scientists out of Germany were a mistake, as the Reich needed their expertise.\u201d\nHeisenberg\nsaid in 1939 that the physicists at the (second) meeting said that in principle atomic bombs could be made.... it would take years.... not before five. He said I didn't report it to the Fuehrer until two weeks later and very casually because I did not want the Fuehrer to get so interested that he would order great efforts immediately to make the atomic bomb. Speer felt it was better that the whole thing should be dropped and the Fuehrer also reacted that way. He said they presented the matter in this way for their personal safety as the probability (of success) was nearly zero, but if many thousands (of) people developed nothing, that could have extremely disagreeable consequences for us.\n[17]\nSo we turned the slogan around to make use of warfare for physics not make use of physics for warfare\n[18]\nErhard Milch asked how long America would take and was told 1944 though the group between ourselves thought it would take longer, three or four years.\n[19]\nOn 4 June 1942, a conference regarding the project, initiated by Albert Speer\nas head of the \"Reich Ministry for Armament and Ammunition\" (RMBM: Reichsministerium f\u00fcr Bewaffnung und Munition; after late 1943 the Reich Ministry for Armament and War Production), decided on its continuation merely for the aim of energy production.\n[26]\nOn 9 June 1942, Adolf Hitler\nissued a decree for the reorganization of the RFR as a separate legal entity under the RMBM; the decree appointed Reich Marshal Hermann G\u00f6ring\nas its president.\n[27]\nThe reorganization was done under the initiative of Minister Albert Speer\nof the RMBM; it was necessary as the RFR under Bernhard Rust\nthe Minister of Science, Education and National Culture was ineffective and was not achieving its purpose.\n[28]\nThe hope was that G\u00f6ring would manage the RFR with the same discipline and efficiency as he had the aviation sector. A meeting was held on 6 July 1942 to discuss the function of the RFR and set its agenda. The meeting was a turning point in National Socialism's attitude towards science, as well as recognition that the policies which drove Jewish scientists out of Germany were a mistake, as the Reich needed their expertise. Abraham Esau\nwas appointed on 8 December 1942 as Hermann G\u00f6ring's\nBevollm\u00e4chtigter (plenipotentiary) for nuclear physics research under the RFR; in December 1943, Esau was replaced by Walther Gerlach\n. In the final analysis, placing the RFR under G\u00f6ring's administrative control had little effect on the German nuclear weapon project.\nSpeer states that the project to develop the atom bomb was scuttled in the autumn of 1942. Though the scientific solution was there, it would have taken all of Germany's production resources to produce a bomb, and then no sooner than 1947.\n[33]\nDevelopment did continue with a \"uranium motor\" for the navy and development of a German cyclotron\n. However, by the summer of 1943, Speer released the remaining 1200 metric tons\nof uranium stock for the production of solid-core ammunition.\n[34]\nThe most influential people in the Uranverein were Kurt Diebner\n, Abraham Esau\n, Walther Gerlach\n, and Erich Schumann\n; Schumann was one of the most powerful and influential physicists in Germany. Diebner, throughout the life of the nuclear weapon project, had more control over nuclear fission research than did Walther Bothe\n, Klaus Clusius\n, Otto Hahn\n, Paul Harteck\n, or Werner Heisenberg\n. Abraham Esau was appointed as Hermann G\u00f6ring's plenipotentiary for nuclear physics research in December 1942; Walther Gerlach succeeded him in December 1943.\nPoliticization of the German academia\nunder the National Socialist\nregime had driven many physicists, engineers, and mathematicians out of Germany as early as 1933. Those of Jewish heritage who did not leave were quickly purged from German institutions, further thinning the ranks of academia. The politicization of the universities, along with the demands for manpower by the German armed forces (many scientists and technical personnel were conscripted, despite possessing useful skills), substantially reduced the number of able German physicists.\n[2]\nEmigrations[edit]\nAdolf Hitler took power on 30 January 1933. On 7 April, the Law for the Restoration of the Professional Civil Service was enacted; this law, and its subsequent related ordinances, politicized the education system in Germany. This had immediate damaging effects on the physics capabilities of Germany. Furthermore, combined with the\nDeutsche Physik\nmovement, the damaging effects were intensified and prolonged. The consequences to physics in Germany and its subfield of nuclear physics were multifaceted.\nAn immediate consequence upon passage of the law was that it produced both quantitative and qualitative losses to the physics community. Numerically, it has been estimated that a total of 1,145 university teachers, in all fields, were driven from their posts, which represented about 14% of the higher learning institutional staff members in 1932\u20131933.\n[45]\nOut of 26 German nuclear physicists cited in the literature before 1933, 50% emigrated.\n[46]\nQualitatively, 11 physicists and four chemists who had won or would win the Nobel Prize emigrated from Germany shortly after Hitler came to power, most of them in 1933.\n[47]\nThese 15 scientists were: Hans Bethe, Felix Bloch, Max Born, Albert Einstein, James Franck, Heinrich Gerhard Kuhn, Peter Debye, Dennis Gabor, Fritz Haber, Gerhard Herzberg, Victor Hess, George de Hevesy, Erwin Schr\u00f6dinger, Otto Stern, and Eugene Wigner. Britain and the United States were often the recipients of the talent which left Germany.\n[48]\nThe University of G\u00f6ttingen had 45 dismissals from the staff of 1932\u20131933, for a loss of 19%.\n[45]\nEight students, assistants, and colleagues of the G\u00f6ttingen theoretical physicist Max Born left Europe after Hitler came to power and eventually found work on the Manhattan Project, thus helping the United States, Britain and Canada to develop the atomic bomb; they were Enrico Fermi,\n[49]\nJames Franck, Maria Goeppert-Mayer, Robert Oppenheimer (who was American, but had studied under Born), Edward Teller, Victor Weisskopf, Eugene Wigner, and John von Neumann.\n[50]\nOtto Robert Frisch, who with Rudolf Peierls first calculated the critical mass of U-235 needed for an explosive, was also a Jewish refugee.\nMax Planck, the father of quantum theory, had been right in assessing the consequences of National Socialist policies. In 1933, Planck, as president of the\nKaiser Wilhelm Gesellschaft\n(Kaiser Wilhelm Society), met with Adolf Hitler. During the meeting, Planck told Hitler that forcing Jewish scientists to emigrate would mutilate Germany and the benefits of their work would go to foreign countries. Hitler responded with a rant against Jews and Planck could only remain silent and then take his leave. The National Socialist regime would only come around to the same conclusion as Planck in the 6 July 1942 meeting regarding the future agenda of the\nReichsforschungsrat\n(RFR, Reich Research Council), but by then it was too late.\n[29]\n[51]\nAt the end of the war, the Allied powers competed to obtain surviving components of the nuclear industry (personnel, facilities, and materiel\n), as they did with the pioneering V-2\nSRBM\nprogram\nGerman historian Klaus Hentschel summarizes the organizational differences as:\nCompared with the British and American war research efforts united in the Manhattan Project, to this day the prime example of 'big science,\" the Uranverein was only a loosely knit, decentralized network of researchers with quite different research agendas. Rather than teamwork as on the American end, on the German side we find cut-throat competition, personal rivalries, and fighting over the limited resources.\n[119]\nIn terms of financial and human resources, the comparisons between the Manhattan Project and the Uranverein are stark. The Manhattan Project consumed some US$2 billion (1945) in government funds, and employed at its peak some 120,000 people, mostly in the sectors of construction and operations. Total, the Manhattan Project involved the labor of some 500,000 people, nearly 1% of the entire US civilian labor force.\n[120]\nBy comparison, the Uranverein was budgeted a mere 8 million reichsmarks, equivalent to about US$2 million (1945) \u2014 a factor of 1,000 less.\n[121]\nNear the end of World War II, the principal Allied war powers each made plans for exploitation of German science. In light of the implications of nuclear weapons, German nuclear fission and related technologies were singled out for special attention. In addition to exploitation, denial of these technologies, their personnel, and related materials to rival allies was a driving force of their efforts. This typically meant getting to these resources first, which to some extent put the Soviets at a disadvantage in some geographic locations easily reached by the Western Allies, even if the area was destined to be in the Soviet zone of occupation by the Potsdam Conference\n. At times all parties were heavy-handed in their pursuit and denial to others.\nThe best known US denial and exploitation effort was Operation Paperclip\n, a broad dragnet that encompassed a wide range of advanced fields, including jet and rocket propulsion, nuclear physics, and other developments with military applications such as infrared technology. Operations directed specifically towards German nuclear fission were Operation Alsos\nand Operation Epsilon\n, the latter being done in collaboration with the British. In lieu of the codename for the Soviet operation it is referred to by Oleynikov as the Russian \"Alsos\"\n.\n[78]", "Basically Germany was way way off a deliverable nuclear weapon.\nAnd the reasons for this are:\nIt was Jewish science and thus discounted by the Nazis.\nA large number of Jewish physicists had left including Einstein although Heisenberg stayed and then he had some explaining to do after the war.\nThe sheer industrial scale of it all and the cost of it. "\u2026\nwho discovered spirit?\n\u2026\ndisambiguation:\nspirit as in awareness or soul\nspirit as in team spirit or school spirit\nspirit in religion, such as allah, ganesha, or the holy ghost\nspirit in mythology such as ghosts, faeries, angels, jinns, or deities\nso which one of these did you really mean, eh?\n\u2026\nlet us begin with the process of discovery as it will apply to all four meanings given above.\nhumans discover everything in many over-lapping stages.\nboth individual and cultural lexicons must develop in parallel to enable people to talk about their experiences.\nthose lexicons will be somewhat ambiguous because the precise meanings each word acquires may be different enough to fall into two or more categories as in the example provided by the disambiguation above, or different people or cultures may use words differently, sometimes in manners that may be nearly unique to themselves alone, or nearly unique to their respective cultures.\nconsequently, few things are ever really discovered by a single individual.\nhistory books do humanity a great disservice by creating the illusion that there was only one discoverer of america, one inventor of the automobile, one inventor of the airplane, or one inventor of the light bulb.\nthat\u2019s just nonsense, but it guides people into a stronger belief in individual importance and it also reinforces the illusion of authority.\nthese are important beliefs and illusions that are difficult to challenge; selective bias helps reinforce only those ideas or beliefs that support what a person or culture already thinks or chooses to believe.\nbooks that offend some people\u2019s local conventional wisdom are still being burned in many places around the world today.\nthat is the operation of cultural selective bias at some of it\u2019s best or worst depending upon whether you support the author or the author\u2019s critics.\nof course, nearly the worst punishment was often murdering the author outright, such as many people feared or hoped might happen when salman rushdie published his notorious book \u2018satanic verses\u2019.\nthat book was far less terrible or objectionable than the controversy that followed.\nit was a collection of beautiful poems in which rushdie explored his own spirituality in context with what he could learn about other people\u2019s spirituality; the book expressed his love of his lord allah, and his revered prophet muhammad.\na beautiful book.\nanyways\u2026\nthe very worst punishment is called genocide, and that is still being carried out around the world today as well.\n\u2026\nvery few ideas of any sort can ever be attributed to a single person; often when such attributions are made they are mistaken, either due to ignorance, social or cultural influence, or deliberate fraud.\nwith regard to spirit, there are cultural reflections of various people\u2019s beliefs or experiences with their own spirits from all over the world.\nevery culture handles their spiritual experiences and beliefs uniquely, but it is still possible to find many similarities in beliefs and practices from what may appear to be two or more disparate cultures.\neven within any given culture there will be factions, assent, or dissent with regard to what people may choose to believe about spirits.\n\u2026\none of the most common aspects of spirit found in nearly all cultures is belief in a human personal spirit or soul.\nin some cultures animals are regarded as having spirits or souls, and some cultures extend the concept of possessing a spirit or soul to all beings, even inanimate beings such as a brick, a rock, or a grain of sand, and the earth, moon, sun, and stars.\nso concepts regarding spirit in the sense of being a part of a person\u2019s soul are both widespread globally and potentially universally inclusive of every part of whatever the manifest worlds and universes people experience may really be.\nno one knows because, while nearly everyone appears to have spiritual experiences in their lives, the nature of spiritual experiences is usually a strongly internalized feeling rather than an objective miraculous event witnessed by many people.\nthere is little or no evidence of spirituality that can be examined under a microscope or measured in four or more dimensions.\nsome people will say that there is no evidence at all, but they are then denying the personal experiences of billions of people who believe in spirits and souls because their experiences have a strong power of conviction regardless of whether any real evidence will ever be forthcoming.\nthat is why we have faith.\nfaith expresses our conviction in something intangible within ourselves that cannot be denied in spite of any lack of evidence.\nwhen we feel our own spirit it feels like something dwelling within us in our heart. when we recognize this indwelling spirit in other people we learn to extend our faith in our own spirit to other living beings.\nspiritual experiences often leave people with a strong conviction that everyone or everything in the worlds and universes they experience shares this indwelling spirit, and as language and cultures evolved their concepts regarding this indwelling spirit evolved into nature spirits, deities, pantheons, and religions.\nwe all share the same indwelling spirit which may be regarded as distinct from one\u2019s own spirit on one hand, but also as providing us with identity with some global or universal spirit on another hand.\nfortunately, we have more than two hands, eh? <wink>\nanyways\u2026\nthat\u2019s a sufficient story for spirit in the first case, and we are pretty sure you are clever enough to apply what we have shared with you to the remaining cases on your own.\n\u2026\n-enjoy!\nlove, the grigs\u2026\n\u2026\nif you liked this answer you may also like to read any of the following:\ngharveyn's article: hell in a It is also really important to distinguish between the CCP, the State, the country and the people of China. The CCP is a one-party authoritarian organisation that attempts to control the people and the economy of China. The State is almost the same, except that it was there before and will continue to exist after the CCP is gone, the country is the amazing and diverse natural environment, that includes unique mountains, rivers and incredible biodiversity. The people of China are mostly Han Chinese, but not all. There are many languages spoken and even within the Han population quite a lot of ethnic variation.\nYou cannot say China is good or China is bad unless you have some sort of hangup. Yang"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "87": {"ans_list": ["Modesta being modest\nFirst all the word dark is a rather meaningless term which is rooted in the insecurities of lighter complexioned people. In out UV bathed environment human skin actually evolves towards dark skin and lighter skin is actually an interruption of that process.\nBeing Indian I\u2019m sure you are aware that Krishna is the most perfect of men, and women like Devaki and Draupadi were the most perfect of women.\nParvati only gave up her beautiful midnight complexion for a golden one because Shiva teased her otherwise she would still be Nyakim\u2019s beautiful complexion. She probably regrets it because these days golden skin is not enough, only the pale white skin of a Nordic woman is good enough and she probably doesn\u2019t want to go that far.\nSo you see Nyakim\u2019s complexion is the way it is because it is the perfect of all complexions."], "topic_list": ["Complexion", "Reason", "Queen Elizabeth II", "Skin", "History"], "view_list": [33], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Barkha Barkat", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What is the reason behind the dark complexion of the Queen of Dark Nyakim Gatwech?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "113", "name_list": ["Frank Church"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "531": {"ans_list": ["What was the major difference between the Anglican Church and the Catholic Church during the reign of Henry the VIII?\nThis is far to complicated a question to answer in any detail in this forum. The English Church broke with Rome between 1532 to 1534. Henry died in 1547. I feels premature to speak of the Anglican Church at this early date.\nInitial reforms made the King the head of the Church in England. There had been long standing dissatisfaction with money sent to Rome (and monasteries sending money to mother houses in France). These were curtailed. There were issues with clergy being brought to trial in Church courts rather than the Kings courts. All these issues were addressed in early legislation.\nThe kinds of things that one might think of such as prayer to Mary, reception of sacraments, and the uses of sacred vestments were not initially the issue.\nKeeping in mind that the King\u2019s health was in decline, what followed the Act of Supremacy and related legislation, was basically a struggle between three groups. The King was conservative and preferred to keep rituals and sacraments as they had always been. But he had appointed Cromwell and Cranmer to high posts to facilitate his annulment. They were part of the second group of reformers who had been influenced by Luther and other Continental reformers. (Incidentally, Cromwell was beheaded by the King. Folks took these disagreements seriously in those days).\nThe third, least powerful group were the Anabaptists who had been influenced by radical reforms on the Continent.\nSo if we were to ask what was the difference between the national Church in England and the Catholic Church, we would have to define exactly when and where. The Monasteries were suppressed starting in 1536. Mass was said in English. Pilgrimages and lesser feast days were abolished. Generally the veneration of relics and that sort of thing were done away with.\nAnabaptists were persecuted. But conservatives (catholics) and reformers (Lutherans) continued to push and pull back and forth. It was not until Edward\u2019s reign that the Protestant forces clearly gained the upper hand.", "There was no Anglican Church until Henry Vlll created it and abandoned the Catholic Church (parted company with ROME).", "The major difference was that the Pope was the head of the Catholic Church and Henry VIII was the head of the Anglican Church. England no longer had to pay monies to Rome and the monasteries, convents and abbeys that had been owned by the Church were now controlled by Henry, through his officials. Selling these brought Henry enormous wealth. At the time, doctrinally, there was little difference and Henry considered himself to be a Catholic. The Ten Articles of 1536, probably writter by Archbishop Cranmer, explained the new doctrines:\nArticles related to doctrines:\n1. That Holy Scriptures and the three Creeds are the basis and summary of a true Christian faith.\n2. That baptism conveys remission of sins and the regenerating grace of the Holy Spirit, and is absolutely necessary as well for children as adults.\n3. That penance consists of contrition, confession, and reformation, and is necessary to salvation.\n4. That the body and blood of Christ are really present in the elements of the eucharist.\n5. That justification is remission of sin and reconciliation to God by the merits of Christ; but good works are necessary.\nArticles related to ceremonies:\n1. That images are useful as remembrancers, but are not objects of worship.\n2. That saints are to be honored as examples of life, and as furthering our prayers.\n3. That saints may be invoked as intercessors, and their holydays observed.\n4. That ceremonies are to be observed for the sake of their mystical signification, and as conducive to devotion.\n5. {"ans_list": ["During the winter of 1914\u201315, there were armed bands of Armenian guerillas, partly consisting of deserters from the Ottoman armed forces or of young men who had avoided conscription by taking to the hills, were launching attacks on the supply lines of the Ottoman forces fighting the Russian forces on the Caucasian border.\nThen in April 1915 there was a large-scale Armenian uprising in the city of Van, in the course of which the rebels massacred or expelled the entire Muslim population, something that was witnessed by American missionaries in the region and commented on approvingly by them. The Armenian rebels remained in control of Van until the arrival of a Russian armed force from Persia in May. In June the Russian armed force retreated back over the border into Persia, and the Armenian population went with them. It was the Armenian uprising in Van and the accompanying massacres of the Muslim, mainly Kurdish population, that caused the Ottoman Government to decide on the deportation of the Armenian population of most of Anatolia to northern Syria.\nMost of the massacres of Muslims perpetrated by Armenians occurred after much of eastern Anatolia was occupied by the Russian Army early in 1916. The Russians were assisted by Armenian auxiliaries, who wanted to create an Armenian state in the region, and for that purpose began to try to ethnically cleanse the region of its majority Muslim population, by massacre or expulsion. There are many accounts by Russian officers who witnessed the atrocities committed by their Armenian auxiliaries, and who tried to stop them. As a result of the opposition by the Russian occupiers, the attempted ethnic cleansing by the Armenians did not get very far.\nThe worst massacres committed by Armenians occurred in the spring of 1918, after the Russian armed forces retreated from eastern Anatolia in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk. Their Armenian auxiliaries tried to hang on to the region, but themselves were forced to retreat by the advancing Ottoman forces. As the Armenian bands retreated back to the Russian border, they carried out vast massacres of the Muslim population of every town they passed through, for example in Erzurum. The advancing Ottoman forces found large numbers of bodies of massacred civilians in every town they came to.\nAfter the Ottoman Empire surrendered in October 1918, Allied military officers were able to enter eastern Anatolia in order to observe the operation of the armistice conditions. Those officers saw with their own eyes the results of the atrocities committed by the Armenians, and reported back to their respective Governments that those atrocities were every bit as bad as the Ottoman atrocities that had formed such a large part of Allied wartime propaganda.", "search tallarmaniantale on google and read every bit of the site.", "Professor Justin McCarthy \u201cHundreds of Thousands of Muslims were killed by Armenian Rebels in Anatolia\u201d"], "topic_list": ["Armenian Genocide", "History of Turkey", "Armenian Ethnicity and People", "Armenia", "Ottoman Empire", "Genocide", "Turkey (country)", "History"], "view_list": [25, 4, 8], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 9, "question_author": "Vineeth Bharadwaj", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 1], "question_title": "Armenian Genocide denial sometimes involves claims that Armenians often attacked Muslims in Eastern Anatolia. "view_list": [4, 90, 6], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Saurav Malik", "upvote_list": [0, 5, 0], "question_title": "If Muhammad was the messenger of God, why did he fight so many battles?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "1,827", "name_list": ["Edmund Blackadder", "Daksh Gohil", "Rohit Tanwar"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "366": {"ans_list": ["Origins of the Italian language\nThe Italian language stems directly from Latin, just like other Romance languages like Spanish, Catalan, Portuguese, French, Romanian and other minority languages (Occitan, Proven\u00e7al, Galician, Ladin and Friulan).\nDevelopment of the language from its origins\nThe Italian language has developed through a long and gradual process, which began after the Fall of the Roman Empire in the 5th century.\nUp until this moment, Latin had spread and had been imposed across the Empire as the \u2018madre franca\u2019, or the shared language.\nAfter the fall of the Empire, vernacular and local forms of the language had an important role in society and the everyday life of the population.\nHowever, for several centuries, and especially during the Middle Ages, Latin was the dominant cultural language, used throughout European Universities and in all the official acts and procedures of the Church.\nThe foundations of modern Italian\nFrom a historical perspective, it is not wrong to claim that the high, or cultured, Tuscan dialect\n, which the three most important poets of the 1300s (Alighieri, Boccaccio and Petrarch) wrote in can be considered the basis of modern Italian. Yet despite this, the Italian language as we know it today is the result of a long process of evolution and debates, which began in the 1600s, over what the correct form of the language should be. At the end, the question of what Italian to speak remained. Even though at the end of the 1900s many writers and cultural figures were being inspired by the Tuscan model, in every aspect of the language, there are several relevant historical and social factors that need to be considered.\nFirstly, for centuries up until the Unification of Italy\nin 1861, the country was divided into a number of different states, which were usually under foreign rule. When Italy was united in 1861 the decision was taken to make Tuscan the official language of the country.\nWithin the Italian population, however, there was and always had been high rates of illiteracy, and this illiteracy continued predominantly in rural regions until the 1950s.\nAs a result, dialects were used as the everyday language for centuries, and anyone who was able to express themselves and communicate in Italian did so using grammatical, lexical and phonetical aspects influenced by regional and local dialects.\nUse of dialects in Italy\nThe use of dialects in Italy represents a unique situation compared to the rest of Europe. Even today in many different parts of Italy dialects are used as an informal way of communicating in different social settings and within families.\nContrary to popular belief, in certain Italian regions dialects are widely used\n, and not only within the older generations. Even though the use of standard Italian prevails in the younger generations, many young people can express themselves in their own dialect, or at least understand it, in informal social situations.\nIt is also worth remembering that dialects, as well as accents, can change a lot even within the same region.\nIf you take Tuscany as an example, even though there aren\u2019t real and proper dialects, the Florentine accent\ngreatly differs from that of Pisa or Livorno and that of Lucca or Arezzo.\nIn other regions, it is easy to spot dialectal differences between places in the same Province, or every those just a few kilometres away from each other. In other regions, it is easy to spot dialectal differences between places in the same Province, or every those just a few kilometres away from each other.\nDialects and regional Italian\nFor a long time, dialects have been incorrectly considered the \u201cpoor and impoverished parents\u201d of standard Italian, which has mainly developed from the Tuscan dialect. Yet, in reality, dialects represent a cultural richness.\nThis can be seen in the fact that in the last 50 years many regional terms, from Tuscany, Lombardy, Veneto, Naples and Sicily, have entered the national language. As such, it isn\u2019t surprising that dialects have been heavily studied by linguists and have been used in literature and poetry.\nIn the past, there was a prejudice towards dialects, with people thinking that standard Italian was the language used by the bourgeoise, while dialects were used by farmers and the working class, yet now this prejudice has mostly died out. For example, recent statistics have revealed that in Veneto, which is one of the most economically developed regions, around half of the population speak in dialect both with their families and with friends.\nAll you need to do is walk around one of the beautiful and historic cities of Veneto like Venice, Padua, Treviso, Verona or Vicenza to realise just how present dialects are in urban centres.\nThe spreading of standard Italian\nIn 1950, just as the country was going through a time of complete infrastructural, economic, social and politic reconstruction, less than 20% of the Italian population spoke Italian fluently in their day to day to life.\nIlliteracy and semi-illiteracy were largely present in various groups of the population. The Italian Constitution\n, which was established in 1948, gave everyone the right to a basic education.\nYet in certain situations this right to education was not completely guaranteed. Access to higher education and university was pretty much only reserved for children from more affluent families, while children from working class and farming families ended up just being an economic resource for the family.\nThis meant that many children didn\u2019t even finish primary school, even though the law demanded they stay in school until they were 18 or 20, before taking part in compulsory military service.\nPerhaps rather strangely, the event which had the biggest impact in kickstarting the unification of the language was the introduction of television\n.\nTV programs began to be broadcast by RAI\n, the state broadcaster, in 1954 on just one channel. In the years that followed, up until the economic boom between 1958 and 1962, television did not just become a way to bring people together (as very few people actually had a TV set), but also a way to broadcast cultural programs and linguistic models.\nIn fact, between 1960 and 1968 RAI broadcast a show in the late afternoon which was called Non \u00e8 mai troppo tardi\n, or \u201cIt\u2019s never too late,\u201d which was presented by the teacher Alberto Manzi. As a result of this show, many illiterate people learnt to read and write, and it is estimated that in this period around one and a half million Italians managed to get their certificate of primary education.\nAnd so, the spreading of a standardised Italian language was aided by economic growth, a better quality of life, the gradual spread of education and linguistic programmes shown on TV."], "topic_list": ["History of Italy", "Culture of Italy", "Italian Ethnicity and People", "Italian (language)", "Italy", "History"], "view_list": [20], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Naman", "upvote_list": [2], "question_title": "How has the Italian language changed over time?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "176", "name_list": ["Schanna Muliyil"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "0": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Roman Empire", "Ancient Rome", "Ancient History", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Ramkumar Parthipan", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Why was there a shortage of workers in the Roman Empire?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "81", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "628": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["History of Italy", "Byzantines", "Rome, Italy", "Roman Empire", "Ancient Rome", "Italy", "Ancient History", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 4, "question_author": "Dani Grimblat", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "How long did it take to get from Italy to Caesarea during the Roman times? The occupation of Poland was much more brutal than elsewhere, and it does remain a source of pride for Polish people to have the highest number of the Righteous Among the Nations, despite the fact that hiding Jews in occupied Poland (as opposed to most other places) was punishable by death. It really is a subject that people don\u2019t want to hear more about.", "Six countries and this answer is written as a timeline.\nIn 1951, the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was founded with six original member countries: France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands & Belgium.\nIn 1958, these same six original member also established the European Economic Community (EEC) and Euratom.\nThe 1965 Treaty of Brussels provided a unified executive for three previously mentioned institutions: ECSC, EEC and Euratom. Together, the three institutions became known as the European Communities.\nThe United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark joined the European Communities in 1973, bring the total to 9 member states. These 9 were later joined by Greece in 1981, Spain 1986 and Portugal also in 1986. The European Communities now had 12 member states.\nIn 1993, the 12 member states negotiated and ratified the Treaty of Maastricht. This treaty merged the institutions of the European Communities into a single first pillar. Two more pillars were created covering Common Foreign & Security Policy as well as Justice & Home Affairs. Reflecting the expanded competencies, the 12 member states replace the name European Communities with the new name: European Union.\nIn 1995, new members Finland, Sweden and Austria joined the EU - bringing the total of 15.\nIn 2004, there were 10 new members including Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Malta and Cyprus. The EU membership was now 25.\nIn 2007, Romania and Bulgaria joined the EU. Croatia joined in the EU. Painting by Paul Delaroche\n(1797\u20131856), Mus\u00e9e des Beaux-Arts de Rouen\n:\nThe trial was by a French, religious court; she was found guilty of heresy.\nTrial of Joan of Arc\n: \u201cshe was transferred to Rouen, the military headquarters and administrative capital in France of King Henry VI of England\n, and placed on trial for heresy\nbefore a Church court headed by Bishop\nPierre Cauchon\n\u201d\nYes, the English were behind it, but the court was French.\nDuring the trial in 1431, a trio of notaries headed by chief notary Guillaume Manchon took notes in French which were then collated each day following the trial session. About four years later, these records were translated into Latin\nby Manchon and University of Paris\nmaster Thomas de Courcelles. Five copies were produced, three of which are still in existence.\nIn a letter dated 20 February 1431 and sent to the assessors and others summoning them to appear the morning of the following day for the first public interrogation session of Joan, Pierre Cauchon cited the grant of jurisdiction within the city of Rouen by the chapter of the cathedral of Rouen for the purpose of conducting the trial against Joan.\nIn response to the summons of Bishop Cauchon on this same date, priest and bailiff Jean Massieu reported that Joan had agreed to appear in court, but she requested that ecclesiastics of the French side be summoned equal in number to those of the English party (as required by the Church's rules), and she asked that she should be allowed to hear Mass\n. In response, promoter (prosecutor) Jean d'Estivet forbade Joan to attend the divine offices, citing \"especially the impropriety of the garments to which she clung\" according to the Trial transcript (Barrett translation).\nOn May 24, Joan was taken to a scaffold set up in the cemetery next to Saint-Ouen Church\n, and told that she would be burned immediately unless she signed a document renouncing her visions and agreeing to stop wearing soldiers' clothing.\nOn May 28, Joan recanted her previous abjuration, donned men's apparel once more, and was accused of relapsing into heresy.\nHeresy no longer has the weight of common law in France (or anywhere in Europe), so such a charge and trial could not happen in modern times. Churches can use the charge of heresy, but not in common law.", "Don\u2019t forget that Joan was tried, convicted and executed by the English, the enemies of France! She was getting the French to rally to defeat them, so of course they found her guilty!", "Don\u2019t forget that Joan was tried, convicted and executed by the English, the enemies of France! Both teams were investigating yttrium, which was contaminated with traces of other rare earths (aka lanthanoids) and had already yielded erbium which was later to yield ytterbium. Cleve looked more closely at what remained after the ytterbium had been removed, and realised it must contain yet other elements because he found that its atomic weight depended on its source. He separated holmium from erbium in 1878. Delafontaine and Soret also extracted it from the same source, having seen unexplained lines in the atomic spectrum. We cannot be certain that either group had produced a pure sample of the new element because yet another rare-earth, dysprosium, was to be extracted from holmium.\nGroup Lanthanides\nMelting point 1472\u00b0C, 2682\u00b0F, 1745 K\nPeriod 6\nBoiling point 2700\u00b0C, 4892\u00b0F, 2973 K\nBlock f\nDensity (g cm\u22123) 8.80\nAtomic number 67\nRelative atomic mass 164.930\nState at 20\u00b0C Solid\nKey isotopes 165Ho\nElectron configuration [Xe] 4f1 16s2\nCAS number 7440-60-0\nChemSpider ID 22424\nChemSpider\nis a free chemical structure database\nUses\nHolmium can absorb neutrons, so it is used in nuclear reactors to keep a chain reaction under control. Its alloys are used in some magnets.\nBiological role\nHolmium has no known biological role, and is non-toxic.\nNatural abundance\nHolmium is found as a minor component of the minerals monazite and bastnaesite. It is extracted from those ores that are processed to extract yttrium. It is obtained by ion exchange and solvent extraction."], "topic_list": ["Metallurgy", "Metals", "Chemistry", "History"], "view_list": [3], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Balaji Nambi", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What is the history of Holmium?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "132", "name_list": ["Balaji Nambi"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "827": {"ans_list": ["He used to make a joke about himself \u201cin Russia I\u2019m Polish, in Poland I\u2019m Russian\u201d.\nNo one really cared in the USSR (or cares in modern Russia).
