Icons were displayed in churches, carried during religious rituals, and even stored in a special area of the homes of many lay worshippers.\nA famous icon of Christ Pantokrator:\nThe Empire went through two periods of what we call \u201ciconoclasm,\u201d from the Greek for icon-smashing, in the 8th and 9th centuries. Leo III blamed devotion to icons - a violation of the second commandment against graven images - for the catastrophic losses that the Empire faced in the 7th century, losing many of its richest territories to the Caliphate. There was a struggle for the next century and a half between iconoclasts (who wanted to remove the icons) and iconodules (who wanted to restore them). The iconodules finally prevailed in 843 under the regent empress Theodora. Icons would remain a central part of Byzantine devotional life up until 1453, and would pass into the Eastern Orthodox faiths after that, notably the Russian Orthodox Church.\nNot all icons were simply of religious figures; some depicted elaborate scenes. This one is called \u201cThe Ladder of Divine Ascent,\u201d named after a monastic treatise. (Monks were also particularly important in Byzantine life.) It\u2019s hard to imagine what a late Byzantine world could have looked like if the iconoclasts had prevailed - the images are so symbolic of that Empire that the very word \u201cicon\u201d has taken on a significant meaning in our world today. (And \u201ciconoclast\u201d as well.)"], "topic_list": ["Byzantines", "Artwork", "Roman Empire", "Fine Art", "World History", "History"], "view_list": [1, 439], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Efrayim Bulka", "upvote_list": [0, 3], "question_title": "What was the Byzantine Empire's most famous form of artwork?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "910", "name_list": ["Quora User", "Wayne Rossi"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "756": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Death Rate", "COVID-19 (2019-2020)", "Death and Dying", "Indian Ethnicity and People", "History", "India"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Anirban Roy", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Will 2020 see the highest death rate in Indian history due to COVID-19, the recent passing away of Irrfan Khan and the death of Indian saints? Czechia was an industrial powerhouse at that time while Hungary was lagging way behind.\nElectronic industry, ICE engines in 1871\u20131914? Give me a break. The first car from Czechia was President in 1905.", "Is it hoax, provocation or simply bad joke? Czechia was always the industrial center of so-called Austria-Hungary. Hungary was and has stayed an agricultural country. Who knows where you took such a disinformation.\nIn Czechia, according to individual sectors, 60-90 percent of the capacity of the entire Habsburg Empire (Austrian-Hugarian) industry was located (all AH with over 50 millions of inhabitants, Czechia with less than 7,5 millions). Czechia represented the most industrialized regions of continental Europe. Therefore, it is not possible to speak only about sugar exports, when there were such large enterprises as Plze\u0148 (Pilsner) \u0160koda (the biggest competitor of the German steel and armor concern Krupp), which successfully competed with it on foreign markets., companies that later formed Prague \u010cKD, North Moravian steelworks and ironworks and the entire structure of coal mines. It was therefore exported coal, heavy machinery products, armaments industry, modern machinery, especially for power plants, to mention the developed textile industry (regardless of succesfully exported food products, the aforementioned sugar, beer and the world famous Prague ham. We must not forget the automotive industry.\nThe Laurin & Klement company in Mlad\u00e1 Boleslav was actually the only automaker in the entire Habsburg Empire. Furthermore, in comparison with the most advanced countries, the modernization of infrastructure, especially the construction of railway lines and electrification, took place in Czechia at the same speed. Laurin & Klement was exported to neighboring Germany by other industrial companies from Czechia. Industry in Czechia and Germany was equally advanced and successful in business.\nIn Czechia, therefore, values were developing, but their return was mostly invested elsewhere, for example, for a generous reconstruction of Vienna. This must not be forgotten when today the Art Nouveau Vienna from the time of the Empire is admired, without the money from the Czech lands it would not have arisen!!!!!\nLater, when comparing the national income according to the overall average from 1925 to 1934, it amounted to 2 815 million US dollars in Czechoslovakia (Czechia together with Slovakia, when Slovakia left Hungarian domination as an absolutely poor country, without any industry) and 1,442 million US dollars in Austria, ie the economic performance of the interwar Czechoslovakia was basically double.", "Didn\u2019t the Skoda works build the gigantic cannon which enable Ludendorff to capture Liege in 1914, so that he was then available for transfer to Poland where he masterminded the defeat of the Russian army?", "Electronics? 50 years before the transistor? Whaaat..?\nDo you have any idea of when anything was invented?", "Science and technology in Hungary - Wikipedia\nTHE FIRST UNIVERSITY OF TECHNOLOGY in the WORLD\nA mining school called \"Berg Schola\" (modern German: \"Bergschule\"), which was the world's first institute of technology, was founded in Selmecb\u00e1nya\n, Kingdom of Hungary\n[23]\n(today Bansk\u00e1 \u0160tiavnica\n, Slovakia), in 1735. Its legal successor is the University of Miskolc\nin Hungary.\nBME University\nis considered\n[by whom?\n]\nthe world's oldest institute of technology which has university rank and structure. It was the first institute in Europe to train engineers at university level.\n[24]\nThe legal predecessor of the university was founded in 1782 by Emperor Joseph II\n, and was named Latin\n: Institutum Geometrico-Hydrotechnicum (\"Institute of Geometry and Hydrotechnics\").\nTHE FIRST STEAM ENGINE IN CONTINENTAL EUROPE.\nThe first steam engines\nof continental Europe\nwas built in \u00dajb\u00e1nya \u2013 K\u00f6ngisberg, Kingdom of Hungary (Today Nov\u00e1 Ba\u0148a\nSlovakia) in 1722. They were similar to the Newcomen engines, it served on pumping water from mines.[40]\n[41]\n[42]\n[43]\nAutomotive industry\nPrior to World War I, the Kingdom of Hungary had four car manufacturer companies; Hungarian car production started in 1900. Automotive factories in the Kingdom of Hungary manufactured motorcycles, cars, taxicabs, trucks and buses. These were: the Ganz company\n[63]\n[64]\nin Budapest, R\u00c1BA Automobile\n[65]\nin Gy\u0151r\n, M\u00c1G (later Magomobil\n)[66]\n[67]\nin Budapest, and MARTA (Hungarian Automobile Joint-stock Company Arad\n)[68]\nin Arad\n.\nTurbogenerators\nThe first turbo-generators were water turbines\nwhich propelled electric generators. The first Hungarian water turbine was designed by the engineers of the Ganz Works in 1866, the mass production with dynamo generators started in 1883.\n[95]\nThe manufacturing of steam turbo generators started in the Ganz Works in 1903.\nIn 1905, the L\u00e1ng Machine Factory\ncompany also started the production of steam turbines for alternators.\n[96]\nLight bulbs, radio tubes and X-ray\nTungsram\nis a Hungarian manufacturer of light bulbs and vacuum tubes since 1896. On 13 December 1904, Hungarian S\u00e1ndor Just and Croatian Franjo Hanaman were granted a Hungarian patent (No. 34541) for the world's first tungsten filament lamp. The tungsten filament lasted longer and gave brighter light than the traditional carbon filament. Tungsten filament lamps were first marketed by the Hungarian company Tungsram in 1904. This type is often called Tungsram-bulbs in many European countries.\n[97]\nTheir experiments also showed that the luminosity of bulbs filled with an inert gas was higher than in vacuum. The tungsten filament outlasted all other types (especially the former carbon filaments). The British Tungsram Radio Works was a subsidiary of the Hungarian Tungsram in pre-WW2 days.\nDespite the long experimentation with vacuum tubes at Tungsram company, the mass production of radio tubes begun during WW1,\n[98]\nand the production of X-ray tubes\nstarted also during the WW1 in Tungsram Company.\n[99]\nHome appliances\nThe Orion Electronics\nwas founded in 1913. Its main profiles were the production of electrical switches, sockets, wires, incandescent lamps, electric fans, electric kettles, and various household electronics.\nPower plants, generators and transformers\nIn 1878, the Ganz company's general manager Andr\u00e1s Mechwart (1853\u20131942) founded the Department of Electrical Engineering headed by K\u00e1roly Zipernowsky\n(1860\u20131939). Engineers Miksa D\u00e9ri\n(1854\u20131938) and Ott\u00f3 Bl\u00e1thy\n(1860\u20131939) also worked at the department producing direct-current machines and arc lamps.\nIn autumn 1884, K\u00e1roly Zipernowsky\n, Ott\u00f3 Bl\u00e1thy\nand Miksa D\u00e9ri\n(ZBD), three engineers associated with the Ganz factory, had determined that open-core devices were impracticable, as they were incapable of reliably regulating voltage.\n[72]\nIn their joint 1885 patent applications for novel transformers (later called ZBD transformers), they described two designs with closed magnetic circuits where copper windings were either a) wound around iron wire ring core or b) surrounded by iron wire core.\n[73]\nThe two designs were the first application of the two basic transformer constructions in common use to this day, which can as a class all be termed as either core form or shell form (or alternatively, core type or shell type), as in a) or b), respectively (see images).[74\n[75]\n[76]\n[77]\nThe Ganz factory had also in the autumn of 1884 made delivery of the world's first five high-efficiency AC transformers, the first of these units having been shipped on September 16, 1884.[78]\nThis first unit had been manufactured to the following specifications: 1,400 W, 40 Hz, 120:72 V, 11.6:19.4 A, ratio 1.67:1, one-phase, shell form.[78]\nIn both designs, the magnetic flux linking the primary and secondary windings traveled almost entirely within the confines of the iron core, with no intentional path through air (see Toroidal cores\nbelow). The new transformers were 3.4 times more efficient than the open-core bipolar devices of Gaulard and Gibbs.[79]\nThe Hungarian \"ZBD\" team invented the first high efficiency, closed core shunt connection transformer\nand practical parallel-connected distribution circuits.\nThe ZBD patents included two other major interrelated innovations: one concerning the use of parallel connected, instead of series connected, utilization loads, the other concerning the ability to have high turns ratio transformers such that the supply network voltage could be much higher (initially 1,400 to 2,000 V) than the voltage of utilization loads (100 V initially preferred).[80]\n[81]\nWhen employed in parallel connected electric distribution systems, closed-core transformers finally made it technically and economically feasible to provide electric power for lighting in homes, businesses and public spaces.[82]\n[83]\nBl\u00e1thy had suggested the use of closed cores, Zipernowsky had suggested the use of parallel shunt connections\n, and D\u00e9ri had performed the experiments;[84]\nThe other essential milestone was the introduction of 'voltage source, voltage intensive' (VSVI) systems'[85]\nby the invention of constant voltage generators in 1885.[86]\nOtt\u00f3 Bl\u00e1thy also invented the first AC electricity meter\n.[87]\n[88]\n[89]\n[90]\nTransformers today are designed on the principles discovered by the three engineers. They also popularized the word 'transformer' to describe a device for altering the emf of an electric current,[82]\n[91]\n[92]\n[93]\nIn 1886, the ZBD engineers designed, and the Ganz factory supplied electrical equipment for, the world's first power station\nthat used AC generators to power a parallel connected common electrical network, the steam-powered Rome-Cerchi power plant.[94]\nThe reliability of the AC technology received impetus after the Ganz Works electrified a large European metropolis: Rome\nin 1886.[94]\nTelecommunication\nThe first telegraph station on Hungarian territory was opened in December 1847 in Pressburg/ Pozsony /Bratislava\n/. In 1848, \u2013 during the Hungarian Revolution \u2013 another telegraph centre was built in Buda\nto connect the most important governmental centres. The first telegraph connection between Vienna and Pest \u2013 Buda (later Budapest) was constructed in 1850.\n[100]\nIn 1884, 2,406 telegraph post offices operated in the Kingdom of Hungary.\n[101]\nBy 1914 the number of telegraph offices reached 3,000 in post offices, and a further 2,400 were installed in the railway stations of the Kingdom of Hungary.\n[102]\nThe first Hungarian telephone exchange\nwas opened in Budapest (May 1, 1881).\n[103]\nAll telephone exchanges of the cities and towns in the Kingdom of Hungary were linked in 1893.[100]\nBy 1914, more than 2,000 settlements had telephone exchange in the Kingdom of Hungary.[102]\nThe Telefon H\u00edrmond\u00f3\n(Telephone Herald) service was established in 1893. Two decades before the introduction of radio broadcasting, residents of Budapest could listen to news, cabaret, music and opera at home and in public spaces daily. It operated over a special type of telephone exchange system and its own separate network. The technology was later licensed in Italy and the United States. (see: telephone newspaper\n).\nThe first Hungarian telephone factory (Factory for Telephone Apparatuses) was founded by J\u00e1nos Neuhold in Budapest in 1879, which produced telephones microphones, telegraphs, and telephone exchanges.[104]\n[105]\n[106]\nIn 1884, the Tungsram\ncompany also started to produce microphones, telephone apparatuses, telephone switchboards and cables.[107]\nThe Ericsson\ncompany also established a factory for telephones and switchboards in Budapest in 1911.[108]\nRailways and locomotive industry\nThe first Hungarian steam-locomotive railway line was opened on 15 July 1846, between Pest and V\u00e1c.[47]\nBy 1910, the total length of the rail networks of the Hungarian Kingdom had reached 22,869 km (14,210 mi); the Hungarian network linked more than 1,490 settlements. This has ranked Hungarian railways as the sixth-most dense in the world (ahead of countries as Germany or France).\n[48]\nLocomotive engine and railway vehicle manufacturers before World War One\n(engines and wagons, bridge and iron structures) were the M\u00c1VAG\ncompany in Budapest (steam engines and wagons) and the Ganz company\nin Budapest (steam engines, wagons, the production of electric locomotives\nand electric trams started from 1894).[49]\nand the R\u00c1BA Company\nin Gy\u0151r\n.\nThe Ganz Works identified the significance of induction motors and synchronous motors commissioned K\u00e1lm\u00e1n Kand\u00f3 (1869\u20131931) to develop it. In 1894, K\u00e1lm\u00e1n Kand\u00f3\ndeveloped high-voltage three-phase AC motors and generators for electric locomotives. The first-ever electric rail vehicle manufactured by Ganz Works was a 6 HP pit locomotive with direct current traction system. The first Ganz made asynchronous rail vehicles (altogether 2 pieces) were supplied in 1898 to \u00c9vian-les-Bains\n(Switzerland), with a 37-horsepower (28 kW), asynchronous-traction system. The Ganz Works won the tender of electrification of railway of Valtellina Railways in Italy in 1897. Italian railways were the first in the world to introduce electric traction for the entire length of a main line, rather than just a short stretch. The 106-kilometre (66 mi) Valtellina line was opened on 4 September 1902, designed by Kand\u00f3 and a team from the Ganz works.[50]\nThe electrical system was three-phase at 3 kV 15 Hz. The voltage was significantly higher than used earlier, and it required new designs for electric motors and switching devices.[51]\n[52]\nIn 1918,[53]\nKand\u00f3 invented and developed the rotary phase converter\n, enabling electric locomotives to use three-phase motors whilst supplied via a single overhead wire, carrying the simple industrial frequency (50 Hz) single phase AC of the high voltage national networks.[54]\nElectrified railway lines[edit\n]\nBudapest (See: BH\u00c9V\n): R\u00e1ckeve\nline (1887), Szentendre\nline (1888), G\u00f6d\u00f6ll\u0151\nline (1888), Csepel\nline (1912)[55]\nElectrified tramways[edit\n]\nThe first electric tramway was built in Budapest in 1887, which was the first tramway in Austria-Hungary. By the turn of the 20th century, 22 Hungarian cities had electrified tramway lines in Kingdom of Hungary.\nDate of electrification of tramway lines in the Kingdom of Hungary:\nHungary: Budapest\n(1887); Pressburg/Pozsony/Bratislava\n(1895); Szabadka/Subotica\n, Szombathely\n, Miskolc\n(1897); Temesv\u00e1r/Timi\u0219oara\n(1899); Sopron\n(1900); Szatm\u00e1rn\u00e9meti/Satu Mare\n(1900); Ny\u00edregyh\u00e1za\n(1905); Nagyszeben/Sibiu\n(1905); Nagyv\u00e1rad/Oradea\n(1906); Szeged\n(1908); Debrecen\n(1911); \u00dajvid\u00e9k/Novi Sad\n(1911); Kassa/Ko\u0161ice\n(1913); P\u00e9cs\n(1913)\nCroatia: Fiume\n(1899); Pula\n(1904); Opatija\n\u2013 Lovran\n(1908); Zagreb\n(1910); Dubrovnik\n(1910).[56]\n[57]\n[58]\n[59]\nUnderground[edit\n]\nThe Budapest metro\nLine 1 (originally the \"Franz Joseph Underground Electric Railway Company\") is the second oldest underground railway in the world\n[60]\n(the first being the London Underground's Metropolitan Line), and the first on the European mainland. It was built from 1894 to 1896 and opened in Budapest on 2 May 1896.[61]\nIn 2002, it was listed as a UNESCO\nWorld Heritage Site\n.[62]\nAeronautical industry\nThe first Hungarian hydrogen-filled experimental balloons were built by Istv\u00e1n Szabik and J\u00f3zsef Domin in 1784. The first Hungarian designed and produced airplane (powered by inline engine\n) was flew in 1909 at R\u00e1kosmez\u0151.\n[69]\nThe International Air-race was organized in Budapest, R\u00e1kosmez\u0151 in June 1910. The earliest Hungarian radial engine\npowered airplane was built in 1913. Between 1913\u201318, the Hungarian aircraft industry began developing. The 3 greatest: UFAG\nHungarian Aircraft Factory (1914), Hungarian General Aircraft Factory (1916), Hungarian Lloyd Aircraft, Engine Factory (at Asz\u00f3d\n(1916),[70]\nand Marta in Arad (1914).[71]\nDuring the WW I, fighter planes, bombers and reconnaissance planes were produced in these factories. The most important aeroengine factories were Weiss Manfred Works, GANZ Works, and Hungarian Automobile Joint-stock Company Arad.\nThe first Hungarian steamship was built by Antal Bernhard in 1817, called S.S. Carolina. It was also the first steamship in Habsburg-ruled states.\n[109]\nSHIPBUILDING\nThe daily passenger traffic between the two sides of the Danube\nby the Carolina started in 1820.\n[110]\nThe regular cargo and passenger transports between Pest\nand Vienna\nbegan in 1831.\n[109]\nHowever, it was Count Istv\u00e1n Sz\u00e9chenyi\n(with the help of Austrian ship's company Erste Donaudampfschiffahrtsgesellschaft\n(DDSG) ), who established the \u00d3buda Shipyard on the Hungarian Haj\u00f3gy\u00e1ri Island\nin 1835, which was the first industrial scale steamship building company in the Habsburg Empire.\n[111]\nThe most important seaport for the Hungarian part of the k.u.k. was Fiume (Rijeka\n, today part of Croatia), where the Hungarian shipping companies, such as the Adria, operated. The largest Hungarian shipbuilding company was the Ganz-Danubius. In 1911, The Ganz Company merged with the Danubius shipbuilding company, which largest shipbuilding company in Hungary. Since 1911, the unified company adopted the \"Ganz \u2013 Danubius\" brand name. As Ganz Danubius, the company became involved in shipbuilding before, and during, World War I\n. Ganz was responsible for building the dreadnought Szent Istv\u00e1n\n, supplied the machinery for the cruiser Novara\n.\nDiesel-electric military submarines:\nThe Ganz-Danubius company started to build U-boats\nat its shipyard in Budapest\n, for final assembly at Fiume\n. Several U-Boats of the U-XXIX class\n, U-XXX class\n, U-XXXI class\nand U-XXXII class\nwere completed ,\n[112]\nand a number of other types were laid down, remaining incomplete at the war's end.\n[113]\nThe company built some ocean liners\ntoo.\nIn 1915, the Whitehead\ncompany established one of its largest enterprise, the Hungarian Submarine Building Corporation (or in its German name: Ungarische Unterseebotsbau AG (UBAG)), in Fiume, Kingdom of Hungary (Now Rijeka\n, Croatia).\n[114]\n[115]\nSM U-XX\n, SM U-XXI\n, SM U-XXII\nand SM U-XXIII\nType diesel-electric submarines were produced by the UBAG Corporation in Fiume.\n[116]\n[117]", "Surely it\u2019s a joke. Czechia (and especially Bohemia, its Western 60% around Prague) was the first (and the most) industrialized region of Austria-Hungary. The industrialization already exploded around 1850. (In England, industrialization formally started in the 1780s but was only substantial in the 1830s and 1840s.) Hungary (in the modern sense) was one of the least industrial places, even less industrial than Slovakia (then called \u201cUpper Hungary\u201d).\nFor example, \u0160koda Works\nthat would soon become the largest factory of Austria-Hungary was founded in 1859. It produced things like guns, machine guns, turbines, locomotives, aircraft, ships, machine tools, and more. In 1925, the company would buy Laurin & Klement, the carmaker founded in 1895 which became \u0160koda Auto (now owned by the Volkswagen Group). Check some historical videos of Czechia\u2019s currently most important company: history of skoda auto\nThis is the Pr\u00e4sident\n, the first car (it was a petrol-engined one) produced on the Czech territory, in 1897. The company would become Tatra soon. Incidentally, the first airplane built in Czechia was a hobby by Methodius Vlach, a man in Mlad\u00e1 Boleslav, incidentally the same town where \u0160koda Auto resides today. He built it in 1912.\nThere was no \u201celectronics\u201d before 1914, surely it wasn\u2019t meant seriously. The first \u201celectronic\u201d devices were huge and contained relays and then electron tubes. Only when transistors replaced those two (after a 1947 invention), a miniaturization started in electronics. Long after 1914.\nThe first Hungarian cars were produced by the Csonka (automobile)\nsince 1909. It\u2019s a decade after Czechia but the volumes and other things were smaller than the Czech counterparts, and there was virtually no industrialization in Hungary in the 19th century, about a 50-year-long delay after Czechia.\nThis industrial gap in favor of Czechia is even more spectacular when you look at airplanes (despite the fact that the Czechoslovak airplanes were a discipline in which Czechoslovakia was inferior relatively to Germany in the 1930s). The first airworthy Hungarian airplane, Rubik R-22 Fut\u00e1r\n, was built by Ern\u00f6 Rubik (the father of the father of the Rubik\u2019s cube) in 1948, 36 years after the first Czech airplane. Hungary remained underdeveloped in the aircraft industry up to the present.\nOrion and Videoton became the leading Hungarian electronics companies. Throughout much of the 20th century, most of Czechoslovakia\u2019s electronics production was accumulated in the chain of factories Tesla (Czechoslovak company)\nand I believe that the overall production was much higher than in Hungary. Tesla has been making tons of consumer electronics, tape recorders, home computers with their own version of the 8080 chips, and thousands of other products. But electronics really kicked off after the Second World War, not before 1914.\nFor more general comparisons \u201cwho is better\u201d among the two nations, see What does Czechia do better than Hungary? and especially What does Hungary do better than Czechia?", "Your question surprises me because I have always learned in school and from books that Czechia developed in a more modern, industrialized direction than Hungary did."], "topic_list": ["Hungarian Trolls", "Industrialization", "Czechia (country)", "Industrial Revolution", "The Czech Republic", "Economic History", "History"], "view_list": [15, 252, 35, 2, 84, 603, 32], "create_time": "Jan 25, 2020", "no_of_follower": 10, "question_author": "Csongor Csillog\u00f3", "upvote_list": [3, 11, 0, 0, 1, 21, 5], "question_title": "Why was Czechia unable to develop the modern second industrial revolution sectors of the industry in the 1870-1914 period, while Hungary was more successful in this modern industry (like electronic industry, ICE engines, cars, etc.)?", "respond_collected": 7, "no_of_view": "1,556", "name_list": ["Vaclav Sulista", "Vladim\u00edr Hirsch", "Bob Gartside", "Gustaf Johansson", "Csongor Csillog\u00f3", "Lubo\u0161 Motl", "P\u00e9ter Wellisch"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Mar 19, 2020", "Mar 19, 2020", "Mar 17, 2020", "Mar 17, 2020", "Mar 17, 2020", "Mar 8, 2020"]}, "656": {"ans_list": ["I think that there still exist Hungarians being devastated after losing Transylvania 100 years ago. How sad to be a destroyed person.", "The people, who designed the war wanted to stop having a middle size power in the center of Europe. They wanted to get rid of the Russian Empire and the Ottomans too. With the last two they had limited success, so they made the most they could by cutting Hungary to pieces.\nThey made a huge mustake, because if they live Hungary in one piece, the Germans could not start WWII\u2026", "Why was Hungary divided into several nations after World War I?\nThe Kingdom of Hungary lost lands to other nations after WWI as these were area with large non-Hungarian populations that were sick of Magyar rule and or wanted to join \u201ctheir\u201d nations (such as the Romanians in Transylvania).\nThere are consequences to losing a war. Even more so if you are a multi-ethnic state with a small elite ruling class and unhappy minorities chafing for independence.", "This goes back to hundreds of years ago. France and Germany have rivalized and fought each other for centuries. France wanted to permanently destroy its opponent, but because Germany was ethnically too homogeneous, this was not possible. (After World War II, Germany was also been divided, but ethnic unity allowed the reunification 45 years later.) France\u2019s idea was If you can't defeat someone, defeat his strongest ally! During the First World War (and before), Germany's strongest military ally was the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Referring to the freedom rights of the ethnicities (Fourteen Points of Wilson), the Entente states under the leadership of France, divided Austria-Hungary to smaller parts. \"Divide and conquer.\" France referred to the ethnicity's rights for self-determination, but the new borders did not take into account the Hungarian ethnicity, and 100% Hungarian-inhabited territories came under foreign rule, where Hungarians became an oppressed minority without any kind of ethnic rights on their former territories. It seems that France was only interested in the rights of non-Hungarian minorities. The new borders were designed strictly by economic and political interests. A good example is the town of S\u00e1toralja\u00fajhely in north-eastern Hungary, which was chopped half by the new border. The railway station and network with surrounding Hungarian villages were annexed to Czechoslovakia, while the rest of the town remained Hungarian. Despite Mr. Draculea's nationalist-chauvinistic lies, there weren\u2019t democratic elections (except in 1 case), and the local population wasn\u2019t being asked, where they wanted to belong. There was an election 1 year after the peace treaty, in Sopron, where the population voted to remain in Hungary, so Hungary got back the town and the surrounding area. The nickname of this town is \u201cThe most loyal town\u201d now. After this event, the defenders of democracy and human rights (USA, France, UK) prohibited further elections, because they worried the local population would vote to be part of Hungary again, so no further elections were held anywhere else. There was an event at Gyulafeh\u00e9rv\u00e1r (today Alba Iulia, Romania) in 1918. The Romanians always refer to it as a democratic election, but actually it wasn\u2019t. The 1228 delegates who declared the annexation of Transylvania to Romania were ethnic Romanians (600 from Transylvania, the rest from Romania). The local Hungarian and Saxon population was not being asked, can't vote, and they did not have a choice, to express their views. The Hungarian government proposed that Transylvania be transformed into a Swiss-type confederation of cantons, where all ethnic groups are equally represented, but the Romanian government refused it, and they announced the unification. The Entente powers approved the event, and nowadays, the Romanian governments (and peoples) still like to present the events to the neutral public as a result of a democratic election.", "Because the native population in the lands that left Hungary did not want to be part of Hungary (which had a long history of opressing them) so they voted for independence, either forming their own nations or joining others."], "topic_list": ["History of Hungary", "Hungary", "World War I", "History"], "view_list": [3, 98, 153, 677, 97], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Anonymous", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 2, 4, 3], "question_title": "Why was Hungary divided into several nations after World War I?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "1,949", "name_list": ["Rasvan Lalu", "Attila Horvath", "Niko Vasileas", "August Mackensen", "Antoniu Draculea"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "560": {"ans_list": ["I think it\u2019s more accurate if I describe more of how the impeachment process worked in ancient China, it was similar but not quite the same as the modern concept.\nImpeachment was not just done by any magistrates or officials. There was a special position called \u201cyushi,\u201d (\u5fa1\u53f2) or sometimes categorised as \u201cspeaker officials,\u201d (\u8a00\u5b98) whose duties were to do this. Their role was to exhibit some degree of supervision to other politicians or the Emperor himself. If an official that was not a yushi wrote an impeachment request to the Emperor, the Emperor \u201cmight\u201d accept it. Or he might just tell him off by saying \u201cThis power is not in your normal duty.\u201d\nIf the yushi suspect any corruption or miscarriage of justice, they have the power to collect evidence and write to the Emperor to report this. They might also recommend appropriate punishment to the impeached official, such as demotion, dismissal or even criminal sentences.\nIn rare circumstances, they might also impeach the Emperor. However, this form of impeachment was done for the purpose of recommending the Emperor to change on certain policies for improvement. It was borderline high treason to impeach the Emperor to abdicate, because usually this was only done if the Emperor was a puppet ruler that could be easily disposed.\nWhat were the usual results of the impeachment?\nIf what the yushi wrote was accurate, with evidence provided, and logically sound, the Emperor would accept his suggestion and order for a formal investigation or a punishment. However, if the impeachment was not adequate or inconclusive, the yushi himself might get into trouble. He would possibly be punished for libel/defamation, or the officials he impeached would attempt to end his political career.\nStereotypically, this was why yushi were often seen as wise, honourable and good with words. However, politics always had that \u201cMidas touch,\u201d to turn something clean into something vile.\nA yushi himself might be politically aligned with certain people. His impeachment might selectively target people who were his political enemies, but when his political allies commit such acts he would conveniently ignore it. He could also be privately ordered by other officials to make this impeachment process.\nCase study: the fall of Yan Song\nFor example, during the reign of Jiajing Emperor of Ming, the government was controlled by the corrupt grand secretary Yan Song and his son Yan Shifan, who were often sarcastically called \u201cThe Senior and Junior Prime Minister.\u201d The yushi Zou Yinglong, after consulting with rival grand secretary Xu Jie, wrote an impeachment process to the Emperor, but centred it on Yan Shifan abusing his power to have \u201cinappropriate relations during national mourning.\u201d\nWhen one impeachment came, others soon followed. Several other yushi wrote their impeachment of the Yan family too. However, Xu Jie saw that they were accusing Yan family of miscarriage of justice by executing several politicians. Xu Jie asked them to rewrite it, because even if the Yan family falsified evidence to kill rival politicians, the \u201cdeath warrant\u201d was ultimately signed by the Emperor, and they couldn\u2019t be pointing any blames on him.\nThey ultimately settled on a very hand-waving verdict for the impeachment of Yan Shifan: treason by colluding with wukou (Japanese pirates). Which worked out very well and got the Yan family toppled. Yan Shifan was sentenced to death and Yan Song was demoted to a commoner, living the remainder of his life in poverty.\nPolitics was and is always a dirty game, and impeachment was never truly for simple justice. Still, in the case of Yan Song, because he was a notoriously corrupt politician in Ming history, most historians agree he got what he deserved.", "Han Wudi\u2019s grandson was declared unfit as emperor by the magistrate He Guang, a descendent of Han Wudi General He Qubin. His tomb was excavated in Jiangxi. The following is from my book JOURNEY TO CHINA\u2014History and Travel:\nJIANGXI (Pictures in italics not showing)\nJiangxi is in a strategic location to connect the south with the north with trade routes along Gan River, population 48 million. Railways and high-speed rails intersect at the capital Nanchang. Boyang Lake is the largest freshwater lake in China, located in north Jiangxi. It\u2019s a nature reserve for 200 species of birds. UNESCO World Heritage sites include Lu Shan \u5e90\u5c71, Sanqing Shan Geopark \u4e09\u6e05\u5c71, Longhu Shan \u9f99\u864e\u5c71.\nBOYANG LAKE\u2014Paradise of Birds\nNanchang\u2014Capital of Jiangxi. Lord Bao Shrine\u5305\u516c\u7960 is located in Bo River Park to commemorate the revered Song official. Jiangxi being the porcelain capital in China, a series of ceramic buildings in a shopping center have been built in Nanchang, the world\u2019s largest ceramic pieces.\nIn 2011, the Tomb of Marquis Haihun \u6d77\u660f, located north of Nanchang, was discovered. Treasures escaped graverobbers and was preserved in water buried in an earthquake. Grandson of Han Wudi, Liu He \u5218\u8d3a was emperor for only 27 days before he was declared unfit as a ruler. He was demoted as a Marquis in Jiangxi. In 2016 excavation, nearly 10,000 artifacts, 115 kg of gold pieces, 3 tons of coins and his jade seal were found. A new museum has been built for the rich collection.\nLiu He\u2019s Seal Bronze lamp", "There was no impeachment in ancient China in the modern sense. Period. The modern idea of impeachment is a formal proceeding that could result in the removal of the administrative head, and there is nothing like that in ancient China.\n\u2018Impeachment\u2019 would be an attempt to translate the Chinese idea that the emperor had been wrong, unethical, incompetent, or corrupt. The emperor might accept the accusation and blamed himself. This could occur after some catastrophe happened (e.g. famine, flood, earthquakes, or other natural disasters). However, there was no mechanism in place to remove the emperor after some official pointed this out. The emperor could also punish the official, e.g. killing him, for making such daring accusations against him, which occurred more often than not. If it were an impeachment, it would not be such a high stakes game for the officials involved.\nA coup of some sort was required to remove the emperor, and there was no accepted mechanism in place to do that. After a coup succeeded, there might be some official announcement of how bad the old emperor was to legitimize changing the emperor, but it is post facto, and completely different in nature from an impeachment.", "No, certainly not any Chinese emperors had ever been impeached.\nImpeachment is a peaceful process by law to strip the power of a ruler because of his/her wrong doing. In ancient China, there were several emperors who were forced out and gave the power to the members of their family. But, these are not cases of impeachment. They were coups or infightings no matter how seemly these emperors were forced out for wrong doing. Most, if not all, emperors would be considered criminals if they were subjected to the laws.\nIf you saw a record of such a case of impeachment, I would be very interested to read it.", "When I think of ancient China, I think of the period before the Han dynasty.\nLooking back at Chinese history, before or after the Han, I\u2019m not sure what you mean by impeachment. China did not have a constitution, so there were no laws for impeachment in the American sense.\nAn impeached American president retires to private life. This rarely happened to emperors in China.\nUsually what happened was more like a coup. A group of politicians would be dissatisfied with an emperor for a variety of reasons. The Emperor may have been incompetent, or some politician could have grown too powerful and decided to mount the throne himself. A member of the royal family might want to take power. These were not impeachments for high misdemeanors or treason, such as President Trump has committed, but rather someone taking over the power, usually violently. The overthrown emperor rarely survived.\nThink of \u5357\u9f4a\u7700\u5e1d\u856d\u9e1e (452 - 498CE) Emperor Ming of the Southern Chi/Qi, a nephew of the founder of the dynasty. He had his cousin, the Emperor, killed, and murdered so many of his nephews and cousins that he went crazy. This was hardly an impeachment.\nOne of the emperors around that time, I forget just who, was assassinated by his counselors at about the age 19. All the rest did and new peoples, languages and cultures developed in western Europe.\nBritain is unique in this though -the native Britons (near ancestors of the Welsh) managed to hold off the invasions of pirate Saxon, Angles and Jutes - they only occupied part of the Britain which was then contested for the next eight hundred years. It can be fairly claimed that Britain and British culture which evolved into Welsh, Cornish and Breton cultures was the last part of the western Roman empire that survived.\nFollowing this - when the kingdom of Gwynedd came to an end in 1282 it can fairly claim to have been the longest surviving and most successful successor kingdom that was still culturally Roman in Western Europe.\nAlso it was Welsh Christian missionaries who converted the Irish in the first place, and also Wales was the only major part of the Britain and Ireland (as well as most of the north and western seaboard of Europe) that managed to fight off successful Viking attempts at large scale settlements.", "\u201cWhat are some facts about Welsh history before Wales was conquered by the English?\u201d\nThe first thing that comes to mind is that before the English there simply was no Wales, and by extension no history of Wales. Any more than there had been an England before the English (Anglo-Saxons) arrived,\nWales is the name given to the land of the Welsh, or Welisc meaning foreigner.\nThe many Brittonic peoples who occupied that area now known as Wales shared many cultural and ethnic similarities, as they did also with the people living across most of the mainland of Britannia (As the Romans called it!) including the south of modern day Scotland, all of modern England (with the possible exception of the far south-east) and even across the water into Brittany.\nThere are parallels in many other countries, including the Nordic countries, in Ireland and in France (Gaul). These were all patchworks of small tribal groups or kingdoms which shared culturally with their neighbours even when at war with them.\nThe Cymric peoples had their own system of laws, they arrived at Christianity following conversion form their pagan belief systems of old, but were immune from the power of Rome far longer than the English.\nThey may not have been as civilized and advanced as the Irish, in that women do not seem to have appeared as leading lights in their administrative life - the English were far behind too! The various \u2018kingdoms\u2019 fluctuated in scale and in their relative power to influence - just as the English kingdoms did nearby.\nWhat their history was during or before the Romans is veiled simply because, except where the Romans occupied, such as around the Usk, the bulk of what was to become Wales was \u2018Terra Incognito\u2019 to the Roman historians and geographers. The locals were not renowned for their written histories, as theirs was a bardic and oral tradition of history - much of which has been lost.", "Conquered by Normans/Plantagenets, with English The pamphlets were opposed to privately minted copper coinage:\nDrapier's Letters is the collective name for a series of seven pamphlets written between 1724 and 1725 by the Dean of St Patrick's Cathedral in Dublin, Jonathan Swift, to arouse public opinion in Ireland against the imposition of a privately minted copper coinage that Swift believed to be of inferior quality. William Wood was granted letters patent to mint the coin, and Swift saw the licensing of the patent as corrupt. In response, Swift represented Ireland as constitutionally and financially independent of Britain in the Drapier's Letters. Since the subject was politically sensitive, Swift wrote under the pseudonym M. With both former queens dead, there was no reason he wouldn\u2019t be able to marry Jane Seymour.", "Catherine had been Henry\u2019s faithful wife since 1509. She had borne him six children, three stillborn and two died in infancy, so sadly only the Princess Mary survived. Catherine had put up with Henry\u2019s numerous adulteries and infidelities with women of the court. She was in her own right a Spanish Princess, daughter of Ferdinand and Isabella, and her uncle was the Emperor Charles V, who ruled the Habsburg Lands in Austria, Germany, the Netherlands and Spain.\nWhen Henry took up with his new paramour Ann Boleyn, who had seen her older sister Mary royally screwed and cast aside, Ann was more shrewd and insisted on marrying Henry and becoming Queen. But it was a dangerous game.\nIt was one thing for Henry to petition the Pope (unsuccessfully) for the annulment of his 20-year marriage to Catherine. It would have been quite another for him to have had her head cut off. It was bad enough that he was prepared to drag the English Church into schism from Rome, and put to death the bravest and holiest in the land who opposed him.\nAs we know, sauce for Catherine\u2019s goose soon turned into sauce for Ann\u2019s gander.\nAnn was victoriously married to Henry on 25 January 1533, having already conceived Elizabeth outside marriage. She was crowned Queen on 1 June 1533, a status she would enjoy for less than three years.\nShe fell foul of the Machiavellian Cromwell, over how the monies plundered from the monasteries should be used. Ann, to her credit, wanted some of the wealth to go towards schools and hospitals. Cromwell wanted it for his Treasury.\nThe trumped up charges against Ann were that she had had sexual relationships with five courtiers, including her brother, George Boleyn (aka Lord Rochford), and the king\u2019s good friend and groom of the stool, Sir Henry Norris. According to the indictments, not only had she slept with these men (as a result of her \u201cfrail and carnal appetites\u201d), but she had also conspired with them to kill her husband, the king.\nAnn had no powerful foreign protectors. Her blissful marital union with the King came to an abrupt end on 19th May 1536 when her head was lopped off. The Boleyn family had ridden high upon their in-law connection to His Majesty. Now they were disgraced, dismissed from Court, and there was no comeback.\nThe next day, 20th May, Jane Seymour and King Henry VIII were betrothed. He wasn\u2019t one to hang about when he wanted a leg over. On 30th May, only eleven days after Ann\u2019s execution, they were married in a private ceremony in the Palace of Whitehall. Catherine had died on 7th January 1536, to the King\u2019s delight, so he was free to marry no problems after Ann\u2019s precipitous demise.", "Because Catherine was from a very powerful family\u2026.\nCatherine's parents were Isabella of Castile and Ferdinand of Aragon, the monarchs who\u2019s marriage created the country that we now know as Spain. At the time of Catherine\u2019s divorce from Henry, her sister Joanna was ruler of Castile and Aragon; her nephew Maximilian was Holy Roman Emperor; and her nephew John was King Of Portugal. The divorce alone caused major diplomatic issues for Henry - if he had executed Catherine, he would have sparked a war against most of continental Europe, with very little chance of survival, let alone victory.", "Catherine had been Henry\u2019s wife, and the Queen, for more than twenty years. And she was almost universally loved by the people of England. She was of Royal blood herself, and her behavior as Queen had been beyond reproach.\nIf Henry had tried to trump up bogus charges against her, as he did with Anne, he would have had a rebellion on his hands, and he knew it. So did Cromwell. And the backlash from Catholic Europe would have been far greater than it was when he exiled Catherine. Spain might have declared war on Henry to defend the rights of Catherine and her daughter Mary.\nThe only claim Henry was able to make against Catherine was that her marriage to Arthur had been consummated, and thus her marriage to Henry had never been valid. The problem with that was that the papal dispensation he had received to marry her stated that their marriage had the blessing of God and the Church whether or not her union with Arthur had been consummated.\nTrying to discard Catherine was bad enough in the eyes of the world\u2026executing her would have been political and religious suicide. The banzai charge sword in hand didn\u2019t matter much how the sword was made", "There are about three phases to the Gunto sword: early, middle and late. The stereotypical image of stamped metal swords are of course the later variant due to scarcity of materials.\nEarlier Gunto swords were by and large just actual traditional samurai swords worn by officers, but they were already starting to manufacture newer swords at an industrial level to furnish the officer corps of the imperial Japanese Army/ Navy- as some officers came from the older samurai class and had heirlooms, it made sense for them to forego Gunto swords and bring along their forefather\u2019s weapons.\nThe mid-war and late-war variants were of course gradual simplification in design and manufacture, and as you would expect the quality became increasingly low.\nSo no, Gunto swords manufactured as such, as a rule were not made in the traditional forging process, but machined in factories. Note, however, that much of the simplification revolved more around the scabbard and hilt, rather than the blade; only the final versions utilized stainless steel; it seems Gunto blades\u2019 quality remained rather consistent.\nI should also note that, automated and industrial scale manufacturing of swords don\u2019t imply loss of quality- hand-forged swords were merely just that, forged by hands and took longer labour. Machines doing the same thing, so long as quality control was not spiraling out of control, can produce fine quality blades.", "Although the mass-produced \u201cgunto\u201d swords were normally issued to officers and NCOs during the war, it\u2019s known that various ranking officers, descendants of Samurai families, sometimes took \u201cheirloom\u201d blades into combat with them.\nNumbers of these ended up in the hands of GIs, taken from the bodies of their owners. So those swords you see from WWII weren\u2019t even Samurai swords! They were Gunt\u014d\n, military swords.\nWhen the Samurai were disbanded there were not many real craftsmen left who could make these high-quality swords. Instead, cheaper substitutes were created to be used by the military.\nThe Katana\nwas the real Samurai sword but it\u2019s style and length varied throughout history. Some Japanese officers did carry an originally-crafter Samurai sword but most officers just got a mass-product version, made from cheaper steel and with less manual labor and more use of mechanized production methods, as Japan needed a lot of swords.\nAfter WWII many swords in Japan were even confiscated and destroyed and even existing WWII-era swords can still be confiscated in Japan to be destroyed. Outside Japan, they have become collector items, though.\nNowadays, there are swordsmiths who will handcraft these swords again.But they are now also created outside Japan, often with even slightly stronger kinds of steel.\nHow the WWII swords compared to the older Samurai swords? Well, the quality was good enough for the Japanese. The mechanized production methods did allow the new swords to be just as strong as the older katana. It all depends on the quality of the steel itself. It\u2019s a bit like comparing glass bottles made by hand and glass bottles made my factories and various machinery. They would both serve their purpose just fine, but the handmade stuff is way more expensive and harder to get, thus considered to be an elite product.\nThe machine-made swords could have a few more weaknesses within the steel, though. What happens in history books is that the author translates whatever calendar system the people of the time were using into our system. After all, if an author discussing the history of Carthage said Carthage was sacked and destroyed in 613 AUC, you and I as reader would have no idea when that was. That isn\u2019t the system we use now. So the historian translates that into 140 BC for us.\nPeople kept track of years by different methods. History of calendars - Wikipedia\nThe usual method was \u201cx year of Y\u2019s reign\u201d. IOW, they would count years from the start of a king or emperor\u2019s reign. Obviously, different countries would thus have different different \u201cyears\u201d. The Roman Republic designated years by who held the consul position. They also counted years from the founding of the city of Rome (AUC).\nThus, Augustus introduced the concept of \u201cleap year\u201d in 757 AUC. This corresponds to 4 AD in our calendar. 2 BC would have been 752 AUC for the Romans. The Jews counted years from the \u201cCreation of the world\u201d. 1 BC would have been 3759 by the Jewish calendar. (The Hebrew calendar has \u201ccreation\u201d be 3760 BC by our reckoning). As far as the Jewish people considered things, \u201c2 AD\u201d was 3762.\nThe BC and AD is not about science, but about religion and how Christians decided to count years. They decided to count years from the birth of Christ. That, to them, was the essential \u201cdate\u201d to base years on. As we have seen, the Romans decided their essential date was the founding of Rome and the Jews decided the creation of the world was the essential date. Other cultures have had other essential dates to begin counting.", "Q: How did people in ancient civilizations know they were in years 2 B.C. and 2 A.D. without modern science?\nFirst, there are many more calendars than the Gregorian calendar used by Christians. And there have been many more that no one uses today. The Gregorian calendar says it is 2020 AD (anno domini). It can also be called 2020 CE (common era). Before the Gregorian calendar Christians used the Julian calendar\u2026 well, the Gregorian calendar is really the Julian calendar with some fixes.\nThe traditional Chinese calendar says it\u2019s 4714.\nThe Buddhist calendar says it\u2019s 2560.\nThe Byzantine calendar, also based on the Julian calendar, says it is 7526.\nThe Ethiopian calendar, which is similar to the Julian calendar, says it is 2010.\nThe Hebrew calendar says 5778.\nThe Holocene calendar, which uses the beginning of the Human Era (HE) randomly chose 10,000 BCE (before common era) as the start date and, therefore, it is the year 12018.\nThe Islamic calendar says it is 1439.\nThe Japanese calendar says it is Heisei 30. 30? Yes, because their calendar counts from the reign of the current Emperor. Many older calendar systems did this as well.\nThe ancient Roman calendar was weird. The Senate could decide how many days were in a year so politics could get involved. Plus, they usually added days that to keep the seasons and months lined up with nature instead of having leap days. I\u2019m not sure what year it is.\nThe Thai Solar calendar says it\u2019s 2561.\nAnd there are many other calendars. The \u2018year\u2019 is just a number. Someone came up with a way of counting days, months, years, eras, etc and other people say, \u201cokay, we\u2019ll use that.\u201d\nTo understand the AD/BC counting system, you have to understand that the idea came about because Christian church leaders wanted to figure out when Easter should be celebrated. The First Council of Nicaea in 325 AD decided that Easter would fall on the Sunday following the full moon that follows the Spring Equinox. It\u2019s basically Passover for Christians but they needed a way to define when it should be celebrated by everyone in the Christian church.\nA guy by the name of Dionysus Exiguus came up with a system to calculate Easter. He wasn\u2019t the first but he created his \u201cEaster table\u201d (the list of calculated dates) and called it \u201cAnno Domini 532\u201d. The previous year had been calculated using a different system so it was called \u201cAnno Diocletiana 247\u201d, which had been named after a ruthless emperor who had persecuted Christians. It was his way of showing how he felt about the former emperor.\nDionysus never said how he calculated the date of Jesus\u2019 birth so everyone just had to accept he knew what he was doing. He was kinda close but research since has shown he was off. But, by that time, everyone agreed on the year so why change it?\nSo, a \u2018year\u2019 is just a number you happen to use now. People didn\u2019t think of 2 AD versus 2 BC because no one came up with that idea for several hundred years.", "The whole B.C. and A.D. is NOT the only calendar system in the world: It is the one most used today, that is all.\nB.C. and A.D. are based on Christianity: B.C. being \u201cBefore Christ\" and A.D. being \u201cAnno Domini\" which is latin for \u201cYear Of The Lord\". Other cultures and religions have their own calendar systems. Like the jewish calendar which uses a different start time than BC/AD. And in countries like japan and china they have a calendar system symbolized by animals. Such as \u201cYear Of The Horse\" and \u201cYear Of The Dragon\" which structurally is different from BC/AD.\nIn the far past, the origin point of the many calendars of ancient civilizations were most likely based on the founding of their culture, the reign of their kings, or another system we know nothing about today.\nSo, ancient people couldn't know about AD and BC any more than we today can know about \u201cThe Fifth Year Of The Reign Of King Karnezer\" or whatever calendar system the future inhabitants of Mars creates.", "The concept of AD didn\u2019t come around until later. It\u2019s an abbreviation of Anno Domini, or \u201cin the year of the Lord\u201d. People used other dating systems at the time, such as the year of the king or emperor\u2019s reign, or from when they thought the world was created.", "They didn't.\nDid you know it's 2563\nin Thailand? So, the \u201cancient civilizations\u201d didn\u2019t claim to be in a year based on the birth of Jesus.", "They didn\u2019t - those calendar concepts didn\u2019t arise until late antiquity. But they did know what date it was, according to whatever calendar they used.\nYou don\u2019t need \u201cmodern science\u201d to know what date it is. All you need is a set starting point, and daily markings. Even scratches on the cave wall will do. Gather enough scratches to count a year, mark a passing year, start again. If you lose track, or don\u2019t know how many days are in a year, just wait until a recurring astronomical event, like an equinox, to reset the count - and humans knew how to track these already in Stone Age.", "Simple, they cannot because that particular calendar system was invented in 525 C.E.\nThe Anno Domini dating system was devised in 525 by Dionysius Exiguus to enumerate the years in his Easter table. His system was to replace the Diocletian era that had been used in an old Easter table because he did not wish to continue the memory of a tyrant who persecuted Christians.[10] The last year of the old table, Diocletian Anno Martyrium 247, was immediately followed by the first year of his table, Anno Domini 532. When he devised his table, Julian calendar years were identified by naming the consuls who held office that year\u2014he himself stated that the \"present year\" was \"the consulship of Probus Junior\", which was 525 years \"since the incarnation of our Lord Jesus Christ\".[11] Thus Dionysius implied that Jesus' incarnation occurred 525 years earlier, without stating the specific year during which his birth or conception occurred. \"However, nowhere in his exposition of his table does Dionysius relate his epoch to any other dating system, whether consulate, Olympiad, year of the world, or regnal year of Augustus; much less does he explain or justify the underlying date.\"[12]\nAnno Domini - Wikipedia\nAny civilization at the time would have their own calendar. Artz begins his book The Mind of the Middle Ages, originally published in 1953, with this quip:\n\u201cSociologists usually begin with the Flood and the Fiijis; writers of history, with the Greeks. These \u2018spoiled darlings of the historians,\u2019 as they have been called, may often be allowed too dominant a place in world history, but their role in the story of mediaeval culture is fundamental.\u201d\nOf course, there is something that all readers should immediately take note of about Artz\u2019s book: the date.\nFor much of history, people in western Europe and in cultures descended from those in western Europe did not have access to many historical records from ancient Egypt or ancient Mesopotamia. Almost everything they knew about those cultures came from Greek sources and the Bible. The ancient Greeks were the earliest people that historians had access to detailed records of.\nOver the course of the past two centuries, thanks to the development of the brand new field of archaeology, these matters have drastically changed. Now historians have access to a wide array of different sources from ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt that have been recovered by archaeologists.\nNot all historians are making use of those sources, however. Some histories still begin with the Greeks. Many histories don\u2019t even go back that far; indeed, in my experience, it is a rare thing for a book dealing with the history of a certain thing or idea to go back any further than the discovery of the Americas by Europeans. Most historians\u2014at least here in the United States\u2014tend to speak as though the world didn\u2019t even exist before the year 1492.\nABOVE: Illustration of the Ni\u00f1a, the Pinta, and the Santa Maria, the three ships sailed by Christopher Columbus\u2019s crew on his first voyage across the Atlantic Ocean", "One word answer: Eurocentrism. In the early Middle Ages the Crown\u2019s income was limited to revenue from Crown property and whatever taxes or loans he could cajole out of his subjects or borrow from foreign subjects.\nNone of this was sufficient to pay for a force for very long, so the Crown instead relied on feudal obligations to serve, where the knights paid for their own arms, mounts, and provided a certain number of retainers.\nThese armies were typically only required to serve for a set amount of time, usually seasonal, when they were released for the harvest and other duties.\nThis is why castles were so effective, because for the most part the Crown didn\u2019t have the money to pay an army to invest them long enough to take them.", "Kings had their empire spread in large areas so they have to keep their armies to protect the places won by them", "In Medieval Times, why didn't the King have his own army\nMost medieval kings did have a personal \u2018army\u2019 or bodyguard. However, armies cost maintenance.\nrather than call his banners when going to war?\nWhen going to war, a feudal king would call upon his vassals to support him (who had their own private \u2018armies\u2019), possibly adding some mercenary force.\nHowever, few medieval kings would have \u2018banners\u2019, whcih is a term used for Mongol or Manchu armies.", "The way in which a King ruled his country varied throughout the Middle Ages and to some extent from country to country. A simplified explanation is as follows.\nIf a King has his own army, he needs to feed, clothe and house them all. No single area of a country can supply the materials for these, so he has to spread his soldiers out in garrisons round the country. Each garrison needs a senior officer to command it. So each of these senior officers is given a title (Duke, Earl, Lord, etc.) and each one is responsible for feeding, clothing and housing his own garrison. Instead of the garrison being a single fortress, the soldiers are spread out round the land that the officer is responsible for. In times of peace, the soldier is a farmer, who produces food and goods, some of which he keeps for himself, some goes to the officer and some to the King in the form of taxes. In times of war, the King calls in his officers, who call in their own soldiers. The problem sometimes is that an officer can get too powerful and challenge the authority of the King.", "Feudalism was about decentralization, each lord rules his chunk of land and reports back to the king with his own chunk of land.\nThere was no professional army funded by a central government because there was no central government, and so each lord of the land rellied on what they could master, knights and levies = lords and peasents. And they decided Mozzarella is the best Cheese and perfect for the Pizza.\nItalian Cheeses are a class of its own, and Mozzarella comes under the category it is called the Pasta Filata category, which means stretched curd.\nThe making process of Pasta Filata type cheeses is altogether different than the rest of the cheeses.\nThe most significant characteristic of Cheese on Pizza must be it should not oil off, and Mozzarella's unique process allows it. And the second characteristic of Italians wanted it, and the Cheese should be elastic and stretch when eating the Pizza. That is also built in the Cheese, the third characteristic of the Cheese must be it should not interfere with the authentic flavor of the cheese, Mozzarella is the cheese which is made with a neutral flavor. We in cheese technology call it washed curd cheese, which means one step in the process curd is washed to reduce lactose in the curd to tame down other flavor development in cheese.\nLet me summarize: Mozzarella is the cheese specifically developed for Pizza, it has to have three characteristics.\nCheese should not oil off, in puddles on the Pizza.\nCheese must be stretchable, not rigid like plastic.\nCheese should not interfere with the authentic flavor/taste of the Pizza.\nONLY Italians originally knew the art of science of Pasta Filata type of cheese, and they perfected it over the centuries. However, Caligula decided he could not wait for that and insisted on enjoying the privileges of godhood while still in human flesh.\nIronically, Augustus did not even declare himself King but only \u201cFirst Citizen.\u201d But, in order to legitimize his right to power, he did call himself a \u201cson of the divine\u201d: i.e. the (adopted) son of the newly deified Julius Caesar. So Augustus was the \u201cSon of God\u201d before this title was applied to Jesus Christ.\nCaligula, and Nero after him, declared he had more than the privileges of kings; he had the privileges of a \u201cSon of God\u201d and ultimately Zeus or Apollo.\nAnd the problem with these rulers \u2014 in contrast to hard-working emperors like Augustus, Claudius, and Marcus Aurelius \u2014 is that Caligula and Nero saw only the privileges of being divine and not the hard work of being the person who had to keep everyone in the empire happy and fed. Plus, obviously he died long before 1914. Impressions can be made from original etched plates after an artist is dead, and these impressions will count as \u2018originals\u2019. But if Leonardo didn\u2019t make any etchings, impressions can\u2019t be made from them at any time.\nWhat you probably have is an etching made by a later artist after a picture by Leonardo, in other words copying something by him. This isn\u2019t plagiarism or in any way underhand; it was a very common way (the best way before photography) of making reproductions of works of art so they could be distributed and seen by people who had no access to the original. Your etching is probably 17th or 18th century, and it\u2019s a very nice thing to have.\nIncidentally, he was known as \u2018Leonardo\u2019 during his lifetime, and that\u2019s how he\u2019s referred to by most people today. It seems to be mostly in the US (thanks to Dan Brown?) that he\u2019s usually called \u2019da Vinci\u2019. How many countries are involved in the Gulf War, and why did it happen?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "144", "name_list": ["Guru Prasaath"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "300": {"ans_list": ["The ancient Chinese retained its militaristic tradition because the original proto-Sinids arrived in the Central Plains as foreign conquerors. The \u201cbirthplace\u201d of the Chinese civilization was once filled with non-Sinitic people who spoke an unknown language and lived side by side some of the Sinitic tribes. These early proto-Sino-Tibetic settlers came to the western fringe of Yellow River basin and gradually expanded eastward, meeting the Dongyi in the east and a smaller \u201cAltaic\u201d group in the northeast. As competition over resources between these groups became fierce, these tribes began to form factions, by which time the proto-Sino-Tibetan people had already splintered off into two subgroups. The Sinitic tribes based out of the basin became unified under the confederacy between two chiefs\u2014Yan Di and Huang Di. The combined forces of the Sinids overwhelmed the Dongyi, defeating them and taking over their territory while assimilating defecting groups. The ancestors of the Chinese became militant in this period because of the threat of a common enemy and the need to acquire resources.\nThe Xia was succeeded by the Shang, who had a militant policy of raiding \u201cbarbarian neighbours\u201d that refused to give tribute and expanding its borders, during which foreign subjects were often captured in the process as human sacrifices. The warlikeness of the Shang and its cruel practices draw parallels with the Aztec of Mesoamerica, who also practiced live sacrifices. In this period, factors such as the Shang dynasty\u2019s religious beliefs and desire to subjugate barbarians pushed for war.\nModern illustration of what it might\u2019ve been like\nThe Shang was succeeded by the Zhou, which began as a semi-nomadic group living near the western fringe from which the original Sinids came to conquer the barbarians in the fertile Central Plains. The first King of Zhou overthrew the Shang with the help of the barbarians which suffered through the Shang\u2019s brutality, and thus began the next dynastic cycle where the Zhou brought China into the period of true feudalism, under which fiefdoms prospered eventually at the expense of the Zhou authority. As competition between the fiefdoms-turned-kingdoms (de facto) stiffen, the reality of an imminent war pushed for rapid reforms and militarization of the Chinese region, prompting many states to drive deeper into barbarian lands to obtain strategic lands and resources. The Chinese attitude of war in the Warring States period was driven by interstate rivalry and resources that would help one state best another.\nThrough reforms that brought about standardization and institutional meritocracy, the state of Qin went from humble beginnings to an industrial powerhouse whose war machine was unleashed for conquest. The scale of warfare in this period was comparable to an ancient \u201cWorld War I\u201d in which, perhaps, the German Empire emerged victorious. As each state had its reason for maintaining a strong culture of millitancy, it is much more complicated to dissect and analyze.\nFollowing unification, the Qin ramped up its national defence against the threat of a northern invasion. For centuries and millennia, the Chinese plain had been a rich and fertile oasis in the middle of less-than-desirable lands, yet with it come very little natural defence in the north. Throughout history, the Chinese people have had an overarching will to band together against this foreign threat from the north and protect the Chinese heartland. However, realizing that existing measures may not be enough to repel a large northern invasion (and rightly so in hindsight), the First Emperor looks to expand to the south of Zhongyuan to secure a Chinese \u201cLebensraum.\u201d This set off a series of invasions that ultimately led to the Chinese conquest of the south. Although the Qin forces in southern China were met with fierce resistance from the indigenous Baiyue, who repelled Chinese invasions twice, the Chinese nation at the time was arguably the more aggressive and militant of the two. With its better equipped soldiers, the Qin finally broke through the Southern Yue\u2019s last line of defence, establishing Chinese control over the region and began centuries of colonization, assimilation, and eventually acculturation.\nThe Attack of the Qin\nFrom the Qin to the Han, the recurring theme of securing the south as \u201cliving space\u201d for the Chinese and counter attacking the north to drive the barbarians away from Zhongyuan facilitated a culture of highly militant people. For a long time, the Han followed a practice where men carried sidearms upon the age of maturation, wrestling and \u201cwar games\u201d were commonplace, and the whole of Chinese society were trained to be easily conscripted or turned into militia when needed. After the rise of Han power, the Xiongnu threat had been crushed into no more than a scattered people and the Baiyue had been pacified and fell under Chinese control; from here onward began a relaxation of conscription laws and the focus was switched to developing the economy.\nThe Han strikes back!\nAs the Chinese civilization expanded, more lands were incorporated to protect the Chinese heartland. The southern expansion of the Qin, Han, and later dynasties gave the Chinese enough room and resources that the territorial shape of China Proper remained stable for the next one and a half millennia of Chinese history, thereby shifting the attention to governance, the economy and internal affairs, which not only mitigated the need for but also discouraged\u2014over time\u2014the militant culture of the Chinese because it was problematic in peacetime (as it was shown in history later again and again).\nAs to why the Chinese became rice farmers, it is because the lands in northern China weren\u2019t suited for rice farming prior to the early modern period. For the longest time, the Chinese were millet farmers until the expansion into Southern China, which allowed the Chinese settlers to cultivate rice and yield higher food production to sustain a larger population. Even today, the northern Chinese consume a lot of millet and wheat, but mostly wheat and rice.\nMillet vs rice\nActually, other than the transition from millet to wheat/rice, the Chinese also saw a change from lamb being the most consumed meat to pork now being most eaten. The change in diet occured as the population centre of the Chinese civilization shifted south, following the Uprising of the Five Barbarians, which led to various non-Sinitic people occupying the Chinese heartland in the north and expelling the Han to the south. This sparked a wave of acculturation where in the north Han and Xianbei culture intertwined and in the south Han culture intermingled with the Yue. It was during this period when most of southern China truly became sinicized (other than the Min and Yue regions, and Southwestern China). A similar wave of acculturation happened again following the collapse of the Tang dynasty, which led to Tanguts, Khitans, and Jurchens taking parts of China. After the Song dynasty fled south because of the Jurchens, the northern half of China including the Chinese heartland was occupied by the Jin dynasty and then the Mongols. The change in diet most likely accelerated under these conditions as Southern China was not suitable for raising sheep or growing millet/wheat. By the early Ming dynasty, pork had long become the most-eaten meat in China.\nReconstruction of Tang dynasty cusine", "not all chinese are originated han chinese pals. many chinese you see today descended from conquered and assimilated barbarian.\nyou can check northern han chinese and southern han chinese genetic difference online, you can find it anywhere."], "topic_list": ["Three Kingdoms Period (\u4e09\u570b)", "Rice (grain)", "History of China", "History"], "view_list": [69, 58], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Anonymous", "upvote_list": [2, 0], "question_title": "The Chinese up until the Three Kingdoms period were fierce, individualistic millet farmers. But 100 years ago (early in the Twentieth Century) it wasn't so rare. Poor medical healh, poor diet, lack of medicines, lack of prenatal care all were factors in women dying during or just after childbirth.", "The NHS was founded in 1947 - the year I was born. My mother birthed me at home. Doctors and midwives made home visits - and still do.\nHowever, my niece, whose due date is today, was planning a home birth but the midwife told them it will have to be in the Maternity hospital. No doubt it is that emergency help will be at hand If needed. EMS is overwhelmed with Coronavirus emergencies.", "The great majority of women in the UK had a home delivery by a State Certified Midwife. A doctor was only involved if a problem arose which was beyond the midwife\u2019s competence (and they could cope with most complications). There was little in the way of pain relief. Chloral hydrate and Opium drops were the most a woman could expect. Nitrous oxide and oxygen (Entonox), did not come into use until the 1950s. There was a gas called Trilene that was used from 1934, but probably not for general patients. And it had many side effects. There was then no NHS, so the midwife had to be paid for and the doctor as well, if he were called out.\nMiddle class women often gave birth in private Nursing Homes. They had the doubtful luxury of a single room but, like their poorer sisters, they did not have the comfort of their husband\u2019s presence. Men of that era would probably been unable to cope. In the nursing home, \u201c twilight sleep\u201d was administered for pain relief. This was a subcutaneous injection of Morphine and Hyoscine. If the dose needed to be repeated, the Morphine was omitted. It is not a good drug to use in obstetrics, as it depresses the baby\u2019s respiratory rate. So hyoscine was given alone. It promotes amnesia, so the mothers did not fully remember their labor pains. When all was over, husband was wheeled in to admire his new child.\nUpper-class women also often gave birth in the comfort of their own homes. But, whether nursing home or private home, a renowned Harley Street obstetrician would be involved, with probably a midwife present as well.\nBottle feeding had become fashionable among the middle classes but working class women still usually breast fed. No doubt their babies were all the better for it.\nThank you for the A2A\nMargaret Myles: A Textbook for Midwives.Livingstone (1966, Edinburgh)", "Unless you were wealthy or a high risk, the majority of births happened at home. If you couldn\u2019t afford a doctor, female relatives or a lady in the area who specialised in childbirth would deliver the baby. There was a much higher mortality rate for both mothers and infants because if there were difficulties the attending women did not have the equipment or skills required to save them. Think of all the people who need caesarean sections these days - they would often die because of blood loss, infection or ruptures.\nThe birth could happen in a house with an awful lot of other children in it, so privacy and a dedicated area for the Burt were often hard to come by. There were no drugs on offer so women could succumb to exhaustion in a long labour.\nThe advent of the NHS meant that all women had the opportunity to go to either a maternity unit or home with trained midwives and obstetricians on hand. Painkillers were available, medical interventions in case of difficulties were more possible and women could rest after childbirth without having to look after the baby and all of the other children. Childbirth became safer and mortality rates dropped. Women could still give birth at home but there would be a trained midwife there and in case of emergency, an ambulance could be summoned to take them to hospital. And all of this became free so there was no consideration about affording medical help.", "Largely the same. The nhs was simply a grab for existing assets put under unified control to be financed out of general taxation. We know that anything beyond that is vastly harder to make purely by more energetic events - the ones we\u2019ve made artificially all required tricks to get around the problems, not just more energy. And that\u2019s where the problem lies, because there are fundamental limits on how much energy an event can have, because the more you gather in one spot the more chance that it all collapses into a black hole (or kugelblitz, effectively an energy-based black hole rather than a matter-based one) and in a black hole no elements exist - long before they get to that point they get compressed in neutronic matter (what neutron stars are made of) in which no elements exist.\nMaybe, possibly, in some remote corner of the possibly infinite universe, the conditions were just right and those elements formed for an instant before either decaying or being sucked into a black hole, but it is unlikely.", "It\u2019s possible, but so what?
