Mendel was apparently an independently minded monk. He did his pioneering research in the monastery garden. I\u2019ve read he was popular in the local district in that he contributed to garden shows and such. He published his work with the common garden pea in an obscure local journal. It wasn\u2019t discovered by leading biologists for about 40 years, that is in about the year 1900.\nHe also did work on another plant species on the advice of a university biologist. It was hard to work with and responded differently than the garden pea. It\u2019s a pity he apparently didn\u2019t correspond with Charles Darwin, although he was apparently aware of him.\nA short summary of his results with the common garden pea: He chose seven variable characteristics. He made crosses with these. He found in each case a dominant and a recessive allele. The F1 plants in each case showed one of the two variables. The next generation, the F2, segregated ca 3:1 in each case. The characteristic that disappeared in the F1 generation, turned up 25% of the time in the F2. The 7 genes Mendel chose to work with responded the same way. He chose well. Interestingly each gene was on a different chromosome so he didn\u2019t discover linkage. Statistically his results were closer to a 3:1 ratio than would be expected. What may have happened is that once he cottoned onto the 3:1 ratio he may have chosen when to stop counting his material. At that time the science of statistics was not available.\nMendel later gave up his experimental work to become head of the monastery, including hassles with government personnel over taxes.\nWikipedia probably has a good summary of his life and work."], "topic_list": ["History of Biology", "Gregor Mendel", "History of Science", "Scientists", "Scientific Research", "Science of Everyday Life", "Genetics and Heredity", "Biology", "Science", "History"], "view_list": [5, 104], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Forrest Rackard", "upvote_list": [0, 2], "question_title": "What are some interesting facts about Gregor Mendel?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "562", "name_list": ["Biron Lim", "Robert Irvine Wolfe"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "852": {"ans_list": ["Anitbiotics", "Seriously I don\u2019t think any great revolution has ever been the result of a random accident alone. No doubt this shattered his world view of what it meant to be the *human being.*", "If you mean general administration of camps, it was Lenin idea, but the camps were bound to have some administration. If you mean sending prisoners for labor, that was general idea of Bolsheviks (and many other left-wing), but the general idea of prisoner labor existed in Russian Empire and British Empire.\nGulag\n: acronym of Main Administration of Camps, Russian: \u0413\u043b\u0430\u0432\u043d\u043e\u0435 \u0443\u043f\u0440\u0430\u0432\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u043b\u0430\u0433\u0435\u0440\u0435\u0439) \u2026 was the government agency which was in charge of the Soviet network of forced-labour camps which was set up by order of Vladimir Lenin.\n\u2026\nEnglish-language speakers also use the word gulag to refer to all forced-labour camps which existed in the Soviet Union, including camps which existed in the post-Stalin era.\n\u2026\nAlthough the term Gulag originally referred to a government agency, in English and many other languages the acronym acquired the qualities of a common noun, denoting the Soviet system of prison-based, unfree labour.\n\u2026\nThe Tsar and the Russian Empire used both forced exile and forced labour as forms of judicial punishment. Katorga, a category of punishment reserved for those convicted of the most serious crimes, had many of the features associated with labour-camp imprisonment: confinement, simplified facilities (as opposed to prisons), and forced labour, usually involving hard, unskilled or semi-skilled work. According to historian Anne Applebaum, katorga was not a common sentence; approximately 6,000 katorga convicts were serving sentences in 1906 and 28,600 in 1916.[33] Under the Imperial Russian penal system, those convicted of less serious crimes were sent to corrective prisons and also made to work.[34] Forced exile to Siberia had been in use since the seventeenth century for a wide range of offenses and was a common punishment for political dissidents and revolutionaries. In the nineteenth century, the members of the failed Decembrist revolt, Polish nobles who resisted Russian rule, and members of various socialist revolutionary groups, including Bolsheviks such as Sergo Ordzhonikidze, Leon Trotsky, and Joseph Stalin were all sent into exile.[35] Convicts serving labour sentences and exiles were sent to the underpopulated areas of Siberia and the Russian Far East \u2013 regions that had few towns or food sources and lacked any organised transportation systems. Despite the isolated conditions, there were prisoners who successfully escaped to populated areas. Stalin himself escaped three of the four times he was sent into exile.[36] From these times, Siberia gained its fearful connotation of punishment, which was further enhanced by the Soviet GULAG system. The Bolsheviks' own experiences with exile and forced labour provided them with a model on which to base their system, including the importance of strict enforcement.\n\u2026\nPenal labour\nImprisonment with hard labour was first introduced into English law with the Criminal Law Act 1776 (6 Geo III c 43),[3] also known as the \"Hulks Act\", which authorized prisoners being put to work on improving the navigation of the River Thames in lieu of transportation to the North American colonies, which had become impossible due to the American Revolutionary War.", "The first Soviet document, in which the forced labor of prisoners was considered as an economic resource, was published on April 15, 1919. This was a resolution of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee \"On forced labor camps.\"\n\u041f\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0430\u043d\u043e\u0432\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u0412\u0426\u0418\u041a \u043e \u043b\u0430\u0433\u0435\u0440\u044f\u0445 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u043d\u0443\u0434\u0438\u0442\u0435\u043b\u044c\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u0440\u0430\u0431\u043e\u0442\nSubsequently (in 1929) the camp system turned into the [ economic ] department of the OGPU ( and then NKVD ).", "Karl Marx, in his Communist Manifesto, says that one of his goals is \u201cEstablishment of industrial armies\u201d.\nThis is what GULAG is - slave labor.", "Joint State Political Directorate"], "topic_list": ["Soviet Gulag", "Gulags", "History of USSR", "Soviet Union", "Prisoners", "Prisons and Prison Life", "History"], "view_list": [233, 515, 573, 510, 49], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Rohan Thomas", "upvote_list": [0, 4, 2, 2, 0], "question_title": "Who created the idea of a gulag?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "2,537", "name_list": ["George Doolittle", "Roman Podolyan", "Sergey Yaroslavtsev", "Sam Steingold", "Quora User"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "249": {"ans_list": ["Much better than under Stalin but still highly restricted and political .Kruschev really wanted to improve the lives of Russians as long as it was under the aegis of the Communist Party. I\u2019ll lay out some foundations first and then get to that.\nMost rifles made in the 1800s were black powder. Smokeless didn\u2019t become common until the late 1800s. Black powder is inferior to smokeless for most purposes, thus most 19th century (1800s) rifles are by the use of blackpowder inferior.\nIf you mean rifles from the 1900s. Semi-autos were in common use in the early 1900s. WW I had a bushel full of them, even if the primary infantry weapon of most armies was still bolt action until the 1950s.\nAs for better. Caliber, accuracy, and reliability are the primary measures of this. There were and are junk rifles in any century.\nPurpose is another consideration. A nagant made in the 1890s has far greater range than 95% of the semi-automatics out there right now. So a single guy with a Nagant can hold off an entire squad of people using medium ranged weapons like M4s, AK-47s, just about any common configuration for the AR except for 6.5 CM. The Nagant could also take a deer at greater ranges.\nThe Nagant packs a heavier bullet and would be better at taking out big game like a bear than 95% of the semi-auto rifles out there today.\nHowever a Nagant isn\u2019t usually exceptionally accurate. Depends on when and where it was made and what modifications have been made. Semi-autos are usually fairly accurate inside 400 yards. Depends on the round. With the exception of the .50 BMG which sometimes comes as a semi-auto. Some maniac actually made a bull pup version for people who hate their shoulders lol. Generally semi-auto rounds are medium or short range calibers. I say generally. A 6.5 CM or a 30.06 semi-auto can reach out as far as a Nagant.\nBolt action rifles which were becoming very popular in the late 1800s, are typically more accurate than any other kind of rifle. In terms of velocity, a botl action and semi-auto in the same caliber, the bolt action will have more range and velocity. Usually but not necessarily better accuracy. Bolt action rifles are usually designed for accuracy first. Semi-autos favor round capacity, light weight, features, etc first. Accuracy is sometimes an after thought. However, there are some extremely accurate semi-autos and some very inaccurate bolt action rifles.\nIn a fire fight the semi-auto tends to be the better weapon. For hunting and sniping the bolt action is usually the better weapon. The long barrel on most bolt actions make them a poor choice for a self defense weapon. Most semi-autos are carbines and thus make at least decent self defense weapons.\nSo it depends on caliber, specific rifle, and purpose as to which is better.", "Well, Kathy, I'm not sure what you are asking.\nWhat 19th century rifle and better for what?\nOff hand, since the question lacks specificity enough to make an answer, I'd say \u201cno\u201d. It was never one nation.\nThe \u2018British Empire\u2019 was the informal name for the collection of overseas territories, protectorate, colonies, mandates etc that were fully or partially governed / administered from the UK. It was never the official name of a nation.\nTo answer the question, no. There are officially no more empires and no more colonies, as declared by the United Nations.\nThere are countries with overseas territories that are administered in a parent country, i.e. France with French Guiana, Spain with Ceuta & Melilla etc. These are the last remnants of the French Empire, and one of the few overseas territories governed as a part of another country.\nThere are overseas territories governed locally, but rely on a parent country for defence/diplomacy, i.e. the Falkland Islands with the UK.\nThen there are countries with extensive military bases in other nations like the US. Countries with vast investments in other nations such as China with several African nations.\nThe closest old Empire to a modern nation is likely France. Whilst retaining a considerable number of overseas territories, their administration over French Guiana makes them the only European ex-imperial power to retain a large overseas territory directly governed by the main country.", "There most certainly are. The principle three are the USA, Russia and Brazil.\nAs the territorial area gets smaller the term 'empire' enters a grey area, there are arguably other examples but they are more debatable.", "A great number of states were forged from imperial constructs or their remnants.\nIran, for instance, which was officially the Persian Empire for a long time. Archaeologists study the human past through the medium of material culture and physical remains. They typically specialize in some broad region and time period. There are Egyptologists, classical archaeologists, Mesoamericanists, and so on, and even those are very broad categories which contain narrower specializations.\nBiblical archaeologists are one of those specializations. A Biblical archaeologist deals with the region and time period in which the historical events of the Old and New Testaments took place, which is to say mostly the Levant during the first millennium BC, shading into the early AD period and neighboring regions like Mesopotamia and Egypt.", "Perhaps I\u2019m getting irascible in my dotage, but I swear there are so many questions on Quora these days which are somewhat unimaginative.\nWhat is the difference between an archaeologist and a \"biblical archaeologist\"?\nUm, the term \u201carchaeologist\u201d covers a wide range of specialisms, but essentially describes a profession which is uncovering (often literally!) the history of humanity, from the earliest proto-human fossils, right up until a couple of hundred years ago.\nA \u201cbiblical archaeologist\u201d is an archaeology who specialises in the archaeology of Bible lands (from Egypt, Israel, Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, Iraq & Turkey (and perhaps further afield, is studying the spread of Christianity, or Jewish enclaves), as well as comparing finds to events & people in the Bible.\nArchaeology - Wikipedia\nBiblical archaeology - Wikipedia", "One group involves the study of all places and time periods of archaeology, and the other group concentrates upon the archaeology of the Middle East in the time periods associated with the beginnings of Abrahamic religions.\n:D"], "topic_list": ["Archaeologists", "Archaeology", "The Bible", "History"], "view_list": [1, 31, 24], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Christopher Bertram Allan", "upvote_list": [0, 2, 3], "question_title": "What is the difference between an archaeologist and a \"biblical archaeologist\"?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "507", "name_list": ["Matt Riggsby", "Nigel Perels", "TJ Berens"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "915": {"ans_list": ["Why not? To begin with Germany was going to lose money and territory by having long the war. That was a given. Germany was prepared to seize money and territory had they won the war\u2014they did so against France in 1871, and against Romania and Russia in 1918. They had also planned to annex large parts of France and Belgium had they won. Germany mostly lost areas that had traditionally been parts of other nations (A-L to France, S-H to Denmark) who had area with large non-German populations for example to Poland. (And no, the Sudetenland does not count as that had been part of AUSTRIA not Germany).\nReoperations? Not nearly as crushing, especially since the allies were willing to negotiate and set up payment plans. And again, Germany had demanded on \u201cindemnities\u201d from France twice in the 1800s (though once as the German Confederation of the Rhine) and like I pointed out, from Russia in 1918. And again, they were planning to take them from the allies in the west too. Sure German\u2019s economy was a mess in the early 1920s, but the same could be said for all of Europe, there was no \u201cMarshall Plan\u201d in 1919. But, like the rest of Europe Germany had entered into recovery by the mid 1920s and life had largely turned around.\nWar guilt? There was not \u201cwar guilt clause\u201d rather there was a clause that established a legal link between Germany\u2019s actions in the war, and the right of the allies to collect reoperations. The other treaties that settled issues with Austria, Hungary, Turkey and Bulgaria also had similar clauses, these nations simply didn't make a big deal about them. As one Frenchman put it \u201cWas it France that attacked Germany? That invaded and caused havoc in neutral Belgium? That caused as much damage as possible? No! It was Germany that did that to France and Belgium.\u201d\nThe treaty was actually pretty soft on Germany\u2014German\u2019s rival of Austria-Hungary was gone, and Germany no longer had to share a border with Russia. Germany found itself surrounded by weaker, quarreling states that they could have easily had sway over.\nThe Nazis were more a result of issues that already existed in German society before the war, and then the instability of the Weimar Republic and the effects of the Depression. Keep in mind that much of Nazi ideology ( \u201cAryan Racial Purity\u201d destruction of the Slavs, settling their lands, the mass-murder of Jews, Roma and Sinti people as well as homosexuals, people seen as \u201cdisabled\u201d and left-leaning political members, Jehovah\u2019s Witness and others) had nothing to do with the Treaty.\nPart of the problem was the perception in Germany that they \u201chadn\u2019t really been defeated\u201d and thus the allies had no right to determine the terms of the treaty. As a result the allies were much harsher in 1945, invading Germany, insisting on an unconditional surrender, putting the country under occupation, splitting it in two, and Germany lost even more land in 1945 than in 1918.", "German Eastern expansion had not been crushed. But there are exceptions. The epic of Gilgamesh, besides its morefantastic content, is about an actual Sumerian king. The Iliad inspired Schliemann to go lokk for and indeed find the ancient city of Troy.\nSo when looking at legends it\u2019s omportant to realzie that they are legends (not history), but they may contain some elements of historical fact - however small.\nThings become different when we consider cultural history, for which legends are quite important as they give information on the cultural outlook of the yime (and the people) when they were written.\nFor instance, the Iliad tells us plenty about the mindset of the upper class in archaic Greece, as well as about the way war was fought.\nBut here again one must be careful. The second comes from the verb to coddle, meaning to treat somebody in an overprotective way, as though he or she were an invalid. The verb in this sense is not recorded before the early part of the nineteenth century \u2014 its first appearance is in Jane Austen\u2019s Emma: \u201cBe satisfied with doctoring and coddling yourself\u201d. It looks very much as though it comes from an older sense of the verb meaning to boil gently, to parboil. That sense is linked to caudle, an old word for a warm drink of thin gruel mixed with sweetened and spiced wine or ale, which was given chiefly to sick people. Hence, by association of ideas, coddle took on its modern sense.\u201d\n\u201cThe first bit is on the face of it easy enough, since it is from the pet form of the given name Mary (as in Sweet Molly Malone of Dublin\u2019s fair city). But Molly has also had a long history in several different but related senses associated with low living. (The name was popularised by Middleton and Dekker\u2019s play The Roaring Girl of 1611, which featured a criminal called Moll Cut-purse.) As either molly or moll, from the early seventeenth century on it was often used to describe a prostitute, hence, much later, the American gangster\u2019s moll. As molly it was also a common eighteenth-century name for a homosexual man, often in the form Miss Molly, and a molly housewas a male brothel (as in Mark Ravenhill\u2019s new play at the National Theatre in London, Mother Clap\u2019s Molly House).\u201d\n\u201cIt\u2019s sometimes said that the molly in mollycoddlecomes from the sense of a prostitute, but the usage evidence shows that it was really linked to the gay associations. As a noun, it was used particularly of a man who had been over-protected in childhood and so considered to have been made into a milksop or effeminate. For example, William Makepeace Thackeray wrote in Pendennis in 1849: \u201cYou have been bred up as a molly-coddle, Pen, and spoilt by the women\u201d. The verb came along later in the nineteenth century and was used more like the way we do now.\u201d\nAttribution:\nWorld Wide Words: Mollycoddling", "That\u2019s a very old saying.\nIt means \u201ctaking too much care of somebody\u201d.\n\u201c Don\u2019t Molly Coddle them\u201d!\nUsed where kids are being naughty and maybe need a whack on the bum."], "topic_list": ["Molly Weasley (Wizarding World character)", "Etymology", "History"], "view_list": [158, 9], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "Don Kelly", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "Where did Molly Coddle come from?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "660", "name_list": ["Brent Cooper", "Barry Watson"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "618": {"ans_list": ["Probably nothing. It appears that Tibetans captured a number of Arab troops and pressed them into service on the eastern frontier in 801. Tibetans were active as far west as Samarkand\nand Kabul\n. Arab forces began to gain the upper hand, and the Tibetan governor of Kabul submitted to the Arabs and became a Muslim about 812 or 815.\nThe first contacts with Tibet and the Islamic world began around the mid-eighth century when it grew out of a combination of trade via the Silk Road\nand the military presence of Muslim forces in the Fergana Valley\n. Despite the vague knowledge the Islamic world had about Tibet, there were a few early Islamic works that mention Tibet. One such source is from a work authored by Abu Sa'id Gardezi\ntitled Zayn al-Akhbar. In it, the work mentions the environment, fantastical origin of the Tibetans (through the Himyarites), the divinity of the king, major resources (like musk) and a description of the trade routes to and from Tibet. Another source, Hudud al-'Alam (The Regions of the World) written by an unknown author in 982 or 983 in Afghanistan\n, contains mainly geography, politics and brief descriptions of Tibetan regions, cities, towns and other localities. This source has the first direct mention of the presence of Muslims in Tibet by stating that Lhasa\nhad one mosque and a small Muslim population.\nExtensive trade with Kashmir\n, Ladakh\n, and Baltistan\nalso brought Muslims to Tibet especially after the adoption or growing presence of Islam in these regions starting from the fourteenth century. The ongoing growth of Muslims continued as an affect of the Tibetan-Ladakhi treaty of 1684 in which the Tibetan government allowed trade missions from Ladakh to enter Lhasa every three years. Many Kashmiri and Ladakhi Muslims joined these missions with some settling in Tibet.\nDuring the reign of the Dalai Lama Ngawang Lobsang Gyatso\n(1617-1682), a permanent Muslim community settled down in Tibet. They were permitted to elect their own council of representatives, settle their group's legal disputes with Islamic law, and some land was donated to them for the construction of a mosque close to Lhasa\n.\nAn influx of Kashmiri Muslims in Nepal (originally having trade contacts with their kin in Tibet) fled to Tibet starting from 1769 as a consequence of the invasion of the Kathmandu Valley\nby Prithvi Narayan Shah\n. As early as the seventeenth century, Ningxia\nand other northwestern Hui\n(Chinese Muslims) began to settle in the eastern regions of Tibet (like in Amdo\n). They intermarried with the local Tibetans and continued to have to extensive trade contacts with other Muslims inside China.\nAnother recent wave of new Muslim settlers began after the Dogra conquest of Tibet in 1841. Many Kashmiri and Ladakhi Muslim troops (who were taken as prisoners when fighting against the Dogra army) stayed behind to settle in Tibet. A few Hindu Dogras also settled in Tibet and subsequently converted to Islam.\nAfter the Chinese conquest of Tibet in 1950, the Tibetan Muslims faced brutal persecution just like their Buddhist brethren. Since then, Chinese Muslims (along with the Han and others) have settled in Tibet.\nThe Chinese government classified the Tibetan Muslims as Hui. However, the Tibetan Muslims are often called Zang Hui (Tibetan Hui) as they speak Tibetan and have a material culture almost identical to their Buddhist counterparts. The Tibetan Hui in Lhasa\n(unlike other Tibetan Muslims living elsewhere) consider themselves to be very different from the Chinese Muslims and sometimes marry with other Tibetans (including Buddhist) instead of their fellow Muslims from China.\nConverts in Qinghai\nIslam was spread by the Salar people\nto the formerly Buddhist Kargan Tibetans in Lamo-shan-ken.\nSome Tibetans in Qinghai who converted to Islam are now considered Hui people\n.\nBalti people\nThe Balti people\nof Baltistan\nin Pakistan\nand Kargil\nin India\nare descendants of Tibetan Buddhists who converted to Noorbakshia\nsect of Islam . With the passage of time a large number converted to Shia Islam\n, and a few converted to Sunni\nIslam. Their Balti language\nis highly archaic and conservative and closer to Classical Tibetan\nthan other Tibetan languages\n.\nlinks\nISLAM & TIBET Bibliography\nHistory of the Muslims of Tibet\nForeign relations of Tibet - Wikipedia\nTibetan Muslims - Wikipedia", "If Arabs tried to conquer Tibet, then naturally Tibetans would seek Chinese help.\nAnd that would give Chinese another chance to drive out Arabs from Central Asia.\nSo it is logical that Arabs chose not to break their friendship with Tibet."], "topic_list": ["Tibet", "Invasions", "Historic Battles", "The Arab World", "Arab Ethnicity and People", "The Middle East", "Islam", "Military History and Wars", "China", "International Relations", "History"], "view_list": [23, 46], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Aakash Paran Baishya", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "After the Battle of Talas in 751 A.D, why did Arabs not invaded Tibet?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "159", "name_list": ["Aakash Paran Baishya", "Sagar Meloth"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "875": {"ans_list": ["Who is the author? In particular, learn about how his argument with the Roman Catholic church is one of the most mis-understood events in history. Tim O\u2019Neill summarized it quite well:\nTim O'Neill's answer to What is the most misunderstood historical event?\nMost of his actual scientific writings are mostly of interest only if you\u2019re deeply interested in the history of science. If you\u2019re hoping to learn anything about actual physics or other sciences, you\u2019re *much* better off finding a good college textbook instead. A *lot* of stuff that was written during that time frame was expressed \u201cthe best way they knew how\u201d - but improvements in our understanding of mathematics and nature have made a huge difference. So for instance, Newton had to invent calculus to prove what\u2019s now known as the shell theorem - but now the proof is considered a not-difficult homework problem for a college freshman math class.\nSo you can be reading some writing from the 1400s to 1600s, and the poor guy will take 10 pages to explain how to calculate a quantity - and today it\u2019s understood to the point where \u201cOh, that\u2019s just the second derivative of this equation\u201d. On top of that, knowing that A is the second derivative of B tells you more about the system\u2019s behavior than the 10 pages of explanation..", "And why not? Read it. Guderian was calm and collected who used aggression in a controlled manner to punch through his enemy and wreak havoc in his rear. He may not have been as brilliant or original as Manstein but in strategic decisions they were in accord. He may have been caustic and difficult with his superiors but he was usually proven to be right. He also instinctively knew how to get the best out of his men and their armour which may sound a rather simple thing but is very difficult to achieve. He understood logistics and how his army could operate within and on the boundaries of those constraints. He won crushing victories in both the east and the west and was seen as a true threat by all his enemies for his cunning and doggedness.\nPatton on the other hand blew hot and cold and was often ruled by his emotions. He was undoubtedly a good general but he was never as consistent or as effective as Guderian and this comes down to logistics. Patton was useless at logistics and as a result on many occasions his army was hamstrung by his inattentive nature to the minutiae of logistical planning which would have allowed him to exploit victory or stave off defeat, especially in Tunisia. He was definitely very aggressive but it often took the form of gambles rather than calculated risks. Of all the western generals he is the only one where his detractors called him a callous butcher. For him the offensive was all and only the willingness to fight and die mattered. Great when he picks the right plan but disastrous when he picks the wrong one which he did on occasion. The Byzantines suggest in manuals taking care about showing the number of unit banners as , if the opponent knows you have 400 men in a unit and they can see ten banners then they know you have 4000 or so men. But that is a regular army\nThe Avars are noted as foming their battle line of irregular sized units which made counting them difficult. They probably formed from retinues and clan units which varied in size.\nIn Western Europe you coud count banners\u2026not a scientific method , but the higher nobility were the only ones entitled to square banners, the lesser ones triangular pennons. Lots of big banners indicated lots of men.\nOn the march the scouts could guage the length of the column and back at base it could be compared with your own column length to make an estimate. Time to pass a point would give the same comparison.\nCamp size could be compared. In nedieval times tents were placed close together so that interlocking guy ropes would provide a defence against an attack so densities were similar.\nLastly, on the field you could compare the length of the lines. A man on foot, for example, takes upbabout a yard and the likely formation is say eight deep, so distance in yards x eight gives a number. As the armies could get quite close to one another it should be possible to get an idea of depth from a viewpoint.\nLastly the scouts could pick up a straggler or deserter and beat what information they coukdbout of him. Not always useful as only the top people in an army knew its numbers and perhaps not all of them.\nThe most important output from any numbering was whether the enemy would overlap your line and how to make dispositions to cope with that or exploit an enemy\u2019s inferiority. To do that your generals only needed the rough proportions of the opposing troops in relationship to your own. A 10% difference was not significant, a 50% one would be. He decreed that henceforth Christianity would be the official state religion of the Empire. Wessex was the last of the large kingdoms to form, and up to about 685 the situation there is pretty fluid and obscure, but certainly strong Mercian kings like Penda (r.626\u2013655) or Wulfhere (r.658\u2013675) campained and intervened in the region that would become Wessex. Also, in 664, Wulfhere intervened in Essex to overthrow its last pagan king. Sussex, on the other hand, tended to be a willing ally of Mercia at that time. It made strategic sense, in that the rulers of Sussex correctly saw that the main threat they faced was a strong, unified Wessex. Perhaps because of this, King C\u00e6dwalla of Wessex concentrated on defeating and occupying Sussex, succeeding by 688.\nBy the century\u2019s end, Mercia was clearly the largest and most vigorous of the kingdoms, but Wessex was still a power in its own right, fully able to maintain its independence until 726. At that point there was a succession dispute. Exactly what happened is obscure, but one interpretation is that Mercia intervened to put its candidate, \u00c6thelheard, on the throne, and Wessex \u2018submitted\u2019 to Mercia.\n\u2018Ascendancy\u2019 was a peculiarly British form of relationship between kings or kingdoms. One king would \u2018submit\u2019 to another, but still remain in power otherwise, and when the ascendant kingdom weakened, it often happened that the submitting king would then reassert his full independence.\nIn 752, King Cuthred of Wessex threw off Mercian overlordship. In 757, Mercia manged to get its chosen candidate, Cynewulf, onto the throne of Wessex, but then fell into a succession crisis itself, giving Cynewulf the chance to assert his independence as described above, which he maintained for the rest of his reign, until 786.\nAt that point, Offa of Mercia was able to get his ally, Beorhtric, onto the throne of Wessex and establish a full client relationship again. This lasted until 802, when Ecgberht, who had been Beorhtric\u2019s main rival in 786, at last took the throne. He pursued a more independent policy from the start, and in 825 managed to turn the tables, defeating Beornwulf of Mercia and taking control of Mercia\u2019s small dependencies, including Essex and Sussex. In 829, he consolidated this by invading Mercia and making himself king there too. Mercia reasserted its independence the following year, but its ascendancy was over.\nSo I think we can say the Mercian ascendancy began by 700, and included overlordship of Essex as early as 664, but with overlordship of (almost certainly) all the Saxon kingdoms only between 726\u2013752 and 786\u2013825.", "King Offa of Mercia, ruled the South ofEngland, (South of the Humber), I believe Wessex was more of a vassal Kingdom at the time, rather than part of Mercia itself.\nThis was pretty much over all Saxons, since those in the North (Kingdom of Northumbria) were Angles.\nOffa was King of Mercia from 757\u2013796, during a period know was the Mercian Supremacy.\nThe Mercian Supremacy ended in 825, when King Ecgbert of Wessex defeated Beornwulf of Mercia, establishing independence for Wessex. Ecgbert later became King of Mercia as well\nEcgbert\u2019s Grandson was Alfred the Great, who\u2019s grandson was King Athelstan, who was the first King of England.\nSouthern England during the Mercian Supremacy"], "topic_list": ["Saxons (Tribe)", "Anglo-Saxons", "History"], "view_list": [25, 123], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 5, "question_author": "Iggy Fernandez", "upvote_list": [1, 0], "question_title": "At what point did Mercia gain hegemony over the Saxons? Since they started with a civil war, they were quite experienced in executing people way before USSR was formed, so they had some ideas. First, it was (almost always) done via shooting. Like, hanging is more about killing people, while shooting is about FIGHTING THE ENEMY. Since conviction they were under some special restrictions, one of those was - they always traveled between the chambers at the facility with a bag on their heads, to avoid possible escaping attempts. Since it was moths or years between the conviction and actual executing, they got quite used to the drill of walking with 2 guards, holding them from each side, with a bag on their head. That's not ironic, it's normal.\nEngland and France were enemies for centuries, then became allies. Countries tend not to have permanent friends or permanent enemies.", "History has plenty of ironic former blood feud enemies-turned-alliances, so Vietnam become a close ally to the US isn\u2019t something so surprising.\nLook at Western Europe, nations were pretty much constantly at war trying to wipe each others out for the last 500 years, now turned into one of the most geopolitically stable regions on Earth, where anyone can cross borders as easily as shopping groceries downtown.\nIt\u2019s hard to believe a war of apocalyptic scale just took place as recently as 75 years ago on this land. Thanks to the EU, the region has achieved the level of unprecedented peace and prosperity unheard of since maybe the time of the Roman Empire.\nOr how can we not mention the relationship between the US and the UK. From enemies in the American Revolutionary War to become strategic allies in modern time.\nFrom this\nto this\ndrastic improvement if you ask me.\nOr how about the relationship between the US and Japan. Both armies grinded each others out in some of the bloodiest displays of fanaticism and atrocity during the Pacific Campaign of World War II. Asking a soldier or a citizen from both sides in 1945 if they would think that one day, their nations will become friends and allies, have joint military exercises, trade partnerships, and enjoy each others culture, i'm quite sure their answer will be: unlikely.\nAnd yet, the unlikely happened.\nThese are just three of the most prominent examples of the more recent times. We can talk about countless other ironic turns of alliances that goes back to Bronze Age, but that will require word count comparable to an encyclopedia. What my point is, geopolitic situations change all the time, and no affiliation or animosity are set on stone. There're just nations with different interests. When interests converge, alliances are formed. Or the opposite. The Vietnam War was no doubt one of the most terrible conflicts of the last century, but it does not mean there's little chance for a strategic relationship between Vietnam and the US to be formed. As long as they have the same interests, stand on the same ground, and have the same adversary, the possibility of the US gaining another close ally in the South East Asia is becoming more of a reality.", "There is no real irony in this. The United States, in its history, has also been at war with the United Kingdom (twice), France, Mexico, Spain, Germany (twice), Austria, Hungary, Japan and Italy, among other countries. It has friendly relations with, and an alliance, with every one of those nations today. There is nothing ironic about former enemies making common cause at a later date.\nThat Vietnam might become a US ally (and it de facto already is) is no more out of the ordinary than this. Countries form alliances based on what makes sense at a given time. In the case of Vietnam, it never wanted to be an enemy of the United States in the first place; that was a choice we made, by intervening in a civil war in that country on the side of the non-Communist faction. In fact, Vietnam, throughout its long history as a nation, has never desired anything but friendly relations with other countries. They simply want their own sovereignty respected.\nAt the present time, they (correctly) perceive China as a danger to their sovereignty, while the United States no longer has any interest in the internal affairs of Vietnam and sees that country as a trading partner and possible ally in what is now the most important part of the world, the Pacific Rim. Therefore, the geopolitical interests of both the USA and Vietnam, which were at odds with each other in the mid-20th century, now coincide.\nVietnam is an old and proud Nation which extends one hand to the world in friendship, but keeps its other hand on its dagger, lest it is attacked. sold?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "4", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "647": {"ans_list": ["To use the late Professor Brock Millman\u2019s classification of war aims. the UK\u2019s permanent war aims were no different in 1918 than in 1914: the restitution of Belgium as an independent state, the preservation of France as a great Power and the reduction in the German military threat to European peace. Failure to achieve these aims would have represented an actual defeat.\nAs the war progressed, Britain acquired new war aims, in particular those arising from the war against the Ottoman Empire and the capture of Germany's colonies. The wishes of the Dominions had to be taken into account: Britain itself had little interest in Samoa, South-West Africa or New Guinea, but the view from Cape Town, Wellington and Melbourne was different from that from London. By 1917 or so it wasn\u2019t possible to identify purely British war aims, which had become subsumed into consolidated Imperial war aims\nThe aims of Britain\u2019s allies had to be taken into account, though Britain wouldn\u2019t have fought another day for Alsace-Lorraine or for Italian control of Trieste.\nWith the exit of Russia and the entry of the USA into the war, ideological war aims became more prominent. and it became possible to represent the war as a conflict between democracies and absolutist states.\nThere were other conditional \u201cnice to have if available\u201d war aims, such was the destruction of the German High Seas Fleet, but that was never a primary British war aim.\nProf Millman\u2019s article in 1914\u201318 encyclopaedia is very good.\nWar Aims and War "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "753": {"ans_list": ["Ferdinand III.", "Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand III:\nThe Peace of Westphalia (German: Westf\u00e4lischer Friede) was a series of peace treaties signed between May and October 1648 in the Westphalian cities of Osnabr\u00fcck and M\u00fcnster, effectively ending the European wars of religion. These treaties ended the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) in the Holy Roman Empire, between the Habsburgs and their Catholic allies and the Protestant (Sweden, Denmark, Dutch, Holy Roman Principalities) and Catholic (France) Anti-Habsburg allies; and the Eighty Years' War (1568-1648) between Spain and the Dutch Republic, with Spain formally recognising the independence of the Dutch Republic.\nThe peace negotiations involved a total of 109 delegations representing European powers, including Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand III, Philip IV of Spain, the Kingdom of France, Cristina of the Swedish Empire, the Dutch Republic, the Princes of the Holy Roman Empire, and sovereigns of the free imperial cities. The treaties that constituted the peace settlement were:\nThe Peace of M\u00fcnster[1] between the Dutch Republic and the Kingdom of Spain on 30 January 1648, ratified in M\u00fcnster on 15 May 1648; and\nTwo complementary treaties both signed on 24 October 1648, namely:\nThe Treaty of M\u00fcnster (Instrumentum Pacis Monasteriensis, IPM),[2] between the Holy Roman Emperor, France, and their respective allies.\nThe Treaty of Osnabr\u00fcck (Instrumentum Pacis Osnabrugensis, IPO),[3] involving the Holy Roman Empire, Sweden, and their respective allies. The treaties did not restore peace throughout Europe, but they did create a basis for national self-determination.\nThe Peace of Westphalia established the precedent of peaces established by diplomatic congress,[4][5] and a new system of political order in central Europe, later called Westphalian sovereignty, based upon the concept of co-existing sovereign states. Inter-state aggression was to be held in check by a balance of power. A norm was established against interference in another state's domestic affairs. As European influence spread across the globe, these Westphalian principles, especially the concept of sovereign states, became central to international law and to the prevailing world order.[6]"], "topic_list": ["Thirty Years' War", "Holy Roman Empire", "Roman Emperors", "Historical Germany", "History of Europe", "Roman Empire", "World History", "Germany", "Military History and Wars", "History"], "view_list": [6, 17], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Blake Winfield", "upvote_list": [0, 2], "question_title": "Which Holy Roman Emperor signed the Peace of Westphalia that ended the Thirty Years\u2019 War (1618-1648)?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "621", "name_list": ["Bernd Geischer", "Anonymous"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "737": {"ans_list": ["No crowned monarch in British history has after they have been anointed ever abdicated. LBJ was following the same format that his mentor President FDR had taken to appoint the Roberts Commission, name after Supreme Court Justice Roberts, to pin all blame on the Hawaiian military commanders for being unprepared for the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.\nEarl Warren didn\u2019t want to serve, but President Johnson alleged that a nuclear exchange could happen, with the possible loss of 40 million American lives, should the assassination be determined to have ties to the Soviets or Cuba. Chief Supreme Court Justice Warren would write in his memoirs on page 367:\n\"Practically all the Cabinet members of President Kennedy's administration, along with Director J. Edgar Hoover of the FBI and Chief James Rowley of the Secret Service, whose duty it was to protect the life of the President, testified that to their knowledge there was no sign of any conspiracy. To say now that these people, as well as the Commission, suppressed, neglected to unearth, or overlooked evidence of a conspiracy would be an indictment of the entire government of the United States. It would mean the whole structure was absolutely corrupt from top to bottom, with not one person of high or low rank willing to come forward to expose the villany...\"\nPresident Johnson gave each member of the Warren Commission the same spiel about for the good of the country, Oswald must be seen that he would have been convicted as the lone assassin acting alone, thus saving the US from possible nuclear war.\nThe first Commission member to opening break ranks was Democratic House Speaker Hale Boggs. He was openly critical that the Warren Commission could only rely on the FBI\u2019s investigation. Boggs was quoted as saying, \"Hoover lied his eyes out to the Commission - on Oswald, on Ruby, on their friends, the bullets, the guns, you name it...\" Asked about the single bullet theory after the WCR came out, Boggs commented, \u201cI had strong doubts about it.\u201d On April 1, 1971 Boggs would deliver a blistering attack on Hoover saying the FBI under his directship had assumed \u201cthe tactics of the Soviet Union and the German Gestapo.\u201d\nHale Boggs would die in a plane crash in 1972 in Alaska, the wreckage never found. His wife would be elected to his US Representative seat from Louisiana. Mrs. Boggs would be quoted by Bernard Fensterwald, \u201cHale felt very, very torn during his work [on the Commission]\u2026he wished he had never been on it and had never signed it.\u201d\nDemocrat Kentucky Senator John Sherman Cooper also served on the Warren Commission. He called the WCR \u201cpremature and inconclusive.\u201d As a Kennedy friend, he expressed to RFK and Teddy that he didn\u2019t belive Oswald acted alone. When he later mentioned the same thing to Jackie, according to C. David Heymann, she responded: \"What difference does it make? Knowing who killed him won't bring Jack back.\" \"No, it won't,\" responded Cooper. \"But it's important for this nation that we bring the true murderers to justice.\"\nSenator Cooper signed off on the Single Bullet Theory but later negated this with this statement: \"On what basis is it claimed that two shots caused all the wounds?.....It seemed to me that Governor Connally's statement negates such a conclusion. I could not agree with this statement.\"\nGeorgia US Senator Richard Russell, and former Warren Commissioner:\n\"We have not been told the truth about Oswald.\"\nWith the WCR ready to go to the printer, Russell wanted to delay over the issue of the Single Bullet Theory. At a Sept. 18, 1964 meeting with LBJ, the Senator expressedhis doubts. \u201cThey were trying to prove that the same bullet that hit Kennedy first was the one that hit Connally, went through him and through his hand, his bone, into his leg and everything else. \u2026 The commission believes that the same bullet that hit Kennedy hit Connally. Well, I don\u2019t believe it.\u201d Johnson, not to coause a disagreement replied, \u201cI don\u2019t either.\u201d This was the meeting that Cooper stated, \u201cit seems to me that Governor Connally\u2019s statement negates such a conclusion.\u201d\nUS Pennsylvania Richard Schweiker, and former Church Committee member looking into the JFK assassination, stated on \u201cFace the Nation\u201d June 27, 1976\n\"I think the [Warren] report, to those who have studied it closely, has collapsed like a house of cards.....the fatal mistake the Warren Commission made was not to use its own investigators, but instead to rely on the CIA and FBI personnel, which played directly into the hands of senior intelligence officials who directed the cover-up.\"\nKen O'Donnell, former Special Assistant to JFK, quoted by former Speaker of the House Thomas \u201cTip\u201d O\u2019Neill in \u201cMan of the House,\u201d -\n\"I told the FBI what I had heard [two shots from behind the grassy knoll fence], but they said it couldn't have happened that way and that I must have been imagining things. So I testified the way they wanted me to. I just didn't want to stir up any more pain and trouble for the family.\"\nO'Donnell was riding in the Secret Service follow-up car with Dave Powers, who was present and told O'Neill he had the same recollection.\nFinally, President Johnson said to TV Reporter Howard K. So France is the country.\nFootnotes\n[1] How the License Plate Was Introduced", "France was the first country in the world to make license plates mandatory on vehicles. This was in 1893.\nLicence plates have been around for longer than there have been automobiles. France was the first country to introduce the licence plate with the passage of the Paris Police Ordinance on August 14, 1893, followed by Germany in 1896. The Netherlands was the first country to introduce a national licence plate, called a \"driving permit\", in 1898. The first licences were plates with a number, starting at 1. By August 8, 1899 the counter was at 168. When the Netherlands chose a different way to number the plates on January 15, 1906 the last issued plate was 2001.\nIn the U.S., where each state issues plates, New York State has required plates since 1901. At first, plates were not government issued in most jurisdictions and motorists were obliged to make their own. In 1903, Massachusetts was the first state to issue plates. The first license plates in North America appeared in 1903 in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Soon after, other states followed suit, with virtually every state having adopted a form of license plates by 1918."], "topic_list": ["License Plates", "License Plates in the United States of Beyond any rational question the USA made very serous peace offers to the USSR to try to avert hostilities. These were rebuffed \u2014 for no legitimate reason.\nAlfred Montestruc's answer to How did the Cold War start? What did the Soviets do, and what did the US do?", "Ideological differences played an important but not exclusive role. Given that neither the US nor Britain understood World War II\u2019s devastating impact on the Soviet Union, its people, and its government, they would have feared the Soviet advance into Central Europe even without any ideological differences. The Soviet-backed coup in Czechoslovakia increased their fears. That coup had both ideological and power politics components. Any Soviet or Russian government of any ideology coming out of a devastating war like World War II would have demanded and obtained a sphere of influence with high domination over Eastern and Central European areas likely to serve as staging areas for another attack and another war. The US and Britain could have opposed this domination on national interest grounds. But these grounds would not have persuasive to their peoples. Most Americans care little or nothing about Eastern and even Central Europe. Most Britons cared something about these areas, but the war had been devastating to them, too. Neither Americans nor Britons were looking for another war. But the British and American political and economic elites concluded that only an ideological threat could convince Americans and Britons to accept another conflict so soon after World War II. These elites felt the Soviet threat themselves far more than their peoples. These elites felt the Communist ideological threat far more than their peoples. So, in launching the Cold War and keeping it going, ideology was crucial. At first, this use of ideology was successful. But in the 1960s, it no longer worked.\nA similar analysis applies to the Soviet Union and its people. The Soviet people were not interested in another conflict so soon after devastating World War II. Power politics alone would never persuade them to support another conflict. Power politics alone would persuade them to tolerate it like they tolerated everything else about the Soviet dictatorship. So, to generate popular enthusiasm for the Cold War, the Soviet regime had to use both Communist ideology and conversion of Britain and America from allies to threats. At first, this use of ideology was successful. But in the 1960s, it no longer worked.\nIn the 1960s, a new generation (mine) began coming of age. The old ideological conflicts and old national power rivalries moved us much less. The counterculture, the Beetles, and peace moved us much more. On both sides of the Iron Curtain, that was true.\nHoward Lederman", "I disagree. Both were Capitalist states creating sphere\u2019s of influence. Your description of Kierkegaard\u2019s thought is the antithesis to \u201cleveling\u201d which is what you are looking to understand. Put simply, this area of thought (which may be too generous) is recognized by modern philosophers to be the acid which destroys and accelerates the destruction of culture and elevates materialism which eviscerates the value of Man.\nTo provide a simple and well-known example, George Orwell described the man of the future as devoid of any unique aspects which make us human, namely, subjectivity. The dictatorial political system seeks to level everyone. No one has more, no one reads books, no one goes to places alone, etc. And, the thought police who would arrest people for having private thoughts and the massive television in every home that could not only transmit the constant oratory of the Leader but allowed the Government to constantly watch its citizens.) The fear of having individual thought which provides us with our goals of self-knowledge also allows man to exercise free thought. There is a great danger here, in my opinion, since the naming of ever more narrow areas of thought (and Science) is not only obfuscating and confusing but seems to be a way for certain unexceptional thinkers to stamp their thought with an imprimatur of validity. Thus, we know more and more about less and less. One should remember that the thought of the greatest philosophers never fit into a little box with a bow\u2014\nI am not seeking praise or arrogantly attempting to secure adulation but only to distinguish myself enough to support the comments I made above regarding philosophers who concern themselves with \u201cleveling\u201d (unless of course the study of leveling is done to criticize and undermine its validity). I believe that to give some substance for my sharp opinions about this issue, (which I do not enjoy criticizing) I may permissibly refer to my educational background (which in any case is easily found linked to my name and on my home page). I hold (1) a Philosophy Degree in Modern Philosophy, granted with honors based on my thesis on the modern misunderstanding of Nietzsche; (2) a Masters Degree in Modern European Philosophy, focused on the Modern philosophers who inherited the world foreseen and predicted by Nietzsche, and who all attempted to respond to the problems, issues and catastrophe recognized by Nietzsche, and all of whom failed in their own way; (3) during my Masters study in Modern European Philosophy, I went to and graduated from Law School; (4) studied Ancient Philosophy including the pre-Socratics, Plato and Aristotle, in Ancient Greek for two years; (5) was a Masters assistant to the Chairman of the Philosophy department at University; and (6) studied at Harvard and Columbia University concerning the source and analysis of the modern influence of pragmatism, materialism and science on man\u2019s sense of despair. Based on this, and recognizing that piling up degrees is no substitute for intuition or wisdom, I believe that I can assay that Kierkegaard\u2019s thought was written in repudiation of \u201cmass man,\u201d he was the philosopher who stated that a mob is the definition of untruth. Thus, I believe that the issue you raise of \u201cleveling,\u201d which has been a constant destruction of the value of a public or even college education for 50 years, since this leveling reduces the level of education to the lowest common denominator, lowering the level of dialogue and study of all thought to the most uneducated, as an example, is emphatically opposed to the highly destructive and irrelevant type of thought embodied in the study of this theme.\nIn \u201cLeveling down,\u201d as some describe materialism or the destruction of man, and with the caveat that this appellation is unknown to me and I do not know any modern or any other philosopher who adopted this concept as something valuable, I will simply say that my understanding of it, and by answering this question, which I originally thought not important enough to answer, I do not wish to lend to this \u201cPhilosophy\u201d if philosophy it is, is the destruction or exclusion of unique man from a philosophy of man, the eradication of the individual, the unique, and the subjective nature of man. Realizing oneself is only possible by realizing oneself through free choice between meaningful choices, and achieving self-commitment.\nTo exist therefore, according to Kierkegaard, means becoming and distinguishing oneself insofar as he is unique\u2014because the only real man is unique and he is less and less a member of a group."], "topic_list": ["S\u00f8ren Kierkegaard (philosopher, author)", "Epistemology", "Philosophy of Mind", "Metaphysics", "Philosophers", "Concepts", "The Mind", "Philosophy", "History"], "view_list": [42], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Dex Jackson", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "Are there any predecessors to the leveling concept of Kierkegaard (metaphysics, philosophy of mind, history of philosophy, philosophy)?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "158", "name_list": ["David H. The Syrians coordinated their attack on the Golan Heights to coincide with the Egyptian offensive and initially made threatening gains into Israeli-held territory. Within three days, however, Israeli forces had pushed the Syrians back to the pre-war ceasefire lines. The Israel defense forces (IDF) then launched a four-day counter-offensive deep into Syria. Within a week, Israeli artillery began to shell the outskirts of Damascus, and Egyptian President Sadat began to worry about the integrity of his major ally. He believed that capturing two strategic passes located deeper in the Sinai would make his position stronger during post-war negotiations; he, therefore, ordered the Egyptians to go back on the offensive, but their attack was quickly repulsed. The Israelis then counter-attacked at the seam between the two Egyptian armies, crossed the Suez Canal into Egypt, and began slowly advancing southward and westward towards the city of Suez in over a week of heavy fighting that resulted in heavy casualties on both sides", "The \u201cblitzkrieg\u201dtactic term was never in fact used or codified by the germans, but by the press.Essentially, it involved longstanding german concepts of initiative, combined arms, concentration of force,\u201ddecisive battle and quick outcomes brought forward to the mid-20th Century in the use of the radio, tank, and plane.Its not a \u201ctactic\u201d per se.", "Blitzkeig in practise meant deep penetration to the heart of enemy defenses using tanks and aircraft without worrying about enemy forces left behind..\nThe crossing of the canal in a narrow front by israeli forces to destroy the sam missile defences and attack the egytians from the rear has elements of blitzkeig. It involved either one or two separate confrontations involving North Vietnam\nand the United States in the waters of the Gulf of Tonkin\n. The original American report blamed North Vietnam for both incidents, but eventually became very controversial with widespread claims that either one or both incidents were false\n, and possibly deliberately so. The original US claim was that on August 2, 1964, the destroyer\nUSS\nMaddox\n, while performing a signals intelligence\npatrol as part of DESOTO\noperations, was pursued by three North Vietnamese Navy torpedo boats of the 135th Torpedo Squadron.[2]\n[3]\nMaddox fired three warning shots and the North Vietnamese boats then attacked with torpedoes and machine gun fire.[3]\nMaddox expended over 280 3-inch and 5-inch shells in what was claimed to be a sea battle\n. One U.S. aircraft was damaged, three North Vietnamese torpedo boats\nwere allegedly damaged, and four North Vietnamese sailors were said to have been killed, with six more wounded. There were no U.S. casualties.[4]\nMaddox \"was unscathed except for a single bullet hole from a Vietnamese machine gun round\".[3]\nIt was originally claimed by the National Security Agency\nthat a Second Gulf of Tonkin incident occurred on August 4, 1964, as another sea battle, but instead evidence was found of \"Tonkin ghosts\"[5]\n(false radar images) and not actual North Vietnamese torpedo boats. In the 2003 documentary The Fog of War\n, the former United States Secretary of Defense\nRobert S. McNamara\nadmitted that the August 2 USS Maddox attack happened with no Defense Department\nresponse, but the August 4 Gulf of Tonkin attack never happened.[6]\nIn 1995, former Secretary of Defense McNamara\nmet with former Vietnam People's Army\nGeneral V\u00f5 Nguy\u00ean Gi\u00e1p\nto ask what happened on August 4, 1964 in the second Gulf of Tonkin Incident. \"Absolutely nothing\", Gi\u00e1p replied.[7]\nGi\u00e1p claimed that the attack had been imaginary.[8]\nBe careful about laughing at conspiracy theories.", "This answer was posted by me on another forum\nThe involvement was based on a theory called the domino effect.\nIn the years after World War 2, the west had already seen the Soviets bring all of Eastern Europe and North Korea under communists rule. The fear was that communist parties in Italy and Greece would further extend Soviet creeping influence in Europe.\nThat is why the USA gave billions in Marshall Plan aid, to help a war weakened Europe rebuild, be less prone to left wing revolutions, and, of course, return to strong market economies that would be markets for American exports.\nIn 1948 Stalin attempted to blockade Berlin and force the western powers out. Then to America's great shock, the whole of China fell to the commies in 1949. Then in 1950 North Korea invaded the south and the US and its allies had to go to war to prevent the whole of Korea falling to the communist block. Communism was spreading and the fear was that once a country fell to communism, nearby countries would be at risk of falling over, and communism would spread further, knocking over pro western regimes like a line of dominoes.\nNow to Vietnam. France was already struggling with a communists and nationalist movement in Vietnam in the 1950s, and Britain was fighting an insurgency in Malaysia. The 2 countries had different outcomes. The French were defeated, leaving North Vietnam in the Soviet sphere, while in Malaysia, the British managed to isolate the Communists (who were mainly ethnic Chinese) from the Malay majority, ensuing that the insurgency did not get enough popularity to take hold.\nBut communism was still spreading, and in 1959 Cuba fell to Castro, the reds were now on Americas doorstep. In the 50s and sixties, Soviet allied movements spread to central Africa and many regimes in the Middle East were falling under a left wing socialist Arab nationalist movement.\nSo you can see why US foreign policy really feared this Domino effect, it seems at the time that communism had an unstoppable momentum, and at this rate more and more states would fall.\nSo the response was called containment. The US couldn't roll back communism without the risk of setting off a third world war, if the Soviets intervened. The best bet was to stop all future communist expansion, before things got out of hand. So with North Vietnam threatening the South, as well as Laos, Cambodia and the whole region, the stage was set. It was this far and no further.\nWith the French out and South Vietnam's own government increasingly unpopular and weak, America found itself ever more committed to keeping the South in the western sphere, first with advisors and material aid and then with ever increasing amounts of boots on the ground.\nThis containment happened elsewhere as well, but not at such a cost. The US isolated Cuba, shored up anti communists in Central and South America, and shored up its forces guarding Europe, Japan and Korea.\nWe of course know that the massive US involvement in Vietnam was never going to be enough. All the firepower, and the men were not enough. The Southern government was just too unpopular and corrupt to galvanise enough solid indigenous support to combat the more popular left wing insurgency.\nBut the dominoes didn't always fall elsewhere, communism was largely contained. German diplomats didn\u2019t have to risk flying across combat zones to parlay with foreign governments and foreign governments didn\u2019t have to risk their lives as residents in Germany, which was being bombed. Lisbon in neutral Portugal was also a diplomatic meeting place.\nSwitzerland was also believe it or not a sought after holiday location for the mainly German elite wanting to enjoy some R&R in safety during the war.", "Contrary to popular historical myth the defeat of Switzerland would not have been difficult to achieve and the French in the Second World War, at least, feared that the Germans might go through Switzerland or Belgium or both.\nThe Germans themselves when they drew up Tannenbaum assumed they could defeat the Swiss with a handful of divisions in two weeks or less. This does not suggest that the Germans were afraid of the Swiss, or unsure if they could win. On the contrary they were so confident that they concluded they could beat the Swiss right away without even trying.\nBut Switzerland provided little worth taking, being a small state of little industry. Communications to Italy were guaranteed by the St. Gotthard Tunnel and a treaty signed by Germany in 1909 providing for its use in war. But Italy\u2019s defection rendered this redundant anyway.\nIn both wars Germany also already had use of the Brenner, which was a superior means of communication over the Alps.\nThe only advantage Switzerland provided was that it allowed the Germans to outflank the French defences along the Rhine, Vosges, and west of the Vosges.\nPossibly Switzerland might have been used, I believe Schlieffen briefly considered it.\nBut Belgium was chosen instead because it was much more advantageous. It provided an easier path to the enemy, was much closer to the hub of German industry and railway network in the Ruhr and Lower Rhine, which made logistics much easier, Belgium was herself very industrialised and so could provide much of use to Germany\u2019s war effort, and since Belgium had a coastline and was close to the UK, she could be used as a base for naval and air attacks on the United Kingdom.\nNone of this would have been true of Switzerland, so if Germany had to outflank the French on the north or south it was going to be the north every time.\nAnd if Germany had to communicate with Italy via the Brenner, which it already held, or via the St. Gotthard, it was going to be the Brenner every time.", "Because Belgium was enroute to Paris.", "Flanders was always the preferred invasion route to France (you know, the Spanish, the English, the Germans) since it\u2019s flat terrain, not far from Paris, and it\u2019s a rich and industrial region.\nThe strategic problem with France is that both its large industrial basins (Lorraine and Nord) are close to the German border.\nIn contrast, Switzerland is close to nothing important in France, has a more rugged terrain and a larger army.", "Belgium was on the way towards France, Germany was forced to attack after Belgium denied Germany troop access. Swiss however had a purpose, it functioned like it does today as a giant safe for all parties involved and also like a giant black market. A huge amount of shady transaction were brokered through swiss. Imagine forr example the amount of art that germans captured..if you can, much opf it ended elsewere. How? You guessed, through the neutral ground on Switzerland :). It might be worthy to add that the terrain in that country is terrible to conquer and ideal for defense.", "Swiss neutrality was a natural evolving out of its geography. After the changes in this constructing mainly by German Aggression (bad diplomacy) in late 19th, Germany did their Ultimatum to \u201cmarch thru\u201d as Part of \u201cSchlieffen-Plan\u201d what Belgium rejected and declared war when Germans invaded, this brought the British Expeditionary Force (World War I) - Wikipedia\nto land in northern France and Flandres (Belgium) mainly to restore the Belgium neutrality (observant).", "Probably Altitude and Terrain, apart from that a significant portion of the [population spoke German, and once they had occupied France, and with fellow Fascists in Italy, why bother climbing up into the sky with motors that may not work at the altitude? Germany is a small country with limited resources within its own borders. Many of its natural materials came from lands captured during the war. Obviously, the U.S. entered the war in late \u201841, so we\u2019re fighting an imaginary war with a country that wasnt yet in the war? It really makes no sense. But let's move it to 1942 to 1945, which is the same amount of time. This gives a better point of comparison.\nGermany would win in the first few months, then the U.S. would have taken it from there, as actually happened with the Pacific war with Japan. The U.S. wasn\u2019t prepared for war whereas Germany had been preparing for a decade, so that would give them an early advantage. However, as we saw in Russia, the Germans had no capability to carry on an extended war, and an inneffective supply chain that still heavily depended on horse and oxen. As a result, they were ground to a halt and surrounded by the Russians at the battles of Stalingrad and Leningrad.\nI\u2019m afraid the war could have been won by the rules of resources, supply and production. The U.S. had a compartively limitless amount of natural resources, triple the manufacturing capability, triple the shipping capacity and double the population. Also, the Germans had not developed any truly effective aerial bombing capability. They couldnt even bring nearby Britain to its knees with their bombing campaign prior to U.S. entry into the war. The vast distances between cities and bases in the U.S. and overseas bases means that it had an almost innate advantage in the capability to project power across distances. The air war would have stifled Germany's material production capacity. -As it actually did.\nBut the U.S.\u2019s ace in the hole was the ineffective German command structure. The Germans had masterful Generals like Erwin Rommel, and Erich Von Manstein, who was arguably the best General in the war, but they were constantly being stifled by rivalries between factions, branches and divisions, and overruled by leaders such as Goering, who would probably be an acceptable commander for the German Luftwaffe, but was a sometimes inneffectual drug addict, and woefully unqualified to coordinate the effective use of the entire Wehrmacht.\nAnd as the German High Command tended to allow moslty downward flow of military command and control, many German field commanders became extraordinarily frustrated with missed opportunities and losses that didnt need to happen. Then there was the best ally the Allies ever had. - Hitler. He had a stranglehold on the control of military decisions, despite the fact that his sole military experience (in WW1) was as an infantryman and message runner. His mismanagement of resources, and lack of strategic and tactical knowledge could easily be described as being a major factor in Germany's loss. For example, many historians believe that if Rommel had full control of defensive resources deployed in France during the D-Day invasion, the Allies could have been halted at or driven back to the beaches where they landed. Hitler disagreed with Rommel's idea of keeping the Panzer divisions near the Normandy coast; instead deploying them nearer to Paris. Hitler often chose his leadership based on gut feelings, not by education and experience. For example, he selected Albert Speer, a young architect, to basically coordinate and maintain the entire German infrastructure, even though he had no experience. His reasons? - Because he'd developed a personal relationship with Speer when he was assisting Hitler to design the Reich Chancellory. Hitler too often ignored experienced individuals for leadership positions in favor or those with whom he enjoyed socializing.\nSome may argue that \u2018The Germans were figjting a two-front war,\u2019 You just won my argument for me. If he had not attacked the Soviet Union, he could have concentrated their efforts on Britain, France and the U.S. The German High Command was very fond of shooting itself in the foot. Another example of this was that the U.S. was actively seeking atomic weapons, whereas Hitler had relegated those efforts to a sideshow for Germany. Those weapons could likely have been the trump card in any total war. Although their use against Germany would have been in doubt because U.S. war planners feared the Germans could back-engineer the weapons much more quickly than the Japanese if the bomb hadn't detonated.\nSo, no, Nazi Germany would have stood little chance against the U.S. in such a war. Both my mother and father were of noble families from Poland. Up till World War Two Poland was run by noble families for well over 1000 years. What does this mean and how did it work? Nobility in Poland was earned by service to the people of Poland. This usually meant selfless sacrifice for the Nation, usually in times of war. Poland was at war often, invasions coming from all sides. Having people willing and able to protect the Nation was critical for everyone's security. Nobles of Poland had to train and equip themselves, at their own cost, from youth till elder years. All, from children up, had to be capable. At age seven, boys went into training. They had to respond at moment\u2019s notice. When men went to war, women took over running estates. Nobles had to be educated to be capable of organizing and running estates which fed and cared for everyone around. They would gather periodically to vote on national policies and to elect a King. Later, when Poland had a regular army, they served in the army. They also served the church. Poland had two cultures, one was the nobility, the other was peasants. One was not better than the other, each fiercely proud and independent and coexisted in harmony. Eventually a middle class emerged - burgers, which ran shops.
