If it is the latter, this answer is better. If it is about dating methods, please read on.\nThere are several dating methods, each with its limitations. Carbon dating, which is a radiometric dating using radioactive decay from to , is useful for dating evidence as long as it is not older than some 40,000 years.\nBut the key thing is context. If you find a dead cat, all you can say that it is a cat and it is dead. But what if you found the dead cat on the road? Or on the chopping block in a kitchen? Context is the difference between someone\u2019s lunch and a roadkill.\nIn archaeology, context is really important. If we find a skeleton below the foundation of a house, we know that the skeleton is older than the house, which in turn gives us a minimum age. Bones in an iron age midden can be associated with that period. Dendrodating uses tree rings to date when a piece of wood would have been felled at the earliest. Cultural artefacts, like pottery or jewelry, can also be used to date the context of the bones. Funeral practices are an important clue. So it is not as much the bones themselves that gives us a date, but the context.\nIf it is older than that, we\u2019re leaving historical and archaeological settings, and instead we go into palaeontology. Then there are other tools in the toolbox, but it\u2019s still about context. There\u2019s still radiometric dating, but instead of carbon dating, they use other radiometric clocks. Uranium-lead is one, used for volcanic rocks. Uranium-thorium is another, used for sedimentary rocks. Potassium-argon is useful for dating feldspar, etc.\nNote that I am talking rock layers here: the fossils themselves are hard to date on their own, and certainly not through carbon dating, since there is hardly any carbon left and it is way beyond the resolution of carbon dating. So we look at the context: in which rock layer is if found, and in what order in that rock layer.\nYou don\u2019t necessarily have to do that for every fossil you found \u2013 often, it is already done for rock layers, so just finding the bones in a particular layer will automatically date it.", "Probably the most used method is carbon dating. All these methods make assumptions so often are wildly inaccurate. You may find this information interesting:\nCarbon dating-who is fooling whom?", "Paleontologists have made extensive studies of early animals and if the bone piece is big enough they can identify what type of bone and the animal it is likely to come from.\nMost finds are quite small so the field workers will evacuate the area surrounding the first find in order to attempt to gather other relevant pieces. With enough pieces the scientists try to put the bones together, rather like a difficult jigsaw, and see if this helps with identification. There are now many databases that they can use which is helpful. Easy communication through the internet allows scientists from other countries to collaborate.\nStudies are being carried out to improve the use of DNA in studies of archaelogical finds. Because the DNA is so degraded, this kind of study is in its early stages."], "topic_list": ["Jawbone (company)", "Skeletons", "Human Skeletons", "Archaeology", "Bones", "Human Body", "Science", "History"], "view_list": [1, 106, 1, 3], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Blake Winfield", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 0, 0], "question_title": "What are the methods used by scientists to identify a skeleton or a jawbone, etc., that it is thousands of years old?", "respond_collected": 4, "no_of_view": "172", "name_list": ["James L Cameron", "Krister Sundelin", "Alistair Welch", "Anonymous"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "218": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Empires", "World History", "The Human Race and Condition", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "Alejandra Bernu\u00e9s Borau", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Which ones are the most interesting facts about the human empire and why is that?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "63", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "646": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Modern Times", "Heads of State", "Successful People", "Prime Ministers", "Politicians and Government Officials of India", "Politicians and Government Leaders", "Government", "Politics of India", "Politics", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Ayush Das", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Who has been the most successful politician in modern times, outside of heads of state?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "159", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "741": {"ans_list": ["Let\u2019s be certain that the term \u201ccost\u201d can be measured in terms other than money. In classical times, although patriarchal, Sparta retained the basic form of matriarchal organisation. The Spartans retained the original matriarchal \u2018gens\u2019 \u2013 although the two \u2018gens\u2019 had been subdivided \u2013 although the two matriarchs were replaced by two \u2018kings\u2019 ruling side by side.\nAlso despite male domination the \u2018gens\u2019 were still matrilineal, the man marrying into his wife\u2019s \u2018gens\u2019 and leaving his own. The king held office by virtue of matrilineal right and not patrilineal descent. Also the requirement of physical perfection the kings reflected the old requirements of physical perfection in the King-consort of matriarchal times. (See also High King of Ireland)\nIn Sparta there were fewer slaves than in Athens in proportion to the free population and nor were slaves alienable \u2013 bought and sold \u2013 as they were in Athens and were permanently attached to a family. The position of women was vastly different in Sparta, there being no laws governing or concerned with virginity or restrictions generally on women\u2019s sexuality which were introduced into Athens in the oligarchic period.\nWomen were also trained to fight like the boys and Sparta was unique in expecting its women to be as athletic as the men, the only women\u2019s games held in Greece were held in Sparta.\nMost of our understanding of classical Greece is understood through nineteenth and twentieth century bourgeois historians. Athens was far more like bourgeois society than Sparta and even today Athens is held to be the \u2018birthplace\u2019 of (bourgeois) democracy. While Sparta\u2019s retention of \u2018communistic\u2019 forms was held up to restrictive, oppressive and austere (Spartan has entered the language as meaning \u2018austere) In actual fact despite the dynamism of its thinkers and artists and so on\nAthens was an extremely oppressive society ruthlessly exploiting its massive slave population \u2013 presumably the bourgeois exploiters of the nineteenth century and the present day science and philosophy built on slave economy see nothing to remark upon in this as such exploitation and degradation of women is a high ideal and perfectly \u2018natural\u2019 to them.", "In what way? I do not know of any\u2026\u2026", "Many people, particularly young men, have obtained whatever opinions they have about ancient Sparta from the movie 300 - which is about the 300 Spartan warriors led by King Leonidas who defended the pass of Thermopylae in 480 BCE during the Greco-Persian Wars.\nBeyond the obvious fact that the actual Spartans did not fight wearing black leather briefs and capes, there is also a total absence of homosexual relationships in the film. In fact, homosexual relationships were the norm among Spartan warriors who generally lived together in barracks and who were allowed to marry women but had to conceal their marital relations from their fellows by only meeting their wives at night.\nTherefore the common misconception that Spartan warriors were the epitome of masculinity and completely heterosexual is completely false.", "That Sparta was some sort of proto-fascist state filled with illiterate brutes who spent all their time brutally abusing their own children before going off to war every day while their wives were a bunch of lesbians. The misconceptions about Sparta are so egregious, widespread and ridiculous no one historian can ever address them all.\nImages of a society characterized by brutal, mindless discipline and a merciless emphasis on physical fitness, but lacking artistic and intellectual accomplishments \u2013 or even basic literacy \u2013 predominate in popular literature. In fact, ancient Sparta \u2013 or Lacedaemon, as it was known in ancient Greece \u2013 was far more complex and multifaceted. Plutarch claims that \"devotion to the intellect is more characteristic of Sparta than love of physical exercise.\" Lindsay Wheeler calls the Spartans warrior philosophers.\nIn the ancient world Sparta was admired as much for its constitution, its system of education, its philosophical culture, its economic self-sufficiency, its diplomacy, and its music and dance as it was for its famous hoplites. Not her kings, but her citizens \u2013 the lawgiver Lycurgus, the philosopher Chilon, and the poet Tyrtaios \u2013 were the most widely admired Spartans in ancient times.\nBelow is a summary of some key facts:\nSparta was the first democracy in recorded history, predating Athenian democracy by at least 50 and possibly 100 years. Furthermore, Sparta was the only Greek city-state to introduce land reform aimed at equalizing wealth among its citizens.\nThe Spartan public educational system, the agoge, trained the mind as well as the body, and Spartans were not only literate, but admired for their intellectual culture and verbal skills. Socrates himself says \"the most ancient and fertile homes of philosophy among the Greeks are Crete and Sparta, where are found more sophists than anywhere on earth.\" (Plato, Protagoras, 343b:366.) Certainly, Spartan wit and mastery of rhetoric were so widely admired that ancient Greek scholars collected Spartan sayings, and the laconic style of speech was studied and imitated in intellectual circles.\nSparta was the capital city of the large, prosperous, and economically powerful city-state of Lacedaemon. The economy of Lacedaemon was diverse, based on a wealth of natural resources and abundant fertile land. While trading in luxury goods, self-sufficiency in grain gave Sparta a significant political advantage.\nSparta was the only Greek city-state in which women enjoyed elementary rights such as the right to education, inheritance, and property. Furthermore, Spartan women prided themselves on their intellectual accomplishments, possessed economic power, and were not afraid to express their opinions \u2013 leading other Greeks to condemn them as undisciplined, dangerous, and immoral.\nThe high status of women is the best refutation of persistent allegations that Spartan society institutionalized pederasty; modern psychology has demonstrated that the victims of pederasty usually grow up to be misogynous men. There is no convincing contemporary evidence that homosexuality was more common in Sparta than elsewhere in ancient Greece.\nSparta was the first Greek city-state to develop a complex system of mutual defense treaties, and it repeatedly intervened to defend democracy against tyranny. Spartan diplomacy was arguably even more effective than Spartan arms in maintaining Sparta's status for centuries.\nAlthough Spartans were proud to say that they built their monuments \"in flesh\" \u2013 meaning that the virtue and courage of Sparta's citizens were the greatest monuments to the city-state \u2013 they were not lacking in architectural and artistic achievements. The ancient Greek tour guide, Pausanias, cataloged hundreds of sites worth seeing. Nor was Sparta itself a collection of rural villages, as Athenian detractors depicted it, but rather a prosperous capital city with broad, tree-lined avenues, temples, monuments, public buildings, and royal palaces.\nSpartan music and dance were famous throughout the ancient world, and the oldest recorded heterosexual love poem was the work of a Spartan poet praising Spartan maidens.\nFor more about Sparta visit: http://spartareconsidered.blogspot.com", "That they were some war-obsessed maniacs. Many people base their view and understanding relying on the shallow misrepresentations of our culture of brain-dead entertainment. Mainly Hollywood.\nThe ultimate and unique goals of a Spartan were freedom (physically and in mind) and to be a virtuous human being (living and dying honorably while defending the homeland).\nIn Plutarch's biography of Lycurgus, one can get an inside look into the lives and mentality of the ancient Spartans. History is to be studied if one is to formulate an informed opinion, not movies that are purely for entertainment, not education.", "The biggest misconception about Spartans or Dorians in general extending to Macedonians was calling them Barbarians, that by Ionian Athenians at times of competition, like ruffian warriors, Greek of course but still that wasn\u2019t the case.\nAs a Dorian I know from family tradition that Spartans were very sensitive, same as Macedonians alike that killed their enemies only because they didn\u2019t want them to suffer in captivity as they believed that one must live as a free man or die as one, having to come into such known to them beforehand terms when they failed against the Dorians."], "topic_list": ["Myths and Misconceptions", "Ancient Spartans", "Ancient Sparta", "History of Greece", "Common Misconceptions", "Myths, Legends and Untruths", "Ancient Greece", "Ancient Civilizations", "Ancient History", "History"], "view_list": [94, 58, 146, 0, 124, 121], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 3, "question_author": "Peyton DiGregory", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 0, 2, 0], "question_title": "What are the biggest misconceptions about ancient Sparta?", "respond_collected": 6, "no_of_view": "4,954", "name_list": ["Rinaldo Frezzato", "Panos Demos", "Mark H. {"ans_list": ["Both Mike and Tom give good answers to this question that is worded like, \u201ccould \u2014- happen if \u2014\u2014- happened? This has been around a long time, it is sort of like saying could frogs not hit their bottoms so often if they had wings? The idea was after US got it\u2019s bottom handed to us by Russia with Sputnik, we (US, von Braun, Kennedy, etc.) decided we would go to the moon and we did! We were the first! Case closed! So there are a lot of examples where you can second guess situations in the past if you have new data, this isn\u2019t a good place to do it!", "No", "I agree with the essence of the other answers, and add an anecdote to illustrate part of the problem.\nDuring my career I was fortunate enough to know and work with many Russian/Soviet space system designers. All of them were very bright and extremely hard working. But they had to work with the technology, budget, and other limitations of their country and its place in the world.\nIn 1998, I accompanied 7 or 8 senior Russian cosmonauts and designers to the grand opening of the Saturn V center at the Kennedy Space Center. I was the deputy director of the Shuttle-Mir/Phase 1 Program that flew 7 Americans on the Mir, and these gentlemen were at KSC for the launch of STS 89. The grand opening happened to coincide with the launch.\nI was responsible for keeping an eye on our Russian guests, but by this point in the program they were pretty comfortable getting around on their own. So once I knew they were in the facility I went off and visited with Gene Cernan and others.\nToward the end of the evening, I joined the Russians as they stood under the engine bells of the first stage. The senior Russian in the group was Valeri Ryumin, the Russian Mir program manager. Although his emotions were well lubricated with alcohol, that incredibly tough cosmonaut (who was a tank commander in the Russian army before joining their space program) was in tears admiring the Saturn and wishing that his country had been able to build its equivalent. It was the only time I ever saw him admire our hardware. Despite flying on STS 91, he was no fan of the Shuttle.", "No. Their moon program didn't have enough funding, and Soviet manufacturing wasn't up to the job.", "Korolev was a brilliant engineer, and an immensely capable designer. He is, rightly so, listed among the greats of the 20th Century in helping Mankind reach outer space.\nBut, there was never really any chance that the Soviets would get to the Moon sooner than the United States\u2014barring some sort of catastrophe at Cape Kennedy.\nHere\u2019s a link to a discussion of the N-1 rocket the Soviets intended to take their cosmonauts to the Moon.\nN1 (rocket) - Wikipedia\nLook at the first stage engines. There are thirty (30) of them. This is the crucial engineering limitation of Soviet rocket design. They were unable to manufacture the huge engines the United States used for its Saturn V launch vehicle. Having to create a pumping system that would provide identical fuel supplies to 30 engines simultaneously during the critical lift off phase was simply not possible. So, the N1 failed again and again.\nWithout this heavy lift capacity, no cosmonaut was going to the Moon.\nSoviet booster design was robust, but all too often relied upon multiple boosters strapped together to push large payloads into orbit. All well and good, until you want to boost a large load to escape velocity, and plan to land part of that payload on another celestial body.\nTaking nothing away from Korolev, he was just the victim of a country that had aspirations of reaching the stars, but limited technology to get them there.", "Would the Soviets reach the Moon first had not the chief Soviet engineer Sergei Korolev died so early?\nNo, Korolev\u2019s death was a secondary factor. The Soviet problem was that they really didn\u2019t join the race to the moon until 1965, when Khrushchev (not a fan of space exploration) was ousted from power and the USSR finally diverted some effort to a moon mission. (Prior to that, most USSR rocket construction and development work went to the military. The USSR\u2019s incredible space achievements prior to Apollo were basically done with scraps pried away from the Soviet military.)\nFor a Russian assessment of what the Soviets did wrong, I\u2019d recommend this lengthy article summarizing their missteps and lack of commitment: Why did the Soviet Union lose the Moon Race?\nMeanwhile, before 1965, the US ran multiple programs to get to the moon:\nIt ran the Project Mercury\nto figure out the basics of crewed space flight\nIt ran the Project Gemini to master tasks required for Apollo to succeed\n, including orbital interception and docking, orbital maneuvering, and spacewalking\nThe Ranger program\n, Surveyor program\n, and Lunar Orbiter program\nwere dedicated to mapping and learning about the moon to figure out how and where humans could land on it. The Pearly Pioneeer probes\nalso provided some support.\nIt started development of Apollo hardware\nin parallel to Mercury and Gemini\nAnd before Apollo or NASA existed, the USAF and DoD had already started developing some of the rocket engines used in the program. Mercury and Gemini flew on rockets developed in the 1950s to blow up the \u201cgodless commie hordes\u201d (Redstone, Atlas, and Titan rockets), and the Saturn V used engines (the mighty Rocketdyne F-1\n) that started development in 1955.\nThe Rooskies didn\u2019t start developing the N-1 rocket until 1965\n, by which time the Saturn V\u2019s first stage engines had been in testing for a decade. They didn\u2019t have a heavy lift rocket in the 1960s that could deliver a sizable crewed payload to the moon in one launch.\nThe difference in approaches in engine testing and development illustrates how far behind the USSR was in the moon race. F-1 engines went through the following testing sequence:\nYears of research and development to perfect the engines and their notorious combustion instability (1955\u20131960s).\nEach production F-1 engine was test-fired at the factory.\nEach Saturn S-IC\n(the Saturn V\u2019s first stage) was test fired as a fully assembled stage in a test rig with all five factory-proven F-1\u2019s firing together. The intact stage was shipped to the launch site by barge.\nThe Saturn IC was thus a proven stage by the time it was launched with a second stage, third stage, and Apollo stack atop it. Test flights of the full Saturn V began with Apollo 4 in 1967, 2 years before Apollo 11.\nAs a result of 14 years of effort leading up to Apollo 11, the Saturn V and Apollo hardware was very reliable.\nThe Soviet approach to the N-1 was:\nOnly build and test the first stage engines in earnest starting in 1965.\nOnly test fire 1 of 3 first stage NK-15 engines at the factory\nstarting in 1967.\nBuild the entire first stage with 30 engines, but never test fire it all together at the factory.\nBreak down the first stage into sections and ship in small pieces by train to the launch site.\nReassemble the chunks at the launch site.\nLaunch it and see what happens.\nUnsurprisingly, the N-1 blew up on all four of its test fights. Despite my emphasis on engine testing in the description above, software in the flight control system was responsible for 3 of 4 N-1 failures.\nAs noted by the Soviets themselves\n, to get to the moon before the Americans, they needed:\nA focused organization like NASA rather than a rambling mess of individual bureaus pursuing different scientific goals on scraps from the military\u2019s table\nMore than 10% of NASA\u2019s budget, but that\u2019s all they got\nBetter quality control in factories, where the Soviets considered their own workers unskilled and undisciplined\nA start long before 1965.\nAnd that\u2019s at a minimum. Having Korolev around would\u2019ve been useful, but having Khrushchev out of the way before 1960 would\u2019ve helped even more.", "Probably not.\nThe Soviets didn't (or couldn't) throw the same amount of money and resources at the problem as the U.S., something not made better by competing bureaus, each with their own scheme."], "topic_list": ["Soviet Space Program", "Moon Landings", "Soviet Modern technologies are based on machine\\ artificial Intelligence. Ancient technologies were based on pure mind/natural Intelligence. In the sense, if I give you 2 pieces of technology it can be arranged on the line with one end signifying less powerful and other end signifying more powerful. This might be true in some cases but false in most. Like if I tell you fission bomb and fusion bomb. It would be easy to say that a fusion bomb is more advanced than fission bombs. But what if I tell you antimatter bomb and mind control technology. Here I don't mean control other people's minds, but control one\u2019s own mind. Which do you think is more powerful?\nThe entire Hindu scriptures are based on Mind Control Technique. Whether it is Yoga or Meditation or any spiritual practices. It is all about being able to control one's Mind.\nToday, what is the approach of Western knowledge? It makes individuals learn the concept of learning for the initial 20 years of their lives. You don't do anything else but learn to learn, that's it.\nNext 4\u20137 years, depending on craft, they study the concepts they are interested in. They completely submerged in the topics of the field. They work on it, day in and day out. Then once in a while, they have an Epiphany. There are a lot of other words for that moment. Trying to solve a problem and it clicked. Or \u201cIt just came to me\u201d moment.\nNevertheless, it is like throwing a dart in the dark and hoping that it hits the target. And sometimes it hits by luck. That is the reason, it takes so much time to solve a problem. Like, find the treatment for a disease or develop a new method of problem-solving or new mathematical models.\nHindu system was very different. Along with focusing on developing good character and knowledge base for the individual during the initial years of development, they also focused heavily on Mind-Control techniques like Meditation and Yoga. So, instead of Epiphany to happen by chance, they actually will it to happen. But this is a bit more robust system as it can be sustained for extended periods of time. They were even able to identify the drawbacks of the system before actually putting the technique into practice. This is why you see a lot of error-free solutions from olden times. Like Temples build using a monolith. A single chisel mistake would mess the entire project. Another example is creating a verse that has a different sensible meaning depending on the meter used. So, a poetic verse would be available to everyone with a common meter to understand it, but some special people will have a special meter that gives a totally different meaning to the same verse.\neg. They built the Erie Canal and half of the Great Railroad. Or do you mean something else?", "Q: What did the Irish achieve when they immigrated to the US in the 18th and 19th centuries?\n18th century and early 19th century emigration from Ireland to other places in the world, not just the U.S. was generally a protestant migration. These people were usually well-received since they were from the same side of the Protestant Reformation schism as those living where they moved and arrived in relatively small numbers.\nThe 1840s saw that demographic change to poor Catholics from the more rural parts of the island where their small plots failed and absentee landlords did not offer much, if any, support or leeway in paying rents. This was a different migration. They were people who could scrape together enough money to reach a port, pay for [usually] steerage tickets, and still have the required money in pocket when they arrived at their destination. Empty pockets when you arrived could mean you were sent back as \u201cdestitute\u201d.\nThe earliest immigrants in this wave usually walked of the ship directly into the city at whatever port where they arrived (NYC, Philly, Boston, Baltimore, etc) until 1854. After that, there were immigration controls in place making the process more complicated.\nWhat did they achieve? First, they were alive. Starvation was a very real threat in Ireland so getting out was critical.\nSecond, they didn\u2019t go into the poor house in Ireland. While the poor house was setup to help people it was also the destination of last resort since conditions were harsh, families split up, and many didn\u2019t live to leave.\nThird, they now had opportunities to find work and provide for their families. Many sent money back to Ireland or saved money to bring other family members. If you find an immigrant traveling alone you might be seeing the first to leave\u2026 or watch where they went because they were probably meeting someone who had arrived earlier.\nMost of these immigrants were not highly educated or trained in advanced skills. They were generally farmers. Others did emigrate but the bulk were farmers or shepherds. So, the first jobs they got were as general labor or low-skilled entry-level jobs.\nRailroads were in a building boom throughout the latter half of the 19th century so there was lots of work with canals and later railroads. Farm labor was always available as well. And, then, in the cities many ended up as police or firemen or some other type of service job.\nFourth, once they had work they could start a family so they married and had children. Usually, lots of children because it was a tradition for farming families - even those now in the cities - and the Catholic Church pushed the \u201cgo forth and multiply\u201d and contraception was basically illegal. There are a few reasons we need to take this statistic with a grain of salt in particular. Firstly, this was a statistic taken from 2015, so it is already inaccurate. Secondly, there are many philosophical questions like what constitutes a human, and from what point in time do we start our estimate. Thirdly, there is absolutely no way we could ever know the correct number for sure, but for the sake of answering this question, we\u2019ll use it anyways as a vague estimate.\nNext, according to How many people die and how many are born each year?\n, in the year 2020, the projected birth rate is about 140,000,000 births per year, and the projected death rate is about 60,000,000 per year. For the sake of simplicity and since we just can\u2019t be sure of future trends, we are going to assume that these rates will not change.\nHere\u2019s what our equation looks like:\n7,800,000,000 + 140,000,000x = 100,800,000,000 + 60,000,000x\nWhat this equation is saying is there are currently 7.8 billion people in the world, and this number grows by 140 million people per year, and we want this to equal the 100.8 billion people that are already dead as well as the additional 60 million people that die every year. By solving for x, which represents years, this equation will tell us in how many years these numbers will be equal (and since the rate of growth is larger than the rate of death, we can assume that this will very quickly mean that there will be more living people than there have ever been dead people).\n80,000,000x = 93,000,000,000\nx = 1,162.5\nThis means that if we continue forward at the same rate of births and deaths every year, the amount of people living will equal that total amount of dead people in 1,162.5 years from now.\nThis answer should of course not be taken too seriously because like I said, we don\u2019t know how many people have actually died in human history before now, and the rates of births and deaths per year will most certainly change. It would likely take much longer than this value to actually reach this point, but I would think that it is possible for the number of living people to be greater than the number of deceased in the distant future.", "See \u201cThe Vitanuls\u201d by John Brunner.\nA treatise on the conservation of souls.", "No way, more than 100 billion people have died and there is only 7.8 billion alive. The Mercian ascendancy ended in 825, and the Great Heathen Army arrived in 865. Although Wessex only achieved a brief ascendancy itself before Mercia asserted its independence again, it probably remained the more powerful of the two kingdoms thereafter, treating Kent and Sussex as sub-kingdoms, and fully annexing them by 858.\nThe clue to Anglo-Saxon reaction to the Great Heathen Army lies in the name they gave it. By the 9th century, the Anglo-Saxon cultures were devoutly Christian, and the Viking invaders were pagan. There can be little doubt as to the shock and horror in Wessex as these pagans collapsed the kingdoms of East Anglia, Northumbria and Mercia, and very nearly went on to collapse Wessex as well.\nHowever, as these Vikings settled down to rule their new territories, either becoming Christian or at least tolerant of Christianity in the process, the situation became more nuanced. The Vikings were actually quite close relatives of the Anglo-Saxons, especially of the Angles, who had been their immediate neighbours in what is now Denmark not too many centuries before. The coincidence of the Danelaw with the old Angle-identified areas is quite striking, and suggests that if anything it was the Angles who could reconcile themselves without too much difficulty to scarcely foreign Danish rule. How closely related might she be to the Scots?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "1,123", "name_list": ["Catriona MacAllister", "Chrissie Nyssen", "Jonathan Beaumont", "Ann Watson", "Edwin Stewart Deady"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "335": {"ans_list": ["Conventional historians have spent a great deal of time confirming Elizabeth\n\u2019s own claim that she lived and died a virgin. It greatly suited her persona as the most eligible marriage suit in Europe. She was also a most accomplished dissembler, and I have recently completed the text of a book, Elizabeth\u2019s Secret Lover: Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester (to be published by Pen and Sword in 2020), which provides compelling evidence that Lord Robert Dudley\nwas her lover in the full sense. Elizabeth was very much attracted to the devastatingly good looking Dudley, her Master of Horse, who she had known since childhood. She was obsessed with him and showered him with gifts and perquisites. There is really no disagreement that, if Elizabeth had had a free hand, she would have chosen Dudley as her husband. None of her later favourites achieved a similar rapport with her.\nUnfortunately, William Cecil\n, Elizabeth\u2019s Secretary of State, strongly disapproved of her marrying Dudley. This is not to suggest that they particularly disliked each other, and Cecil much admired Dudley\u2019s unfailing loyalty to the Queen, but he wanted Elizabeth to make a political marriage as the means of protecting England from Continental Catholic attack. Furthermore, Cecil was extremely cautious, and he disapproved of Dudley\u2019s more \u2018hawkish\u2019 foreign policy and his support for Calvinist ministers, bent on undermining the structure of the Episcopalian Anglican church that both both Elizabeth and Cecil had done much to set up. Dudley\u2019s aura of Puritan demeanour seemed to sit uncomfortably with rumours of a more chequered private life.\nIn the early part of Elizabeth\u2019s reign, Dudley remained married to Amy Robsart, who had not provided him with children, and was now living in Oxfordshire, suffering from breast cancer. Cecil was not averse to a few devious tricks, and he saw Amy\u2019s illness as a means of tarnishing Dudley\u2019s name. In 1560, he spread rumours that Elizabeth and Dudley were only waiting for Amy\u2019s death so that they could marry. He even suggested that Amy was in danger of being murdered. When Amy, very unfortunately was found with a broken neck at the bottom of a couple of steps a few days later, Cecil only had to ask whether Amy fell or was she pushed. No modern historians believe there was foul play, and Dudley (who had been at Court) was exonerated in the Coroner\u2019s verdict, but Amy\u2019s death hung over him for the rest of his life.\nWith Amy dead, Dudley undoubtedly hoped to marry Elizabeth, and was encouraged by her to undermine any foreign marriage suits as they were put forward by her long suffering ministers. Many have said that they would not have contemplated a sexual relationship, for fear that Elizabeth might become pregnant. On the contrary, it is much more likely that Elizabeth saw pregnancy as her means of gaining support for the marriage to thwart the dynastic hopes of the Catholic Mary Queen of Scots. She could then marry Dudley without opposition from her ministers. So long as their marriage took place before the birth of any child, the child\u2019s legitimacy would not be compromised. (Elizabeth was herself conceived before the marriage of Henry VIII to Anne Boleyn).\nElizabeth always denied that she was in bed with Dudley, but she was an arch dissembler. She also admitted that if she wanted to take a lover, no one could prevent her. Certainly Dudley\u2019s bedchamber at Court was placed next to hers, and it would have been tempting for her to leave her bedroom, which was surrounded by her ladies, and visit Dudley in his. He had a manservant, Tamworth, who slept on a pallet in his bedroom, so it is not unreasonable to assume that Tamworth would have known what was going on. When Elizabeth was suffering from small-pox in 1562, she made a will leaving a pension to Tamworth of \u00a3500 per annum (perhaps \u00a3500,000 in current money). This is an extraordinary sum to leave to a servant unless it were a pay off to keep his mouth shut.\nWe know that Elizabeth did not become pregnant. It is also known that she suffered an irregular menstrual cycle and was only doubtfully fertile. There was no reliable form of contraception in Tudor times, so it is probable that Elizabeth concluded after two years that she was unable to bear children. Certainly when Mary Queen of Scots gave birth to a son, Elizabeth pronounced that she was of barren stock. She had seen the embarrassment of the phantom pregnancies of her sister Mary Tudor, and may have concluded that it was preferable to be a \u2018virgin\u2019 queen than a barren wife.\nCecil remained determined to prevent Dudley from marrying Elizabeth and he proposed a test of his integrity. She was persuaded to ask Dudley to seek Spanish backing for their marriage in return for their support for a Spanish led Counter-Reformation. It seems incredible that Dudley as a staunch puritan would promote such a plan, but it demonstrates that his ambition to marry Elizabeth was of greater importance than his faith. He asked his brother-in-law, Sir Henry Sidney, to make this proposal to de Quadra, the Spanish ambassador. Sir Henry even told de Quadra that Dudley and Elizabeth were lovers. He was in a good position to know as his wife Mary Dudley was one of Elizabeth\u2019s ladies in waiting. Although Dudley confirmed his offer to de Quadra at a later date, when the ambassador raised it with Elizabeth, she backed off. She was shocked that Dudley would take such a step contrary to all his religious beliefs, and she realised that he had failed Cecil\u2019s test of his integrity. It was this that persuaded her to nominate Dudley as a suitable husband for Mary Queen of Scots, with which Cecil heartily agreed.\nDespite this, Elizabeth remained intoxicated with Dudley, and they continued an intermittent relationship until about 1567 when Robert\u2019s affair with Douglas Howard developed. Despite this Elizabeth considered Dudley to have been the love of her life.", "No one is sure. Possibly Thomas Seymour, when she was very young and living with her step-mother Catherine Parr. And possibly Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester. She made him Earl and he was a suitor for many years and many people thought she would marry him. They were certainly life long friends. But there is absolutely no evidence that she was anything other than a virgin. Her image as a Virgin was certainly a useful PR tool though and part of her means of maintaining peace was by constantly behaving as if she might marry one European royal or another. This was a strategy for sure.\nI think its extremely unlikely that Essex was her lover. Both states murdered civilians and prisoners of war, both states permitted medical experimentation on civilian and military prisoners. The attack through bombing of non-military and undefended civilian targets. The launching of attacks on recognized protected targets such as hospital ships. Wholesale deportation and enslavement of populations.\nBoth states sanctioned the taking and killing of hostages, wholesale looting and wanton destruction of property. Both states created conditions of famine in areas under their military occupation through the confiscation of food supplies.\nThese are just few of the reasons why Germany and Japan are portrayed in such a bad way because of the policies they pursued during the war and the actions of their armed forces in pursuit of those policies.", "There was a complex situation in the USA that neither Japan nor Germany of this time frame were made to understand. They are therefore rightfully viewed as incompetent and not long for the World and indeed lucky to even exist today. Why either are seen as *villainous* is something for Hollywood not History.", "The Second World War is generally said to have kicked off when Nazi Germany invaded Poland, having been warned by Britain and France that doing so would lead to war. So, that\u2019s sort of a \u201cbad guy\u201d move - invading your neighbours is generally considered to be a Bad Thing.\nIn 1940 Germany went on to invade Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and France. Again, \u201cinvading other countries\u201d sort of makes you the Bad Guy.\nThen, in 1941, Nazi Germany invaded the USSR, captured millions of prisoners of war, and basically just left them in empty fields surrounded by barbed wire and armed guards to starve or freeze to death (over a million Soviet POWs died in the winter of 1941/2) which is - once again - the sort of move associated with the Bad Guys.\nJapan, likewise, decided that if Nazi Germany could go invading everyone in sight, they could have some of that (on top of their long-running war in China they\u2019d been enjoying for a decade) so they invaded the Phillipines, Indonesia, Malaya, the Dutch East Indies, Singapore, French Indo-China (what\u2019s now Laos, Vietnam, Thailand and Cambodia), Burma, and pushed all the way into India. As far as I can tell none of those nations were particularly eager to have been \u201cinvaded by Japan\u201d.\nThere was also the minor point that for a couple of years, as well as just letting Soviet POWs starve to death, the Nazis were happily working prisoners and slave labour from occupied countries to death in their factories on starvation rations, while also running industrial-scale extermination camps to kill off \u201cundesirables\u201d (Jews, gypsies, homosexuals, Communists, the disabled, anyone who didn\u2019t meet Nazi standards of perfection). Guess what? That\u2019s the sort of thing the villain does so the audience knows they\u2019re Really Bad.\nBasically, if Hitler had said at the start of September 1939 \u201cyou know what, let\u2019s not invade anybody\u201d then the Germany of that time would be remembered much more positively. But once you start fighting your way into other people\u2019s countries, firebombing their homes, and rounding up people for being the wrong religion or having the wrong politics and killing them en masse, you become pretty much the Bad Guy.\nTo pick on the US for just one example, it\u2019s fairly shameful the way they treated the Nisei (Japanese-American citizens) - they were rounded up, interned in camps, had their property confiscated or stolen. It was most definitely Not Good. But the Nisei weren\u2019t worked to death in factories on starvation rations, or shot or gassed on arrival at their internment camp/\nJapan and Germany started attacking other countries, and behaved notably worse than other nations in the way they treated their new conquests. (Note how nobody kicks off about Italian atrocities because - in WW2* - they avoided the worse horrors, despite the Italians being co-belligerents with Nazi Germany and Japan)\n*There were justified complaints about their use of chemical weapons in Africa in the 1930s, for instance, but the Italians avoided the sort of recreational cruelties that Imperial Japan and Nazi Germany indulged in during WW2.", "Is there a reason why German and Japan are viewed in such a bad way, as the villains of WW2, besides the fact that The Allies won? Could it be because history is always told by the winners as the right way that things should be?\nYes, there are reasons. Germany (not \u201cGerman\u201d) and Japan were truly the villains of WW II, and this attitude has nothing to do with who won. It has to do with who started hostilities, and how those nations conducted their wars.\nJapan initiated the Second Sino-Japanese War in 1937, and this grew into the Pacific part of WW II. Their conduct of war in China was brutal beyond normal wartime behaviors. They killed large numbers of civilians including women and children, raped many Chinese women, performed wholly unethical and horrible medical experiments on prisoners including civilian prisoners, and were the aggressors. In December 1941 they extended their war to take on Great Britain and its Empire and Commonwealth, Australia, New Zealand, the Netherlands, and the USA, all without any declaration of war. They violated what was considered by most of the world to be appropriate standards of conduct toward prisoners of war, using them for slave labor, killing many outright, starving many more, and employing torture, the afore-mentionsd medical experimentation, and other truly criminal acts. They deserve the label \u201cvillains\u201d\nOn the other side of the globe Germany was led by the totalitarian regime of the Nazi Party and its Fuhrer, Adolf Hitler. The Germans violated multiple treaties and agreements from 1935\u20131939, culminating in their invasion of Poland that precipitated the European part of WW II. The conduct of German forces during the war was highly variable, but often, and especially in the East, as criminal as that of the Japanese. They killed civilians as revenge for the killings by partisans/guerrillas of German soldiers in France, Belgium, and elsewhere. They terrorized civilian populations. Having started extreme measures against Jews, Roma, and other ethnic or religious groups in Germany before the war, they undertook what today we call the Holocaust, an industrialized form of murder intended to \u201csolve\u201d the \u201cJewish question\u201d by exterminating all the Jews of Europe. They generally treated prisoners of war from western nations well, but they broke all the rules in their treatment of Polish and Soviet prisoners of war, acting in ways very similar to how the Japanese treated POWS less selectively. They used them for slave labor, they killed many outright, they starved most, they tortured some, and in the concentration and death camps they also practiced medical experimentation on prisoners (men, women, and children, especially Jews). They are also appropriately labeled as \u201cvillains\u201d\nOf course had these villains won their wars they would have written their histories differently. However there were honorable Germans who did not approve or or participate in the war crimes of the Nazi regime, and who might have spoken out and written histories against it (had they been brave enough) after the war, particularly with regard to the extermination of the Jews and Roma. It is harder to assess, from this date, whether there were counterparts for those men and women in Japan. That does not change the facts, that what those nations did to start the wars and to carry them out violated normal rules of human behavior, that they acted barbarously, that they committed crimes.", "There are several reasons I'll list a few of the more well known ones just for the sake of argument. But this is far from a complete list. And most of the information you can find on them is largely cleaned up to PG-13.\nWith the Japanese Imperial military we will start with the \u201cRape of Nanking\u201d I will not go into the politics of it. But the methods used were so brutal they made a Nazi observer vomit. That's a pretty high bar to clear to disgust a Nazi.\nThe Bataan death March is another one. I will not go into details beyond this episode violated several International laws governing the treatment of POW's.\nAnd over on the Western front we have a political party and its leader that were so reviled the very names associated with them are used as synonyms for, racism and genocide. Jews, Black's, Gypsies, Homosexuals, communists and the mentally disabled were slaughtered by the millions.\nWW2 was one the darkest times in history for human rights abuses. There were very few clean hands in this war. And yet the Nazis and the Japanese stand head shoulders above the rest on this hall of shame.\nSo yes the reputation they acquired was well deserved. If not more deserving for revulsion. Im not throwing the baby out with the bath water here. There is and was a difference between a Wehrmacht soldier and a Nazi. Not all Nazi's were German or Austrian. And Not all Germans or Austrians were Nazi's. A lot of them were just trying to survive a regime run by a madman and go about their lives. Some of them did the salute and said what they needed to survive without believing in it for a second.\nThe Japanese side of things is \u201cmurkier\" certainly there were citizens that had no idea about what was really going on. And had a sense of nationalistic pride that in and of itself there was nothing wrong with. Some as with every war out and out opposed it on political, moral, or religious grounds or some combination there of. But at least amongst the military there were far more that \u201cdrank the koolaid\" then even the Wehrmacht, for whatever reason. When I was in Japan it was a subject I studiously avoided even though I have a love of studying history. It is a chapter that the Japanese people would rather close and move on from and I had no problem obliging. Not to mention it was gauche to the point of insulting to bring it up in normal conversation. Even amongst academics.", "Typically invading neutral countries with no provocation specifically in order to exterminate millions of people makes you the bad guy, irrelevant of who writes the history. The agitations involved several mass protests, riots, student and political movements majorly in Goa and Karnataka and concerned the official status of Konkani in the Indian Republic.\nAware of the looming danger of Konkani being sidelined, v\u0101man vard\u0113 \u015be\u1e47ai va\u1e37avalik\u0101r, popularly known as Shenoi goemb\u0101b gave a clarion call for the revival of Konkani in the early 20th century. Under his guidance, a steady movement was getting built up and the effort was on to initiate a rejuvenation of Konkani language and heritage, by means of establishing a common cultural identity among the Konkani people.\nThe root of the Konkani Language agitation laid in the denial of Konkani as an independent language and the opposition to merge Goa into Maharashtra. Konkani was not taken seriously as a potential official language except by a few stalwarts. By 1960, pro-Konkani and pro-Marathi groups started a propaganda war through distribution of pamphlets. In 1962, the All India Konkani Parishad held its eighth session for the first time at Ma\u1e0dg\u0101\u0303v (Margao) in post-liberation Goa and passed a resolution urging the Kendra Sahitya Akademi to recognise Konkani. Simultaneously, the referendum in 1967 thwarted the merger of Goa into Maharashtra and paved the way for its statehood in the Union of India. Goan statehood gave a further boost to the pro-Konkani camp.\nEarlier in 1966, the then Chief Minister of Goa, Dayanand Bandodkar appointed a committee to examine the feasibility of declaring Marathi as the official language of Goa. Attempts were made by some members of the Maharashtrawadi Gomantak Party, a party formed before the referendum proposing merger into Maharashtra, and a splinter group to pass a Goa, Daman and Diu Official Language Bill in 1966 which was thwarted by the Chief Minister. On 22 August 1970, Bandodkar declared Konkani, written in the Devanagari script, as the official language of Goa along with Marathi.\nIn 1973, chief minister of Goa, Dayanand Bandodkar died, and his daughter Shashikala Kakodkar ascended to the post. Under Kakodkar, government policies favouring Marathi were framed. Marathi was made compulsory in English medium schools whilst Konkani was excluded. This policy was met with severe criticism from Konkani organisations, both, within Goa and outside. Although promises were made by Kakodkar in 1977 and thereafter by then Congress Chief Minister Pratapsinh Rane in 1980 to treat Konkani at par with Marathi, the matter was kept in abeyance till 1986.\nIn their election manifesto, the Congress party had stated that once statehood was achieved Konkani would be recognised as an official language and demands would be made to include it in the Eighth Schedule of the Indian Constitution. In 1980, the Congress came into power under Chief Minister Pratap Singh Rane, Rane despite the promises made, procrastinated on the issue. This led to an agitation in 1986 on the streets popularly called ko\u1e45ka\u1e47\u012b praj\u0113tso \u0101v\u0101z (voice of the Konkani people). Goa witnessed the bloodiest agitation ever, the Language agitation, in which seven pro-Konkani agitators lost their lives and several were injured. The government inorder to suppress the riot fired at the Pro-Konkani agitators.\nThe Goa, Daman and Diu Official Language bill, presented to the legislative assembly in 1986, was passed on 4 February 1987 declaring Konkani the sole official language of the Union Territory of Goa, Daman and Diu with provisions for Marathi and Gujarati for Daman and Diu. On 30 May 1987 Goa got statehood with Konkani as the sole official language. The Kendra Sahitya Academy recognised Konkani, in the Devanagari script, as an independent language on 26 February 1975. This paved the way for the decision to include Konkani in the Eighth Schedule of the Indian Constitution making Konkani one of the official languages of India.\nThe struggle for Konkani in Goa, did not go unnoticed in Canara and Travancore. The Konkani speakers in Canara (currently Uttara Kannada, Udupi and Dakshina Kannada) and Travancore (currently Cochin and Ernakulam), inspired by the writings of Shenoi Goembab were getting increasingly aware on the issue of mother tongue.(This shows the close relationship between Konkanis of Goa,Kerala and Karnataka)\nThe first public pro-Konkani gathering was held outside Goa and by non Goan Konkanis. In 1939, the All India Konkani Parishad was founded by the efforts of Manjunath Shanbhag and the first session was held. This was followed by the second session at Udupi organised by Dr. T.M.A. Pai. The liberation and subsequent statehood of Goa bolstered Konkani's status in Karnataka. In 1962, the Konkani Bhasha Prachar Sabha, Cochin, took up the issue of inclusion of Konkani in the Eighth schedule with the Government of India and the Linguistic Minorities Commission. In 1976, the Konkani Bhasha Mandali was founded at Mangalore enhance the status of Konkani in the state. In 1994, the Government of Karnataka founded the Karnataka Konkani Sahitya Academy at Mangalore to propagate Konkani literature. The first Vishwa Konkani Sammelan was held in Mangalore in 1995 wherein 5,000 delegated from 75 centres from India, the middle east, the US, UK, etc. participated.\nThe Konkani language agitations truly became successful when Konkani was included in the eight schedule of the Indian constitution in 1992.\nIn 2005, the foundation was laid for a World Konkani centre to further the cause of Konkani on a global scale. From the academic year 2007-2008 Konkani has become an optional subject in the schools of Karnataka and Kerala.\nThanks \ud83d\ude4f"], "topic_list": ["Konkani (language)", "Languages of India", "Language", "History"], "view_list": [91], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Shashank Shenoy (\u0936\u0936\u093e\u0902\u0915 \u0936\u0946\u0923\u094d\u0935\u0940\u0902)", "upvote_list": [12], "question_title": "What were the Konkani language agitations about, and what was the result of those agitations?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "185", "name_list": ["Shashank Shenoy (\u0936\u0936\u093e\u0902\u0915 \u0936\u0946\u0923\u094d\u0935\u0940\u0902)"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"]}, "587": {"ans_list": ["All I know is that it is/was located in California.", "Merce Cunningham - Wikipedia"], "topic_list": ["Photo Developing", "Companies", "History"], "view_list": [61, 1], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "C Hain", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "What is the company history of Cunningham's Studios?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "261", "name_list": ["Rodney Dowling", "Roy Rutanen"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "399": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Philippine Law", "History of the Philippines", "Jobs and Careers for Attorneys", "Politics of the Philippines", "Attorney Recommendations", "The Philippines", "Attorneys", "Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life", "Law", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "F. For most of Western European history, \u201cthe Emperor\u201d indicated the Holy Roman Emperor. A brief exception was occasional use of Imperator totius Hispaniae - Wikipedia\nto claim hegemony in Spain around 1000.\nNapoleon crowned himself Emperor of the French only after abolition of the millennium-old HRE title, leaving Francis II as just hereditary https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_of_Austria?wprov=sfti1\ninstead of elected Holy Roman Emperor. When his grandson proclaimed himself Napoleon III, \u201cimperialism\u201d still meant pretensions to the title, not overseas colonialism as it came to mean a few years later. The end of the French Second Empire was the start of the German Second Reich and Kaiser. Next Disraeli made Victoria Empress of India to compete with Russia where Peter the Great had taken up \u201cImperator\u201d in 1721 modeled on Constantinople not the western Rome. Ironically the major European state without an emperor was now Italy.", "\u201cEmpire\u201d has a history attached to it. The name was coined by the Romans to describe a specific political arrangement. The empire was what the Romans had. It described their state and their political ambitions. In theory, everything was potentially subject to the empire. They just hadn\u2019t taken control of it yet (and, of course, they\u2019d forebear to take control of places they couldn\u2019t or didn\u2019t feel like conquering and would negotiate with whoever lived there). Other things we call empires, like the various Persian states, the Romans didn\u2019t call empires, because they weren\u2019t the empire.\nWhen Roman control over western Europe collapsed and the line of emperors ended there, that opened the door for things to become more generic. In the late 7th century, the ruler of the Bulgars was awarded the imperial title of Caesar by the Byzantine empire, which opened the door to call the territory of the Bulgars an empire. In 800 AD, Charlemagne was crowned emperor by the Pope, reviving the idea of a line of supreme rulers operating under Roman legal precedent. That title vanished again some decades later but surfaced again as the Holy Roman Empire started to come together. Serbs, Russians, French, and even British rulers eventually adopted it. What happened is that the name became less and less an indication of Roman legal and political heritage and more and more a statement of comprehensive rule over many nations.\nSo, then, it became acceptable for some power which happened to be European to call themselves an empire as soon as they invented the idea. The idea of multiple empires slowly developed over the course of the Middle Ages and into the modern era.", "Start with the Roman Empire"], "topic_list": ["European Preeminence", "Imperialism", "European Ethnicities and People", "Empires", "Power (society)", "History of Europe", "World History", "Europe", "History"], "view_list": [65, 21, 93, 1], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Thao Dao", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 4, 0], "question_title": "When did it become acceptable for European powers to call themselves empires?", "respond_collected": 4, "no_of_view": "404", "name_list": ["Victor Hernandez", "Joseph Boyle", "Matt Riggsby", "Dennis Wojahn"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "62": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Investment Bankers", "Bankers", "Introductions (meeting)", "Investment Banking", "World History", "Banks", "Banking", "Finance", "History", "Jobs and Careers"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Padhmapriya", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Who are some prominent bankers in the world? There were courts of law and courts of equity.\nIn a nutshell, the law was quite rigid and limited in the remedies it could offer, usually an award of damages. Equity, by contrast, was more flexible and could offer a wide range of remedies, such as injunctions or specific performance.\nLawyers who dealt in the courts of law were called attorneys; lawyers who dealt in the courts of equity were called solicitors. Barristers were specialist advocates who could practice in either set of courts, but the chancery bar (which dealt with the equity cases) was seen then (as now) as a specialist branch of the profession.\nIn 1875 the court of law and courts of equity were merged, a long overdue reform. In theory law and equity remain as two discrete disciplines, but in practical terms equitable principles are now part of \u201cthe law\u201d.\nThe term \u201cattorney at law\u201d was abolished by the Judicature Act 1873 and all attorneys and solicitors became Solicitors of the Supreme Court (the new High Court created by the reforms; not to be confused with the Supreme Court of United Kingdom created when Mr Blair was Prime Minister; in his enthusiasm for \u201cmodernisation\u201d, he seemingly forget that there was already a supreme court)"], "topic_list": ["History"], "view_list": [112], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Ramona Grant", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What does \u2018attorney\u2019 mean in history?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "642", "name_list": ["Martin Collier"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "392": {"ans_list": ["He was Anne Boleyn\u2019s uncle as well. This is the most common epistemology in history, even among Natural Scientists.\nYet, empiricism effectively excludes Ethics, Aesthetics, Virtues, Honor, Temperance, Wisdom, Morality, Beauty and other Ideals from the realm of Truth! This is one of the problems of modern Philosophy.\nThere\u2019s my reading.", "Which widely adopted epistemological realization has had the greatest impact on human history?\nI\u2019d say that associated with Alexander Koyr\u00e9\u2019s book From the Closed World to the Infinite Universe\n, which describes the transition from the medieval to the modern world view, from a closed and finite world such as described by Aristotle and Ptolemy, to an open and infinite universe and progressively came to consciousness through the great scientists of the scientific revolution, from Copernicus through Galileo and Kepler to Newton and Einstein. Also crucial for this development was the transition from Scholastic philosophy to modern philosophy, primarily the work of Descartes, which is sometimes characterized as a shift from metaphysics to epistemology. So that epistemological realization of modernity was itself epistemological in nature\u2014the transition from metaphysical questions to asking How do we know what we know? What exactly do we know? How does science make it possible to know things? And so on. These questions were present in Scholasticism, but they had no particular importance or urgency. Descartes gave these questions urgency.\nThe scientific revolution had the greatest impact on human history because it was the spirit of the Enlightenment, the political revolutions of 1776 and 1789, and the industrial revolution, which had been made possible by the scientific revolution and its picture of the world. This picture of the world was naturalistic and rooted in human knowledge, rather than being supernaturalistic and rooted in faith."], "topic_list": ["Epistemology", "Impact", "World History", "Philosophy", "The Human Race and Condition", "History", "Philosophy of Everyday Life"], "view_list": [1, 3, 24, 29], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Jack Magee", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 1], "question_title": "Which widely adopted epistemological realization has had the greatest impact on human history?", "respond_collected": 4, "no_of_view": "256", "name_list": ["Hugo Le Roux Guthrie", "Richard Berg", "Paul Trejo", "Nick Nielsen"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "898": {"ans_list": ["Chickens were domesticated thousands of years ago, most likely for sport (rooster fighting). As they spread from place to place, they crossbred with a few closely related species, which is why it is difficult to determine their genetic history and exact place of origin. Eventually they were bred for eggs, meat and esthetic value (the sultan chicken, Japanese varieties of long tail chickens and so forth).", "My understanding is that chickens evolved from killer dinosaurs; if so, the man that discovered the first chicken might not have been able to convey his discovery considering his consumption by a six foot tall evolving chicken.\nVelociraptor"], "topic_list": ["Chickens", "Discoveries", "Chicken (food)", "History"], "view_list": [35, 328], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Saurav Kumar Bir", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "Who discovered the chicken?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "548", "name_list": ["Abby Stein", "Amos Cline"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "516": {"ans_list": ["At least 90% Just simply by doing these following things.\nPrecautions in handling with small animals.\nHunts and getting rid of rodents and fleas.\nImprove area and personal Hygiene\nPersonal protective attire when handling the dead. Particularly protection from flea bites around the infected.\nAdopt modern day quarrantine methods, and getting rid of the death fast. Adopt cremation if fast burial is not available."], "topic_list": ["Black Death", "Plagues", "Pandemics", "Time Travel Scenarios", "Middle Ages (era)", "Epidemiology", "England", "Alternate Histories (Hypothetical Historical Scenarios)", "Hypothetical Scenarios", "History", "Medicine and Healthcare"], "view_list": [124], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 3, "question_author": "Grant Hartlage", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "Say Edward III of England somehow had modern medical knowledge about the Black Plague, perhaps given by a time-travelling medic. With his power and the material conditions of the time, how many deaths could be prevented?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "660", "name_list": ["Liew Jia Pau"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "405": {"ans_list": ["The term of enlistment for the earliest volunteers for the Confederacy was due to end in the Spring of 1862. Many figured on going home. But in April of that year McClellan's army was on Virginia soil and Confederates had been defeated at Fort Donelson, Shiloh, New Orleans and at Pea Ridge, Arkansas. Subsequently the Confederate Congress passed two laws at Jefferson Davis\u2019 request. The first extended all enlistments for the duration and the second required all those men between eighteen and thirty-five to serve in the army for three years. Wealthy draftees simply paid other men to serve in their place, and men who owned twenty or more slaves were exempt. Governors of Georgia and North Carolina said they would ignore the law because it trampled on individual states rights. Joseph E. Brown of Georgia said, \u201cThe Conscription Act at one fell swoop, strikes down the sovereignty of the states, tramples upon the constitutional rights and personal liberty of the citizens, and arms the President with imperial power.\u201d There were no conscription riots in the Confederacy I am aware of.", "There were little draft dodger communities in isolated mountains or swamps, on the edge of towns. Friends or relatives would bring out food and other necessities. Youngsters near draftable age would escape to these. By the mid point in the war, they knew that going to the military was a near death sentence.\nSome of these little enclaves were so dangerous, that even law enforcement was leery of going after. By the end of the war, there were some 100,000 that were dodging the draft or AWOL.\nTurns out war wasn\u2019t really so fun after all. Who knew??", "As far as I know there were no anti-draft riots in the southern states during the Civil War. There definitely were food riots, the most notorious of which occurred in the capital, Richmond, and Jefferson Davis was actually confronted by some of the protesting women. Those women broke into bakeries and store houses during the riot.\nIn addition to the other forms of resistance to the draft mentioned in other answers, some state governors refused requests for troops. The most famous of these was Governor Brown of Georgia, who kept some Georgia regiments in-state and refused to allow them to go north to fight with Lee. Under the strict States\u2019 Rights CSA Constitution, he got away with this (until W T Sherman came along and made the point moot).", "Draftees violently resisted conscription officers of the Confederate government; I don\u2019t know that they gathered into a \u201criot\u201d which suggests crowds.", "Question: \u201cDuring the American Civil War, was there instances of conscription riots in the Confederacy similar to the New York Draft Riots in the Union?\u201d\nDraft Riot is a misnomer which does not properly describe what happened. For three days in July of 1863 Irish immigrants from the crime ridden Five-Points District engaged in an orgy of shootings, beatings, murder and arson directed at Negroes. Although the catalyst for the riot was the desire of the Irish to avoid military service in the Civil War (while continuing to enjoy both access to American citizenship and the prosperity induced by the war), the primary cause was extreme racial hostility.\nThe Irishmen viscerally hated Blacks. They regarded Free Negroes as a threat to their jobs as unskilled laborers. Moreover, the only people possibly socially and economically below Irishmen in the American social hierarchy were the Free Negroes. And the Irish wanted them to stay there. The Irish despised the idea of the racial equality. If the Irish could not climb up the social ladder they at least desired to kick someone off the rung below them! And they were not going to fight in any war that would free Negro slaves and make them equal to Irishmen.\nThis Irish Race Riot resulted in the murder by hanging (often accompanied by vicious beating, shooting, and mutilation with knives) of eleven Negroes, one of which was an eleven year old child. Fifty buildings were burnt to the ground, including the occupied Colored Children\u2019s Orphan Asylum. The mob set fire to many black homes which the Irish looted before setting fire to them. As many as 2,000 people may have been killed and 8,000 injured. Three-thousand Blacks were made homeless. But the lasting result was racial cleansing, the removal of all Negroes from the now Irish dominated Five-Points slum district.\nThere were Southern riots by poor women who were trying to protect their husbands, often deserters, from capture by militia hunters. Poor Southern women also violently resisted the confiscation of their crops and food by self-appointed militias. (Note that those militia gangs who hunted down women\u2019s husbands and raided farms and confiscated the crops and food from near starving women and children conveniently made themselves exempt from real military service.) But Southerners also resisted the Civil War Draft by other means.\nFirst of all those Southerners with influence bribed legislatures to exempt either their class or their occupation from military service. For example, any man who owned 20 slaves, i.e. was of the class that would benefit from a war for the preservation and expansion of slavery, was automatically exempt from serving in that war. This exemption was taken advantage of by the planter class who divided their lands and slave holdings into parcels with 20 slaves each. If one owned 100 slaves (Some planters owned over 1,000.) this legal trick then permitted five sons (or anyone else to whom one could sell the exemption) to avoid military service in the Confederacy.\nSome states had special interest exemptions. Georgia, for example, passed a law that for some reason exempted owners of drug stores from military service. This persuaded peddlers to sell kits containing a small number of combs and scissors and a few bottles of patent medicine to Southern draft dodgers who then, with their meager supplies and a shop front, proclaimed themselves to be druggists. Shabby drug stores popped up all over Georgia.\nBut some Southerners went way beyond draft dodging or bribing legislatures. They murdered military recruiters or militia members searching for deserters. Many poor farmers in Georgia knew the Civil War for what it was, a \u201crich man\u2019s war\u201d, promoted by and for the benefit of the rich planter class. Many refused to join the Confederate Army, many more, often having been begged to do so by their wives, deserted. There were counties in the mountains of northern Georgia and in the wire grass south of the state occupied by gangs if deserters. In those counties Confederate Recruiters or those hunting down deserters were bushwhacked and shot or hung. There were during the Civil War parts of Georgia and western Virginia where Confederate Recruiters feared to go.\nNote re the draft: The New York board of Supervisors paid for substitutes for any city policemen, firemen, or poor men with dependents. So when after the riots ended and the draft resumed the New York Sun reported that, through September 28, 1863, 1,042 drafted men provided substitutes, 49 paid the $300 exemption fee, and many men from the Five-Points district were rejected as physically, mentally, or morally unfit for military service. Only 2 Irishmen joined the Union Army. Both deserted.", "They didn\u2019t have to riot with the inactment of the \"Twenty Negro Law\", also known as the \"Twenty Slave Law.\u201d Basically, the Confederate Congress passed a law which specifically exempted one white man for every twenty slaves owned on a Confederate plantation. To further aid slave owners and their cohorts, and to keep slaves in check, the law also allowed military service exemptions for two or more plantations within five miles of each other that collectively had twenty or more slaves. This allowed the slave owners to subdivide their plantations into many smaller ones. Whereas, their sons and nephews then became overseers - Avoiding the draft.\n[", "No, the reason for the riots in the north was that they knew Lincoln was wrong. The reason there were no riots in the south is the Southerners knew the north and Lincoln was Attacking them unconstitutionally.", "Resistance in the South took other forms. The only riots I am aware of had to do with food rather than conscription.\nFood was a problem that only grew as the war went on. Confederate money, became worthless, prices for foodstuffs soared, and the poor people in the South started skipping meals.\nWomen in Richmond Virginia rioted over food in 1864.\nThe first and very well known instance of resistance was the slave population. Those that could ran away, costing their owners lots of money. Many ended up joining the Union Army. The total number was around 185,000 soldiers. That was larger than an entire Field Army at the time.\nSome that stayed became spies. Others ran away when the Union Forces neared their location. (Thank You Russell Pearson for pointing out my mistake.)\nHow a Black Spy Infiltrated the Confederate White House\nAn absolutely fascinating account of a Southern White woman, who was an abolitionist and a Black Freed woman, who worked her way into becoming a servant at the Confederate White House. She helped POW\u2019s escape from Libby prison, and she spied there, as well for a time.\nThe answer to your question is there were surprisingly large parts of the South that were hostile to the cause. The story of the \u201cKingdom of Jones\u201d has become well known through a movie called \u201cFree State.\u201d\nIn fact, besides the border states like Kentucky, Missouri, Maryland, and West Virginia, there were quite large portions of North Carolina, and Tennessee, that were pro union, and anti Confederate from the start. The Egyptian Pyramids and the Stonehenge are dated around the 3rd millenia and the Mesopotamian ziggurats are in between them.\nNow, let\u2019s imagine we are in a Neolithic tribe and we want to make something special to honor our Deities or Nature or a compination of them. We have no advanced tools or technology to make an elegant monument. All we have is our strength and tenacity and these are what we offer by making a huge structure that requires 100% of our abilities.\nSo, plain Neolithic persistent people had built them.\nAs the civilization progress, the need of megastructures decline. Structures like the more elegant Persian and Greek temples took their place.", "To start, we wouldn't call the pyramids megalithic structures. Yes they made of big stone blocks, but they are made of many, many stone blocks arranged in a complicated shape that only looks like a basic pile from the outside, now that the exterior has been chipped off.\nNext, the \u201cmegaliths\u201d have been constructed in vastly different techniques, in vastly different shapes, in a wide variety of levels of complexity, by vastly different peoples, at completely different periods of time.\nThe only thing that makes them similar is that they are older than modern buildings and made of rock.\nWhy rock? Because all the structures that weren't made of rock have been worn away by time, errosion, nature, fires, and people scavenging building materials over millenea, so that only the structures made of worthless stone remain. If we could see even a tenth of what used to be around those 'megaliths' we wouldn't be anywhere near so impressed by the rock show.\nLet's also forget the type of rock, which varies constantly. The construction materials matter much more. Stonehenge uses huge monoliths, where as the pyramids are made of blocks cut into different shapes, originally capped by smooth limestone, and South American structures are made in Cyclopean style, of uncut stones painstakingly fitted together.\nSo the answer to \u201cwho built the structures?\u201d is lots, and lists of different people at different times using different tools, for completely different purposes.", "Humans.\nnot aliens of any type, or gods. Humans built them.\nIn each particular location that you want to ask about who built them, the answer is going to be the human societies that were local to that area when all those specific stone buildings, pyramids, megaliths, ziggurats, statues, platforms, and mounds were built. they built them. not an alien intergalactic race of beings nor any non-local human society. they were locals. they lived there. They built their cities there. Unlike a slave, an indentured servant is one who was generally released after providing X amount of value, usually equivalent to some large debt or the price of passage to the new world, plus a few other incidental expenses, or a promising a certain number of years of labor, generally 7 to 14, and released afterwards.\nAnthony/Antonio and his wife, Mary, got their freedom sometime after 1635, and his first legal transaction as a free man appears in 1647 when he purchased a calf.\nHe became prominent and well to do, owning 650 acres with his wife while his son went on to own 550 acres.\nHowever, he is perhaps best known as being one of the first men to legally own other men (indentured servitude was not considered ownership, nor slavery, of the person) in Virginia, and one of the first men of color to own slaves in the colonies.
