While not all the delegates to the Constitutional Convention were Brothers, they were all certainly influenced by Masonic values. First and foremost was the overarching principle of creating a nation of LAWS and not of men, sustained by an ingenious and unique arrangement of centralized and decentralized authority, mixed with a separation of powers. Behold a partial list of Masonic principles:\nThe grand lodge is supreme in the Masonic federal system\nLocal lodges are self-governing and independent\nThe selection of officers is carried out by secret vote using a ballot and elections\nGovernance is limited by the Constitution\nThe popular sovereignty of representative government and majority rule are fundamental\nFiscal responsibility is delegated to the legislative body\nA type of judicial review is conducted by the grand lodge\nFreedoms of speech and equal participation are hallmarks of Freemasonry\nJust as a Masonic Lodge lives and dies by its Grand Lodge\u2019s Charter and its own By-Laws, the USA was to operate within the parameters of its Constitutional (both federal and state) limitations.\nAnother couple of Masonic virtues that made it into our founding values - equality before the law, and equality with each other regardless of position. In a Masonic Lodge, all Brothers are equal - from the Grand Master of the Grand Lodge to the uninvolved sideliner who does nothing more than attend meetings, a Brother is a Brother is a Brother. That holds whether he\u2019s visiting from another city, state, country, or planet (yes, there is a Lodge on the Moon). Also, there is no \u201cnobility\u201d in Masonry. There are no inherited positions or titles. Office holders have to be elected by a one-man one-vote election, and those elected are vested with carrying out the responsibilities of their position and nothing more. They receive the thanks of their Brethren for their service, but no further \u2018elevation\u2019 takes place. There are no special box seats for Past Grand Masters and Worshipful Masters - they retain their form of address, but they sit alongside everybody else. When balloting, they get one vote like everybody else. There are no Masonic aristocrats or commoners. Just Brothers.\nWas the American revolution a Masonic Revolt? Considering that many of the signers of the Declaration of Independence were Brothers, and that the Commander in Chief George Washington and 33 of the Continental Army\u2019s Major Generals were Masons, as were the French commanders serving with us - Admirals D\u2019Estaing and de Grasse, and General Rochambeau, as well as most of the European volunteers that served - Baron von Steuben, the Marquis de Lafayette, and others, as well as our first naval commander - John Paul Jones, and that we fought to enshrine in our new nation the Masonic values they all held dear, it\u2019s not a stretch to say that it was.\nAfter the Revolution, we exported out values to the rest of our hemisphere, where other Masons - Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna, General Simon Bolivar, and General Jose de San Martin went about their own revolutions against autocracy and colonialism. When the Empire struck back with the French occupation of Mexico, Brother Benito Juarez went about that country\u2019s second liberation. The Texas Revolution against the tyranny of Santa Anna (who had demitted his membership) was led by Masons - the Colonels who commanded the Alamo - Crocket, Travis and Bowie were all Masons, as were Austin, and Houston - the victor of the battle of San Jacinto.\nElsewhere, while the French Revolution was not begun by Masons, fully one-third of the National Assembly were Brethren. Brother General Garibaldi unified Italy as a secular state, and Brother Mustafa Kemal deposed the Ottoman Sultanate and created the first and still only successful secular Islamic republic. I do not know \u201cwho traded myrrh in 1 BCE?\u201c It was apparently considered to be very valuable.\nMYRRH\nAn aromatic gum resin. (Ca 1:13;\n4:6,\n14;\n5:1,\n13\n) Its precise source in ancient times is uncertain. But generally myrrh is the resin obtained from various thorny shrubs or small trees of the genus Commiphora, such as Commiphora myrrha or Commiphora abyssinica. These shrubs thrive in rocky areas, particularly on limestone hills. Their wood and bark have a strong odor. Although the resin exudes by itself from the stem or from the thick and stiff branches of either variety, the flow can be increased by means of incisions. Initially the resin is soft and sticky but, upon dripping to the ground, it hardens.\nMyrrh was one of the ingredients for the holy anointing oil. (Ex 30:23-25\n) Esteemed for its fragrance, it was used to scent garments, beds, and other items. (Compare Ps 45:8;\nPr 7:17;\nCa 3:6, 7\n.) The Shulammite maiden of The Song of Solomon appears to have applied liquid myrrh to her body before retiring for the night. (Ca 5:2,\n5\n) Massages with oil of myrrh were included in the special beauty treatment given to Esther. (Es 2:12\n) Myrrh was also one of the substances employed in preparing bodies for burial. (Joh 19:39, 40\n) It was apparently viewed as having sufficient value to be presented as a gift to one born king of the Jews.\u2014Mt 2:1, 2,\n11\n.\nTo research any Bible topic, click here", "Anyone who get hold of it.\nMyrrh was a very valuable product in the Roman Empire and very expensive as well. As I recall from having read what Goethe had to say about it, at one point the conversation came around to Goethe\u2019s Werther, which Napol\u00e9on apparently had read closely, and voiced some reservations that one passage in the book was \u201cnot natural,\u201d which Goethe conceded, but claimed the right of a writer\u2019s license for poetic artifice. This was apparently the meeting where Napol\u00e9on is supposed to have said, \u201cLe destin, c\u2019est la politique\u201d as reported by Goethe.\nLater, on 6 October 1808, Napol\u00e9on met Goethe and Wieland in Weimar, but there are no details about their conversation from Goethe. (Apparently, Wieland wrote something about it after the fact, but Goethe did not.) About a week later (14 October 1808), Napol\u00e9on awarded both the Cross of the Legion of Honour.\nIncidentally, the meeting between Goethe and Napol\u00e9on occurs as a sort of flashback in Thomas Mann\u2019s novel Lotte in Weimar. It is not precisely a mystery.\nGoethe was probably at that time the most famous literary figure in Europe, and his work \u2014 particularly Werther \u2014 were enormously popular and influential. Wieland was German literature\u2019s elder statesman, and well-known and regarded in his own right; he wrote the Bildungsroman Geschichte des Agathon and the play Oberon, both of which were popular. At one point, Napol\u00e9on called Wieland \u201cThe German Voltaire.\u201d\nI am not sure what the point of this question was. It was not at all unusual to be a fan of Goethe back in the day, and it crossed international boundaries. And Napol\u00e9on was an intelligent fellow, and pretty well-educated and interested in many things. In addition, Napol\u00e9on was not unaware of the public relations benefits to be obtained to have himself seen as being on good terms with the giants of German literature. I am not saying he was uninterested in meeting them, but it\u2019s a mistake to think of Napol\u00e9on as a fan. Think of everything he did as partly politically-motivated.\nSo my summary answer to the querent\u2019s question is, \u201cYeah, so what?\u201d\nAs Emperor, Napol\u00e9on met and spoke with a lot of people of cultural, artistic, and scientific importance. There were some famous exchanges with Lagrange and Laplace, for example, and he was rumoured to be quite interested in maths."], "topic_list": ["Christoph Martin Wieland", "Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (author)", "Literature of Germany", "Napoleon Bonaparte", "History of France", "France", "Literature", "Germany", "History"], "view_list": [135], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "T.C.A. The pattern is global because World War II rebooted most societies. Some societies were not rebooted, such as China and South America, and so they don't follow the pattern. Rather they have their own pattern.\nMy model from 2015 predicted that the dictatorship period will be sustained, and that's exactly what happened in 2020 when the dictators actually grew stronger: The Ideology Matrix\nSo if you see your society suddenly descending into dictatorship despite your best efforts to prevent it, know that it is a natural phase. A person ignorant of social cycles will go against the natural tyranny without achieving anything. Proof is that despite all the protests against Trump from 2016, he is still in power.\nThere is a proper time to go against tyranny, just as there is a proper time to go against an oligarchy or communism (democratic mob rule), but the time is not now (or rather, the time has passed).\nIgnorance of social cycles is like ignorance of the seasons. If you plant crops in the winter time or wear winter clothes in the summer heat, then you naturally get failure and pain. But if you time your activity at the proper season, then it will succeed with far less effort. "topic_list": ["Roman Empire", "Ancient Rome", "Ancient History", "History"], "view_list": [0], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Arika Srinivas", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What is the great Roman history?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "229", "name_list": ["Arpit Kumar"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"]}, "421": {"ans_list": ["What made the Praetorian Guard elite was that they protected the Emperor and were one of the few military forces allowed in Rome along with the Urban Cohorts and the Vigiles. In most cases, they used similar equipment to the main army.\nMiniArt 1/16 Praetorian Guardsman\nMy answer to Is there any record of what regular legionnaires in the Roman army thought about the Praetorian guard? includes a quote from the Rhine Muntineers:\nDo the Praetorian cohorts, which have just got their two denarii per man, and who after 16 years are restored to their homes, encounter more perils? We do not disparage the guards of the capital; still, here amid barbarous tribes we have to face the enemy from our tents.\nAs you can see, the regular army in the early empire had a rather low opinion of the Praetorian Guard [Matyszak, 2011, p47].\nHere are the people who kept Rome safe (or at least less unsafe):\nRoman Vigiles with a thief. Vigile along with the many other guard forces employed by the emperor's, including Prea\u2026 | Roman and Byzantine Civilization | Ancient rome, Ancient pompeii, Classical antiquity\nIn fact, the Guard were a bunch of troublemakers. According to Philip Matyszak (who as you can see wrote two of the sources I\u2019m using), the Guard had a poor reputation when it was a respectable military unit in 14, but by 200 it seems the people of Rome saw them as breakers of law rather than enforcers, not to mention useless at a military role, but the Urban Cohorts and the Vigiles still had the confidence of the public. Indeed, the Urban Cohorts protected the people from the Guard when Commodus ordered them to attack the citizens. [Matyszak, 2007, pp71\u201374].\nEven so, the early emperors did not have the Guard protect them closely. Emperors until Galba had Germans protect them as they had no political loyalties to anyone else in Rome. However, Galba did not trust them, so disbanded them [Webster, 1985, pp101\u2013102].\nQuora user Jeffrey Dubiel had the right idea about the Praetorians\u2019 special status:\nI see things haven\u2019t changed much. Those closest to the boss, in this case the emperor, get the goodies, while those at the tip of the spear also get the shaft as well.\nAnd as I said:\nIndeed. Of course, those closest to the boss are the ones most capable of stabbing the boss to death\u2026\nIn terms of equipment, the Guard often had the same weapons and armour as everyone else, though received new developments first. Things changed in the 3rd century when they received ceremonial scale armour [Barker 1981, pp63\u201365].\nHowever, your question has raised an interesting point. Was there a force within the Roman army comparable to modern special forces? Who would be the SAS or SEALs of the classical world? I\u2019ve looked around and the definitions I\u2019ve found for special forces are units that perform special operations (very helpful, I know). Special operations are tasks that normal soldiers would not normally do, are extremely intense, or don\u2019t follow the usual rulebook. It is not enough to simply be better than everyone else, there has to be a special role.\nIn terms of units that performed special tasks, the Romans in the Dacian Wars had special units designed to take out enemy falxmen or more likely were the only ones lucky enough to receive the new equipment. Falxes were vicious weapons that could cut through anything unarmoured, so the natural response was to give certain soldiers more armour [Ibid, p64] [Matyszak, 2011, pp108\u2013109].\nDacian Shield and Sword ~ The Dacian Wars\nAndrea Miniatures: Classics In 90MM - Roman Legionary, Darcian Wars, 101-102 AD\nThe toruble is that everyone I can think of turns out to be elite at best rather than special. Roman auxiliaries who engaged in low-intensity warfare or scouting were simply doing what armies had done for a long time, well within the bounds of convention. The cataphracts in the later army were just doing what the enemy had done as part of conventional tactics.\nHowever, there may be a group of people who could be considered Roman special forces. I only found one source for them, Phil Barker\u2019s source from 1981, but they sound good. In what Phil Barker calls the 2nd and 3rd Century Modifications, Vegetius said that the Legions now had light infantry integrated into their ranks.\nEarlier, Barker says that Arrian is his contemporary text Order of Battle Against the Alans mentioned legion light infantry, that there was a figure on Trajan\u2019s Column who could represent them, and that they seemed to fit the existing legion organisation rather than be in addition to those already there.\nThere are also sources that there was a group called the Lanciarii who may have used the cavalry Lancea spear and wore less armour. The Lancea was a light spear better at thrusting than the pilum. It seems that Lanciarii. Whatever the case, Lanciarii often worked on independent missions, though Barker has not provided any examples. However, he does say that Ammianus and Vegetius mentioned groups called the Ferentarii and Exculcatores who darted out of a legion's ranks to pursue the enemy [Barker, 1981, pp10\u201312, 70].\nI\u2019ve found a mention of them in the Battles of Antioch and Adrianople, though the source for Adrianople says that by 378 they were no longer the original light infantry [Jacobsen, 2017]. It seems that they drifted from their original role. Maybe the Fentarii took over the light role in battle and elsewhere. When they were in their original role, perhaps the stuff they did wasn\u2019t the sort authors at the time recorded.\nPhil Barker (1981), The Armies and Enemies of Imperial Rome, (Printed in Sussex: Wargames Research Group)\nBarry Jacobsen (2017), ADRIANOPLE: TWILIGHT OF THE LEGIONS, The Deadliest Blogger: Military History Page, ADRIANOPLE: TWILIGHT OF THE LEGIONS, accessed 30/04/2020\nPhilip Matyszak (2007) Ancient Rome on Five Denarii a Day (London: Thames and Hudson Ltd)\nPhilip Matyszak (2011) Legionary (London: Thames and Hudson Ltd)\nGraham Webster (1985) The Roman Imperial Army (London: A & C Black (Publishers) Ltd)", "Nothing really. They were not fully trusted. Tiberius kept small African and German Guard units to watch the praetorians. Claudius was made emperor by them and Nero kept 2 legions near Rome to counterbalance the praetorians.", "No they are not the equivalent to moderns special forces.\nThey are more like the Secret Service, o r the Dignitary Protection Forces of other countries, whose sole job is dignitary protection.\nThey were considered \u201celite\u201d because they were hand picked VETERAN\u2019S, who had survived at least one battle, and had shown they were capable fighting men.\nThey also came form \u201celite\u201d noble families, and generally came from privilege which probably means they could read and write.", "No, they werre not the equivalent of SEALS or SAS or GSG9. The problem of Praetorianism is inherently insoluble, by the way.", "They were assigned to protect the emperor and his government.", "Uniform design. Yes they possibly were like SF. Why do we remember him in Indian history?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "275", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "721": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Brands and Branding", "Online Advertising", "Advertising and Advertisements", "Marketing", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Reed Adalgiso", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Over the last 100 years, who do you see as the best advertisers\u2014as in the people behind the brands?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "250", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "844": {"ans_list": ["Rollie Fingers\nSorry im an Oaktown fan through and through so I have a wee bias, but you have to admit these are some killer moustaches!\nBen Davidson"], "topic_list": ["History of Sports", "Mustaches", "Sports", "History"], "view_list": [0], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Kris Craig", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "Who has the most epic mustache in sports history?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "2,276", "name_list": ["Noah Lehman"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"]}, "211": {"ans_list": ["I think we can answer this question relatively simply. Two world Wars and the American desire for free trade.\nIn 1914 there is little argument that Great Britain dominated global finances, Britain\u2019s main allies in the war France and Russia were more or less unable to pay the full costs of the war and Britain was forced to aid them financially unsurprisingly Britain, came out of World War One with a mountain of debt.\nGiven a significant period of peace its likely that Great Britain would have recovered, but as World War Two broke out in 1939 that recovery simply hadn\u2019t happened and Britains financial situation got worsened, this situation was exacerbated by the fact that almost all of Great Britain's war debt was held by the United States.\nIt is important to understand that an empire is rarely financially viable, the costs of running an empire are significant and it those costs get greater the larger it is. The British Empire was rarely planned, much of the expansion was driven at the periphery rather than by any government decision, so prudent financial decisions as to whether the expansion was sensible rarely factored into its growth. The British Empire\u2019s continued survival was based on Britain\u2019s ability to maintain closed and captive markets, this meant parts of the empire could only buy and sell from Britain or other parts of the empire (typically with Britain as the middle man getting a cut) and at prices dictated by Britain.\nSo India might be made to produce cotton which it could only sell to Great Britain at what would be lower than the market price, Cotton mills in Great Britain would then create clothing cheaply with subsidised cotton and then sell those clothes back to the rest of the empire (including India) at controlled and inflated prices. America might have cheaper clothes to sell but as the British empire was largely a closed market American industry would simply not be allowed to sell its products there.\nOne of America\u2019s post-war conditions to Great Britain as her principal debt holder and financier (Britain by 1945 was nearly bankrupt, so reliant on US loans) was that these closed markets be opened up, as a result, the Empire became a financial burden on Great Britain rather than a financial engine at which point its days were numbered.", "I would only opine that there may be greater glory now, when not ruling others against their consent.", "The British Empire was once the greatest empire to ever have existed, but now it is a shadow of its former glory. What were the most important factors in the empires decline? Were they forced, or was it their own doing which caused it?\nSo much is wrong with this question.\nNeither. The conditions that allowed the British Empire to exist changed, so it ceased to exist. This is what has happened to every empire that has ended and, hopefully, will happen to those that still exist.", "World War 1 started the countdown, but Britain had been losing strength starting in the late 19th century.\nThe Dominions\nThe Dominions were the first to go for the exits. They won, in a series of Imperial Conferences\n, de facto independence from the Empire. The Balfour Declaration of 1926\nand later Statute of Westminster 1931\nsealed the deal and also killed the last gasp for British control over the Dominions in the Imperial Federation\nidea.\nThey would all (except Ireland) still fight for Britain occasionally, most importantly in the Second World War, but after that it was over. With the exception of South Africa, all of the Dominions got swept into the American sphere of influence after WW2.\nEconomic Competition\nThere\u2019s also the fact that starting in the late 19th century, British commercial and industrial dominance was being challenged everywhere, but especially by America and Germany. The temporary block against Germany after WW1 simply expanded America\u2019s economic reach around the world -it did no real economic favors for Britain. Indeed, British assets around the world were liquidated to pay for that war, assets which the Americans scooped up on the cheap. WW2 accelerated that trend.\nIn addition, Britain had started losing its industrial edge by the 1870s. The US economy overtook Britain\u2019s around that time, while the unification of Germany created a new industrial powerhouse -not to mention the other powers that were industrializing at a rapid clip, particularly Russia and Japan.\nGeopolitical Competition\nIn the early to mid 19th Century, Britain could more or less do what they wanted globally with little competition. Everyone else was recovering from the Napoleonic Wars, or was no threat at all.\nBy the late 19th, that had ended. North America and the Caribbean were essentially Washington\u2019s playground by the end of the Spanish-American War, and Britain often made concessions on this front to America. In Central Asia, Britain found itself engaged in the \u201cGreat Game\u201d with Russia, while in Africa Britain found itself at odds with its old foe France. In East Asia Japan was a rising power that couldn\u2019t be ignored, while of course, in Europe, there was Germany.\nThat Germany ended up being the mortal threat is often taken for granted as inevitable today, but it could\u2019ve been either of these powers or a combination of them. Indeed, Japan would be just that in WW2 to an extent, and it was America in the end that basically absorbed the Empire. The important thing is that Britain was facing lots of threats from around the world, often at similar times, and unlike the post-Napoleonic Wars era it wasn\u2019t a sure bet that Britain could head them off.\nA Much Weaker Empire\nThe British Empire going into World War 2 was a far more decentralized, poorer, overstretched entity than it was at any time prior. There was basically no way such an entity could survive that war.\nBut even pre-World War 1 the British Empire was already being challenged across the world across all fronts -technological, military, geopolitical. It was able to head off most of these challenges using skillful diplomacy -ceding primacy in the Americas and Caribbean to the USA, containing (and then allying with) France and Russia, allying with Japan. It was very close, with very fast footwork, but it worked.\nThere was just one power left to negotiate with, and then Britain could enjoy an empire on which the sun would never set.\nUnfortunately, that one remaining power was Germany, a militaristic revisionist power that desperately wanted its own place in the sun.\nThe First World War knocked Germany down a peg, but Britain was practically made bankrupt by fighting it. After this war the Empire started to slowly drift apart, starting with the Dominions, though no one really realized it yet. The economy was moribund. The colonized people -especially India and Ireland- were restless; Ireland even got out entirely. Egypt had to be spun off (although still under tight British influence). The empire was fading but as most of the world was doing much, much worse, few really took note.\nUntested Weakness\nThe only reason it survived up to the middle of the 20th century is because up until 1939 no one challenged it. British warplanners, for example, noted in 1924 that the absolute best case scenario for a war against the United States would be a stalemate, and even there they realized they couldn\u2019t defend Canada, stalemate or no.\nWhen Britain was actually threatened by strong powers (Germany, Japan) they basically collapsed and had to be bailed out (in the military and economic sense) by the USA. The Empire simply had nothing left in the tank by 1939. They could defend, yes, but only the Home Islands and parts of Africa. Everything else was basically on its own -in fact resources were stripped from elsewhere for exactly this purpose, further driving away the Dominions. In fact Australia had to break with Britain over this policy and force the recall of their troops back home against British insistence, yet another nail in the Imperial coffin. The interests of the Dominions and Britain were diverging. Britain could no longer defend them.\nAmerican loans and supply (and eventually direct military support) propped up the Empire throughout the war, while the German struggle against the USSR took off some pressure. In East Asia the British basically had to cede the entire war theater to the Americans.\nPostwar reflected this reality, as the UK and its dominions were swept into the American sphere of influence -the cost of the bailout. The Suez Crisis\nand Britain\u2019s humiliation in that crisis was simply the new geopolitical reality made visible for all to see. Now the UK and its former Dominions (bar South Africa and Ireland) are tied into American military and intelligence networks, like Five Eyes.\nWas it Britain\u2019s own doing?\nNot really. Well, you can point to bad decisions they made sure, but when it comes down to it no empire is eternal. It was less about Britain and more that it was time for sunset.\nEveryone thinks they\u2019ll sit on the throne forever.", "You will find that you can google the answer to this!!", "This has been answered so many times. Look, times change! Physical Empires don\u2019t exist anymore, economic ones maybe, but colonial powers do not. This is down to modern trade and communication.\nNo one on the U.K. wants a return to the days of Empire. Basically, post WW1 and then WW2. A rise in nationalism, a rise in post-war economics. Primarily, it was to expensive to maintain.\nIt\u2019s legacy was the Commonwealth. One of the greatest alliance Of countries ever!", "To a large extent it was the homeland that caused it. There were 2 levels of the British Empire when I was a small boy. The self governing dominions of Canada, Australia and New Zealand, and the rest which were mainly colonies at a lower level. The British government made little effort to help the latter to achieve local democracy, and hence national independence movements flourished. The classic examples were Ireland and India.", "This is established history and has also been answered well on Quora many times so I won\u2019t reiterate the wealth of information which is out there.\nBasically WW1 and WW2 are what did it. Forced or our own doing? Well that\u2019s at least slightly subjective. Essentially our own doing since we could have reneged on agreements made with other nations and sat happy whilst friendly nations were annexed. But assuming a degree of honour and integrity, then yes \u2018forced\u2019 by agreements made and unfolding hostile events.\nBritain had also long recognised the threat of a single dominant power on the continent, so there were some practical long term considerations for ourselves and for the globe too. At the time of holding the role of \u2018world policeman\u2019 it wasn\u2019t really possible to turn a blind eye, even though the consequences were disastrous for the UK.", "A number of factors were involved in the fall of the British empire. The cost of WW2 which was huge. Many call it \u201cCorona virus\u201d but that is very vague, there are loads of corona viruses, most of them kind of harmless.\nThe correct terms are SARS-CoV-2 for the virus, and COVID-19 for the disease the virus causes. The \u201c19\u201d refers to the year of discovery, 2019, not that there have been 18 COVIDs before it.", "Nobody\u2019s \u201ccalled this pandemic \u2018Corona\u2019\u201d. Well, people have but usually as a sort of nickname.\nCovid is caused by a virus which belongs to a family known as coronaviruses. They\u2019re called that because of their appearance, which people decided look like the \u201ccorona\u201d around the sun, that sort of \u201cring\u201d it has.\nNow, there are multiple coronaviruses out there. They cause colds, usually, so it\u2019s a reasonable bet that you\u2019ve had a cold caused by a coronavirus before. So simply terming this \u201ccoronavirus\u201d is unhelpful, since the pandemic is being caused by one individual coronavirus.\nScientists have named the specific virus involved here \u201cSARS-CoV-2\u201d. That\u2019s (insofar as I know) because it\u2019s related to the virus which caused SARS - or \u201cSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome\u201d - a decade or so ago. The \u201cCoV\u201d part means \u201cCoronavirus\u201d, and the \u201c2\u201d is because it\u2019s the second such virus in that family, the first one being the SARS virus itself.\nThe virus causes a disease, which has been named \u201cCovid-19\u201d. That\u2019s short for \u201cCoronavirus Disease of 2019\u201d, by the way. You\u2019ll often hear people calling the disease \u201ccovid\u201d in passing.\nPeople calling it \u201ccorona\u201d have concluded (rightly) that \u201ccoronavirus\u201d is more of a mouthful, but forgotten or not known that there are other coronaviruses out there in circulation. COVID-19.\nThe virus (which is named SARS-CoV-2) is a type of corona virus that is related to the virus that causes SARS, which is why it has that name.\nCorona viruses have their name because the surface of the virus, when viewed under a high-powered microscope, is spiked. This reminded some of the researchers of a crown. The Latin word for crown is coronam. For instance, most of what we know of Egypt\u2019s predynastic period (and even early dynastic period) is the result of archaeology. From this we know there was (before the unification of Egypt) a king \u2018Scorpio\u2019 from a macehead depicting said king with the image of a scorpion where his name might be. We know there was a king, but we don\u2019t know his exact name. So is that history or prehistory?\nOn the other hand, the entire history of the Indus Valley civilization is known from archaeology only, simply becasue nobody has been unable to decipher their language. Now the G8 is a G7.", "Group of Eight, formerly and subsequently Group of 7 (G7), intergovernmental organization that originated in 1975 through informal summit meetings of the leaders of the world\u2019s leading industrialized countries (the\nUnited States\n, the\nUnited Kingdom\n,\nFrance\n,\nWest Germany\n,\nItaly\n,\nCanada\n, and\nJapan\n). Canada did not attend the initial meeting in 1975, and the president of the\nEuropean Commission\njoined the discussions in 1977. Originally the name evolved from the Hebrew name of Ham, the son of Noah from the Torah and Biblical tales of the world encompassing flood. It became Hamon. It is one of the few personal names which changed from a first name to a surname. In popular myth, Hamon was thought to have a meant \u2018sun burnt\u2019 or \u2018dark,\u2019 however scholarly translators believe this was a mistake and the surname of Hamlin, means \u2018home.\u2019 Ham is listed as the father to western Asia, and Africa according to the bible. It is also a name which garnered popularity with early crusaders returning from the holy land.\u201d\nMore recent origin story:\n\u201cThe first recorded instance of the surname being used, as a surname in England, was 1219 in the Devonshire tax census rolls of 1219. The next appearance of Hamlin, is in Germany in the Lower-Saxony village of Hamlin, where they commemorate the story of the \u201cPied Piper of Hamlin.\u201d Local records show the story had some grain of truth, and was placed into the stained glass windows of the local church in 1300. The church did suffer a fire in the 17th century, but there is ample documentation recording their existence. The Hamlyn surname is originally from Widecombe and Buckfastleigh, Richard Hamlyn received or purchased two manors at those two locations. The Hamlyn family during the medieval period were land owning farmers and, who were also soldiers, often referred to as English Yeomanry.\u201d\nSource and more information: Hamlin Coat of Arms", "User-submitted surname Hamlin - Behind the Name\nAccording to this site, it\u2019s from Old English and means \"home\" or \"homestead\" with the diminutive suffix -lin.", "The name Hamlin is very rare - in fact I\u2019ve never met anybody with that name - but Edward Mac Lysaght says that it was prominent in Co Meath from the 13th to the 18th centuries. There are townlands called Hamlinstown in both Meath & Louth, presumably called after the family. It\u2019s probably of Anglo Norman origin. The war was not a second revolution, but it represents a continuation of some of the issues left over from the Revolution. It was the violent culmination of years of disputes over British violations of American sovereignty and British attempts to impose controls over American foreign policy and trade. During the Napoleonic Wars a major British priority was interdicting trade with France. As part of these policies, the British government issued a series of decrees which effectively crippled American trade with Europe. Britain regularly boarded American ships, kidnapped American sailors under the guise that they were British subjects or deserters from the Royal Navy, and even seized cargoes. The resulting economic harm from British trade policy and the violations of American sovereignty created massive anger among many Americans, pushing the U.S. into war. It is arguable that the War of 1812 represented the possibility for the British to crush the U.S. and reimpose imperial rule, however the British never took this route.", "Source: The Second War for American Independence [ushistory.org]\n\u201cThe former period had strong ties to the more hierarchical colonial world of the 18th century, while post-war developments would move in dynamic new directions that contributed to a more autonomous American society and culture.\u201d\nBefore The war we were a sovereign nation with a British colonial culture. As soon as Elizabeth became the English Queen, she curried favour with Philip II of Spain, who certainly did not want the English throne being handed to Mary, causing Spain\u2019s conduit to the Low Countries to be threatened from both sides of the English Channel. With both Spain and France being exhausted by war, neither of them was in a position to embark on all out conflict for the English throne, which the other would be forced to oppose.\nCatherine de Medici\u2019s great fear was that Mary, once returned to Scotland, would arrange to marry Philip II\u2019s son, Don Carlos, so that she could lay claim to the English throne. Nevertheless, she remained unaware that he was mentally unstable. In 1564, she attempted to divert this threat by offering the 13-year-old Charles IX as a husband for Elizabeth, who was 30, but this was never going to succeed. Luckily for her, Philip II removed Don Carlos from contention by locking him away. Catherine who was personally politically moderate, still had to cope with differing factions within France who at various times forced her to take either an Ultra-Catholic or more Humanist stance in French Government, so that at different periods her political stance was either more or less threatening to Protestant England.\nThe English Government was determined to ensure England\u2019s security by pushing Elizabeth into a political marriage, but she did not initially play to their tune. She still hoped to extend her long running romance with Lord Robert Dudley, who the Government considered unacceptable as her consort. The fear was that their marriage would lead to France and Spain combining in a Counter Reformation to depose her. Her remedy was to provide underhand support for the Huguenot rebels in France and the Protestant rebels in the Low Countries, to keep both France and Spain focused on their domestic difficulties. In the end, she came to an unwritten agreement with Catherine de Medici that England would stop interfering on behalf of the Huguenots, and the French would not seek to place Mary Queen of Scots on the English throne.\nNevertheless the English Government still wanted Elizabeth to make a political marriage to provide protection from one or other of the super powers. Unfortunately the French did not have a Royal Prince of appropriate age to become Elizabeth\u2019s spouse, but the Habsburgs could offer the Archdukes Ferdinand and Charles of Austria, and even their elder brother, the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian. Elizabeth played along with these suits, but remained besotted with Lord Robert Dudley, and did her best to undermine her Government\u2019s plans. This of course rather suited the French.\nThis rather complicated balancing act was put in danger by Pope Pius V. Elizabeth had stamped heavily on an English Catholic rebellion, the Northern Rising, in 1569. This had been designed to place Mary Queen of Scots on the English throne (having arranged her marriage to the Duke of Norfolk). Elizabeth\u2019s action caused the Pope to publish a papal bull, Regnans in Excelsis, which excommunicated her. This was strongly opposed by both the French and the Spanish.\nThe various marriage suits rumbled on until Catherine promoted her youngest son, Francis, Duke of Alencon (later Duke of Anjou) to become Elizabeth\u2019s husband in a final attempt to thwart a Habsburg match. By this time, Lord Robert\u2019s eyes had wandered elsewhere, and Elizabeth played along with the Anjou match, so that she could maintain a French alliance as she developed her plan for an invasion of the Low Countries. The death of Anjou ended this alliance and led to Elizabeth\u2019s worst nightmare. The Spanish launched its Armada against England in 1588, in the knowledge that France would remain neutral. With the Armada being defeated, England returned to its policy of support for the Huguenots until the Huguenot Henry of Navarre inherited the French throne and ended the civil war in France by becoming Catholic. Wars have tended to make this even worse. If we use the American Civil War as an example, of the 620,000 to 750,000 who died, two thirds died from disease. This ratio is reasonably consistent with other wars for several reasons.\nMen are bunched together for training from various areas. Before widespread vaccinations, measles, small pox, and other diseases would spread throughout a regiment or Brigade. Between a quarter and half of the thousand men in a regiment died before first combat.\nPersonal hygiene and bathing was very limited. Fleas and lice often infested the men's bodies and caused diseases.\nUntil the 1870s disease transmission from polluted water passed cholera and typhoid fever. In many cases, water was polluted by human waste upstream, or human waste not being properly disposed of.\nBecause doctors did not know about Germ transmission until the 1870s, doctors often treated wounds with dirty, bacteria laden hands. Thousands of soldiers died from infected wounds.\nCombat frequently leaves dead human bodies scattered around the landscape. Bodies that decompose in or near water sources can pollute them.\nModern warfare is often aimed at disabling the infrastructure of the enemy. Without electricity, refrigation is impossible, this leads to contaminated food, and potential food borne diseases. Without electricity, running water, or natural gas, hygiene disintegrates, cooking of food stops, leading to famine, and losses from disease. Those kinds of conditions occurred in Germany and Japan under heavy aerial bombardment during World War II.\nI hope this helps.", "Short answer. Logically, wars normally lead to having more people die. The rate of human disease infection or those getting sick would not affect those directly killed as combatants or non-combatants in war.
