If you are interested in this subject matter then please read completely! I can assure you that you won\u2019t be disappointed.\nPART 1 \u2013 ARTICLE BY PROF. M.S. BHATNAGAR\nPART 2 \u2013 IT\u2019S ORIGIN AND VERY IMPORTANT DETAILS.\nBTW, DID YOU KNOW?\n\nIn Arabic \u201cQutub\u201d literally means \u2018axis\u2019, \u2018pivot\u2019 or \u2018pole\u2019. Qutb can refer to celestial movements and used as an astronomical term or a spiritual symbol. So the term \u2018Qutub Minar\u2019 signifies an astronomical Tower. That was how it was described to Sultan and later referred to in court correspondence. In course of time the name of Sultan Qutubuddin came to be unwittingly associated with the Qutub Tower leading to the misleading assertion that Qutubuddin built the Qutub Minar.\nPART 1.\n\n\u2013 by Prof. M.S. Bhatnagar, Ghaziabad (India)\nJune 10, 1977\nThis unique and unprecedented diagram (Fig 1) is that of the so-called QUTB MINAR. It uncovers the truth and knocks out all confusing, contradictory and fabricated explanations given by chroniclers of the Moslem Kings of Delhi and some archaeologists about the history and purpose of this lofty stone-tower.\nA visit which fostered the present research :\nIn 1961, some college students went with me to the Qutb Minar and engaged an official guide, an M.A. in History. Questions and answers between our party and the Sarkari guide are given below in brief :-\nQ. What was the purpose of building this \u2018MINAR\u2019 ?\nA. Victory Tower.\nQ. Whose victory over whom ?\nA. Md. Ghori\u2019s victory over Rai Pithaura (Prithvi Raj)\nQ. Where ?\nA. At Tarain near Panipat.\nQ. Why is the Victory Tower at Delhi ?\nA. Do not know.\nOne gentleman from the visitors, a Lecturer in History in the University of Delhi, took up the threat and answered:\nThe Victory Tower was commenced by Ghori because Delhi became his capital.\nQ. Objection, Sir! Ghori never had his capital at Delhi. His capital was at Ghazni. What logic is there in building the Victory Tower in Delhi ?\nA. Silence.\nQ. Even if the Minar was commenced by Ghori, its name ought to have been \u2018GHORI MINAR\u2019 and not \u2018QUTB MINAR\u2019. Why is it called \u2018Qutb Minar\u2019 ?\nA. It was probably Qutubuddin Aibak, slave of Ghori, who laid the foundation of the minar for his master.\nQ. If this is true, what made him choose Delhi as the site for the Victory Tower?\nA. Delhi was the capital of Qutbuddin Aibak.\nQ. It is said that the building of the Minar was commenced during the life time of Ghori. When Ghori was alive, the question of his slave\u2019s capital being at Delhi does not arise. After the death of Ghori, Qutbuddin was crowned at Sultan at Lahore. He ruled from Lahore and not Delhi and ultimately died at Lahore. His capital was at Lahore ? Why did he build the Victory Tower at Delhi ?\nA. Silence.\nSomebody from the audience asserted that the Minar was not a victory tower but a \u2018Mazina\u2019 (Muezzin\u2019s Tower in mosque) attached to \u2018Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque\u2019.\nQ. The word \u2018Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque\u2019 is unknown to contemporary history of India. This word was coined by Sir Saiyid Ahmad Khan in the first part of the nineteeth century. Do not be surprised to know that the name \u2018QUTB MINAR\u2019 too, is not known to Indian History. It is also a recent fabrication. If, for the sake of argument, we take it for granted that the minar is a muezzin\u2019s tower, the mosque assumes primary importance and the tower secondary, but unfortunately the mosque, as you see it, is in complete ruins. How do you account for the mosque of primary importance to be in ruins and the muezzin\u2019s tower, a building of no consequence, to be standing in full majesty ?\nA. No Answer.\n\u2018Masjid & Mazina\u2019 with regard to the Qutb Minar is a \u201cCOCK & BULL STORY\u201d. The so called Qutb Minar and the ruined Jama Masjid close by cannot be ascribed to the same builder. The Qutb Minar is a much older tower.\nQuranic inscriptions on the Minar\nThe Quranic inscriptions on the Minar are forced and lifeless insertions between forceful and beautiful frieze-bands of the pure HINDU DESIGN. To consider the minar of Moslem origin from the Quranic inscriptions would be labelling a non-Muslim as a Mussalman because circumcision has been forced on him.\nThe Dhruv Stambha\nThe pillars of Shri Vishnu Temple, just adjacent to the Dhruv Stambh (Qutub Minar), illuminated at night\nThe Minar is in fact the Dhurva Stambha or the central observation tower of an ancient Hindu Astronomical Observatory. Fig. 1 is based on observation from a two seater aeroplane made to hover over the top of the DHRUVA STAMBHA. The tower looks like a 24-petalled lotus flower (Fig. 2), each petal representing an \u201cHORA\u201d, i.e., an hour on a 24-hour dial (Fig. 3). Vertical projection lines drawn from the mid points of stone-flutings on the top of each storey of the tower to the horizontal plane at its base create a lotus flower similar to what can be seen from the sky over the top of the tower \u2013 bottom fig. 1. (Note : Please refer below scanned pages for reference of figures mentioned in this paragraph)\nFig. 1\nFig. 2\nFig. 3\nThe 24-petalled architectural lotus flower is purely a Hindu concept. It cannot be attributed to any Moslem king from dry parts of Western Asia where lotuses do not grow.\nYou are the proud possessor of the \u2018LOTUS\u2019 projection of the DHRUVA STAMBHA which is the result of original thinking, perseverance and expense. Such a projection was neither drawn nor conceived by any architect or archaeologist in the past. Let any body come forward and challenge the statement. Now, you can reasonably silence all those who believe the DHRUVA STAMBHA to be a production of Md. Ghori or Qutbuddin Aibak. Sultans associated with this \u2018Minar\u2019 defiled its casing, reversed stones bearing human or animal figures and inserted Arabic Inscriptions. These Sultans can, of course, be praised for not making any claim that they built the \u2018Minar\u2019. No body has left any inscription asserting that he started the Minar.\nPART 2 : Its origins\nAbout the Qutub Minar itself...(more)", "Please visit\nhttps://www.indiatoday.in/magazine/indiascope/story/19760930-qutab-minar-was-not-originally-a-hindu-monument-say-experts-819348-2015-04-11"], "topic_list": ["Qutb Minar (Monument in New Delhi, India)", "Human Psychology", "Monuments", "Controversies", "Delhi", "Historical India", "Architecture", "Mumbai, Maharashtra, India", "New Delhi", "Psychology", "History", "India"], "view_list": [39, 16], "create_time": "Jul 27, 2019", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Siddharth Das", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "What are some controversies of Qutub Minar?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "607", "name_list": ["Rani", "Dhanush Dhari Misra"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Oct 21, 2019"]}, "3": {"ans_list": ["Well, Hitler WAS the leader of the National SOCIALIST Party, so that might give you a hint about his leanings \u2026", "\u201cHow true is it when conservatives say that Hitler was a socialist, and just how much is it tolerated by real historians?\u201d\nRight - national socialist. left - Soviet socialist.\nIt shows that socialism is not even ON the left-right spectrum.\nIt also shows that Hitler was a far right socialist.\nLook, you don\u2019t want these words to mean what history says they mean. I get that. You really need to use different words. History objectively happened.", "People who say so are making a category mistake or have a problem with the common meaning of political theory. Yes fascism was a collectivist doctrine, but no it was not \u201csocialist\u201d. See Hannah Arendt\u2019s work.\nHitler took over a party that had the word \u201csocialist\u201d in its name and didn\u2019t change it; the Party had some people in it who wanted to move toward socialism but still be anti-Semitic and nationalistic but he had them killed.\nHitler allowed private enterprises to profit and remain functioning because they could generate the war materiel he wanted. He made sure there was no political freedom nor employment of Jews so Nazi power controlled every organization he could manage but he did not end free enterprise or require state ownership of all enterprises. I.e. he was not a socialist.", "Hitler was fiercely anti-communist; he called communism a Jewish invention.", "Not at all.\nHe took inspiration from Mussolini, who had been a leading socialist before World War One. But became a clear enemy of socialism on most issues.\nHitler was never even partly socialist, unlike Gregor Strasser\n, whom he had killed.\nSee also Nazis No More Socialists than Bismarck Was.", "The idea that Hitler was a socialist has become a popular talking point among more right-wing people who are keen to discredit socialism by any means necessary.\nI would like to see if we can figure out how this came about.\nThe idea has become popular because it very neatly suits the tendency of some people to treat politics and history as a matter of labels and definitions, and their parallel tendency to completely ignore history and human experience.\nI suppose I\u2019ve read quite a few reputable history books about the Third Reich, including Richard J. Evans\u2019 The Coming of the Third Reich and The Third Reich in Power; Joachim Fest\u2019s biography of Hitler, and his book of psychological profiles of the Nazi leaders, The Face of the Third Reich; Ian Kershaw\u2019s The Hitler Myth and his two-volume biography of Hitler, Hubris and Nemesis.\nI\u2019ve also read works which have since been superseded, such as Lucy Dawidowicz\u2019s The War Against the Jews, 1933\u20131945, which argued that Hitler\u2019s long-term plan from the beginning had been to exterminate the Jewish people, and that everything else he did was done with that plan in mind\u2014an argument which founders somewhat on the considerable body of evidence that there was no such long-term plan in mind from the beginning, other than Hitler saying that he wanted to do it, which isn\u2019t quite the same thing; and that the evidence for the very real plan to exterminate the European Jews all dates not from the earliest years of the Reich but from within WW2, and (to be sure) was made easier by the habits of anti-semitism that Dawidowicz spent her long career deploring.\nI\u2019ve also read a considerable number of writers from that period, including English-language ones such as George Orwell, W.H. Auden and T.S. Eliot, all of whom had things to say about the nature of Nazism and Hitler, and German-language ones as diverse as Victor Klemperer, a literary academic of Jewish background who managed to survive the war within Germany; Ernst J\u00fcnger, a conservative non-Nazi who\u2019d been a war hero in WW1 and who spent the war as a Wehrmacht officer in occupied France; and Walter Benjamin, a Jewish literary critic and philosopher with Marxist inclinations who observed the rise of Nazism and died while trying to flee from it.\nAnd I\u2019ve even read lesser-known writers of the era who had personal experience of Germany and felt a certain fondness for the place, such as the poet and novelist Stevie Smith and my own grandfather, the playwright and broadcaster Denis Johnston. In my grandfather\u2019s case, he was to a certain degree unwilling to think that there was anything so intrinsically wrong with a movement of national renewal\u2014until, that is, he saw the interior of Buchenwald concentration camp after its liberation.\nOne of the reasons I\u2019ve read all these is that, when studying history, it helps to know what people at the time thought was going on. Other than Hitler himself, certainly.\nAnd one of the common threads in people\u2019s experience is that, at the time, nobody had any great difficulty distinguishing between, on the one hand, Hitler and the Nazi Party, and, on the other hand, socialism in Germany. This is one of the basic facts of German history as presented in the works listed above.\nT.S. Eliot, who in the 1930s was at his most sternly conservative as a writer, might be thought to be someone who could have felt some sympathy towards the Nazis, especially given some of the more notorious lines in his poetry about \u2018the jew\u2019, and his comment in a lecture in a US university that large numbers of \u2018free-thinking Jews\u2019 were \u2018undesirable\u2019. But we might also well expect that Eliot would be staunchly anti-socialist.\nHere he is writing in 1935 to his cousin Henry Eliot Scott (from volume 7 of The Letters of T.S. Eliot. This is before the war, remember:\nI was much interested by your enquiry of the 19th, particularly as I had supposed that there was hardly any interest in America in any of the forms of fascism. It is not easy to express briefly any general opinion on fascism, because it varies so much from country to country. At any rate, the Italian and German versions differ considerably, and it seems to be of the nature of fascism to develop its theories after it has become established. At any rate, that was the case in Italy, where it apparently endeavoured to find a basis of political philosophy in the work of Pareto and Sorel. In Germany, on the other hand, it seems to have started with a few definite ideas of an agrarian and guild socialist type, which have disappeared into the background as the National Socialist Party has got more and more closely associated with big capital.\nEliot says here what we know, from the historical record, to be true: the German Workers Party, the forerunner of the Nazi Party, contained socialist elements in its platform, which were later expunged when Hitler and his faction took control of the party in 1934. Hitler regarded Italian fascism and Nazism as two forms of fascism, not as forms of socialism, which he thought Nazism had at first embraced, and had then dropped. The Nazi party could not have gained power, and did not gain it, without the support of the business classes in Germany. Eliot had a keen interest in foreign affairs, having worked for eight years on the foreign accounts desk at Lloyds Bank in London.\nThe Nazis aligned themselves in opposition to the two political parties in Germany that did espouse socialism as an ideology: the Social Democrat Party, and the Communist Party of Germany. Both parties were made illegal after the Nazis gained overall power.\nThose who claim that the Nazis were socialists, are obliged to explain why this happened.\nThey usually don\u2019t respond, but inasmuch as I have seen half-hearted attempts to deal with the embarrassing fact that the Nazis declared actual socialist parties to be their mortal enemies and indeed enemies of Germany as such, it\u2019s usually along the lines that the Nazi/socialism fight was a sort of internal squabble between different socialist factions, with the Nazis coming out on top.\nTo which we can only say: Nobody thought so at the time, especially not the many social democrat, socialist and communist politicians and party members who the Nazis murdered.\nAfter 1934, the ideology of the Nazi party was not socialism, but a particularly violent and exclusivist form of nationalism, organised around a very particular set of notions about ethnic purity, which dictated that only some German citizens were truly German, and therefore deserving of the benefits of citizenship, while others\u2014mostly the German Jews\u2014were not German at all but inescapably foreign, and by nature subversive of German nationhood and German national unity.\nOkay: now we get to why people are trying to make Hitler out to be something which nobody at the time thought he was, and which no reputable historian now considers him to have been.\nHitler was always on the right of the German Workers Party, and he led the right wing of the Nazi Party to victory over the socialist elements.\nHe disliked the socialist elements in the party program, partly because he was generally hostile to communism and Marxism: even one of the other answers to this question, attempting to cite Hitler\u2019s own words that he was a socialist, couldn\u2019t help quoting Hitler\u2019s own bizarre definition of \u2018socialism\u2019:\nCommunism is not Socialism. Marxism is not Socialism. The Marxians have stolen the term and confused its meaning. I shall take Socialism away from the Socialists. Socialism is an ancient Aryan, Germanic institution. Our German ancestors held certain lands in common. They cultivated the idea of the common weal. Marxism has no right to disguise itself as socialism. Socialism, unlike Marxism, does not repudiate private property. Unlike Marxism, it involves no negation of personality, and unlike Marxism, it is patriotic.\nThis is, frankly, historically illiterate nonsense. Communism is a form of socialism, and Marxism is a particular way of analysing socio-economic conditions that aligns itself against capitalism, and with forms of social ownership that are common elements of socialism as a school of thought.\nBut let\u2019s look at the date on those words.\nHitler said that in 1923.\nHe said in an interview\nwith the journalist George Sylvester Viereck, and he said it in response to Viereck\u2019s question, Why do you call yourself a National Socialist, since your party programme is the very antithesis of that commonly accredited to socialism?\nIn other words, Viereck himself found it puzzling that the Nazis called themselves National Socialists, and Hitler, by way of response, basically bullshitted him.\nIf we go forward ten years to later on Hitler\u2019s Wikiquote page, we find Hitler striking a rather different note.\nHere he is in 1932, speaking to the Industry Club, sounding more like Ayn Rand:\nThis whole edifice of civilization is in its foundations and in all its stones nothing else than the result of the creative capacity, the achievement, the intelligence, the industry, of individuals: in its greatest triumphs it represents the great crowning achievement of individual God-favored geniuses, in its average accomplishment the achievement of men of average capacity, and in its sum doubtless the result of the use of human labor-force in order to turn to account the creations of genius and of talent. So it is only natural that when the capable intelligences of a nation, which are always in a minority, are regarded only as of the same value as all the rest, then genius, capacity, the value of personality are slowly subjected to the majority and this process is then falsely named the rule of the people. For this is not rule of the people, but in reality the rule of stupidity, of mediocrity, of half-heartedness, of cowardice, of weakness, and of inadequacy\nIn 1939, he makes grand claims for how Germany has become a nation of \u2018social welfare\u2019 and \u2018social equality\u2019, but conveniently omits to mention that it has also taken away the civil rights of its Jewish citizens, forbidding them from owning businesses, work in shops, drive cars, go to the cinema, own weapons or attend schools with non-Jews. The Romani people in Germany had been shipped off to camps from as early as 1935.\nAnd still he harps on about National Socialism, at a time when he\u2019s also saying things like:\nGermany neither intends nor wishes to interfere in the internal affairs of Austria, to annex Austria, or to conclude an Anschluss.\n(Speech in the Reichstag, 21 May 1935)\nAnd:\nWe want to be a peace-loving element among the nations. We cannot repeat that often enough.\n(Speech in the Reichstag, 30 January 1936)\nAnd:\nThe motto must be, \"Never war again.\"\n(Speech in Berlin, 1 May 1938)\nIt\u2019s all very well saying that Hitler himself said he was a socialist.\nWe have to look at what he meant by saying that, and when he said it, and to who he said it; and also bear in mind that he said a shitload of other things which we can now all too clearly see, he didn\u2019t mean.\nWhy are we obliged to always take Hitler at his word?\nBy the late 30s, as a read of his Wikiquote page shows, Hitler was basically using \u2018socialism\u2019 as a synonym for \u2018totalitarianism\u2019.\nHis use of the word \u2018socialism\u2019 in no way resembles the way an actual socialist would use it.\nBut this is also the way people use it, who say that Hitler was a socialist. They have essentially adopted Hitler\u2019s definition of socialism, in order to discredit socialism as such.\nThe reason is that such people cannot tell the difference between social democracy, or socialism, and totalitarianism. To them, all the history I\u2019ve recounted in this answer is simply irrelevant. If Hitler said he was a socialist, we automatically take him at his word, and therefore socialism, however we define it, is something that Hitler would have approved of.\nWhatever these people don\u2019t like, they label \u2018socialism\u2019.\nWe\u2019ve seen with the COVID-19 pandemic how some Americans have equated social distancing, a means of preventing the spread of a highly contagious disease, with communism.\nThis is the triumph of inanity in our contemporary political discourse.\nIf the state does anything at all, it is socialism, and therefore totalitarianism, and therefore something that Hitler would do.\nWhat actually went on in the Third Reich and its territories, the things that made it so striking and so horrific\u2014the persecution of Jews, of Roma, of socialists and communists, of LGBT people; the extermination of the mentally ill and mentally disabled; the concentration camps; the Einsatzgruppen; the invasion and conquest of other sovereign countries and the plunder of their resources; the assassinations; the gas chambers\u2014all of this is irrelevant to the game of labels that these people are playing.\nThey are brushing aside millions of deaths, untold suffering of innocent people, they are painting over a vast and awful history, in the name of short-term political goals. And they seize on whatever scrap of evidence they can find to do so, and ignore the mountain that supports a very, very different point of view.\nI\u2019ll leave you with one more quote from Hitler, which may or may not serve to warn us against taking him at his word. He said it to Franz Halder, one of his generals, who was dismissed in 1942 for arguing with Hitler too much, and who sat out the end of the war in prison:\nYou will never learn what I am thinking. And those who boast most loudly that they know my thought, to such people I lie even more.", "Well, labeling people \u201cconservatives\u201d and \u201creal historians\u201d here is pretty pointless because it adds nothing to the discussion of whether National Socialism is a form of socialism.\nSome say it was\u2026and by some measures it was\u2026but by others it wasn\u2019t.\nIt\u2019s a matter of opinion, not fact. Political leanings are labels, not testable by reason, and shift with politics.", "It is true that Hitler was a socialist, going by the fact that he called his party the National Socialist Party.\nThe problem for historians is that the word \u201csocialism\u201d has many, many different meanings to different people in different contexts. For example, some people call Denmark\u2019s government \u201csocialism,\u201d but Denmark herself denies it.\nFor some readers, \u201ctrue\u201d socialism must be International only. For these readers, the phrase, \u201cNational Socialist\u201d is an oxymoron.\nYet there are many types of national socialism, and the Nazi Party is only one of those.\nWhat made the Nazi Party \u201csocialist\u201d is that Hitler\u2019s State took complete control of all economic decisions. Hitler pulled Germany out of the Great Depression by breaking the Versailles Treaty. He made Full Employment (for all white males) by building a massive war machine.\nStarting around 1933, German factories ran at full capacity building tanks, airplanes, submarines, battleships, bombs, canons, machine guns, ammunition and a 5,000 mile freeway for the tanks. Hitler increased his 100,000 man Army to a million troops, and then two million, and then three million.\nEverybody had a job guaranteed by the State. That is one legitimate definition of \u201csocialism.\u201d (The fact that \u201ceverybody\u201d was there defined as \u201cwhite males\u201d only, is another problem.)\nIt\u2019s fair to call that one version of \u201csocialism.\u201d It seemed to work great for six years, but then after you\u2019ve built up the biggest Army the world had ever seen \u2014 what do you do with it?\nHitler decided to attack another version of \u201csocialism\u201d, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and take their territory. Most Germans hated Communism, and the USSR was Communist. For some readers, Communism is the \u201ctrue\u201d socialism, because it is International.\nNazis hated Communists, and Communists hated Nazis \u2014 though they were both \u201ctechnically\u201d socialists. German National Socialism (1930\u20131945) was built upon the myth of Aryan Supremacy. Russian Soviet Socialism (1917\u20131991) was built upon the myth of Marx\u2019s Labor Theory of Value.\nBoth were built upon errors, and so both have collapsed. Yet both had a legitimate right to that very imprecise word, \u201csocialism.\u201d", "It\u2019s a right wing lie and no responsible historian has any truck with it.", "Hitler called himself a socialist. Is that good enough for you?\nSince we are socialists, we must necessarily also be antisemites because we want to fight against the very opposite: materialism and mammonism\u2026\nand\nSocialism is the science of dealing with the common weal. Communism is not Socialism. Marxism is not Socialism.\netc\nAdolf Hitler - Wikiquote", "The word NAZI means National Socialism. The government is based on socialist principles of government control over business and industry and the lives of its people. But it is different from Communist Socialism practiced by the then Soviet Union. Germany and the Soviet Union were rivals, so Soviet Communism was outlawed in Germany. Both countries had mass killings of dissidents. NAZI ism was worse, because it targeted innocent people, based on prejudice.", "How true is it when conservatives say that Hitler was a socialist,\nIt\u2019s not true, it\u2019s false. Hitler and his Nazi party hated socialists. Nor do conservatives claim this: uninformed rightwingers do, and beign rightwing doesn\u2019t make you a conservative. Case in point: Hitler.\nand just how much is it tolerated by real historians?\nHistorians (real or otherwise) tolerate lots of opinions. However, they are prone to point out that this claim is simply historically and factually inaccurate.\nIf Hitler had been a socialist, he would never have received financial support from arch-conservative capitalists. Unlike certain modern would-be conservatives, they knew exactly what Hitler and the Nazis stood for.\nThe NSDAP always was a right wing extremist party. After gaining power they imprisoned frst communists, then socialists. (And then outlawed all parties save theirs.)", "Imagine presenting a sea lion to a group of biologists and insisting that it is a lion. It must be, it's got lion in the name! And sure, if you focus in on tiny parts of its appearance and behaviour you might be able to make a meaningful (or at least not entirely nonsensical) comparison to the appearance of the corresponding part or an aspect of the behaviour of a lion. But when you look at the whole creature and insist that a semi aquatic, flipper footed pinniped is actually a big cat which abhors water you're going to get asked politely but firmly to leave.\nThe Nazis were not socialists. They locked up socialists, banned trade unions and literally killed off their socialist party members when they were no longer useful.\nA sea lion is not a lion.", "It's like pointing out that Tiny Tim was a singer as a way to denigrate singing. Hitler was a nationalist, as is trump. And he used nationalism as an excuse to turn his hatred and biases into policy, as does trump. No, trump isn't hitler. It's a matter of degree and time.", "The word \u201cSocialist\u2019 means more-or-less anything. If you ask someone its meaning, it reveals more about them then it does about the meaning of the word.\nHowever, Hitler said he was a Socialist, his party was the NSDAP, National Socialist German (Deutsche) Workers (Arbeiter) Party. What he meany by the term was a part which put the interests of the German Society above individual interests.\nIf you want to achieve anything, it is best to avoid the term \u2018Socialist\u2019 as say what your objectives are directly.\nSome (but not all) meanings of \u2018Socialism\u2019", "Here is a political compass\nHitler is in the autoritanian right and technically a socialist as he was the leader of the national socialist party", "American conservatives will say just about anything.\nThe grain of truth in it is that the Nazis had plans for wholesale nationalisation, once the Second World War was over."], "topic_list": ["Historians", "Socialism", "Adolf Hitler", "Political Conservatism", "History"], "view_list": [6, 7, 16, 8, 145, 0, 12, 34, 8, 22, 25, 70, 72, 40, 108, 61, 29], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Joe Barbaro", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 5, 0, 0, 1, 2, 2, 0, 7, 7, 0, 1, 1, 0], "question_title": "How true is it when conservatives say that Hitler was a socialist, and just how much is it tolerated by real historians?", "respond_collected": 17, "no_of_view": "2,962", "name_list": ["Jake Guthmiller", "Doug Freyburger", "Thomas Musselman", "Vahe Demirjian", "Gwydion Madawc Williams", "Alex Johnston", "John Beatty", "Paul Trejo", "Justin Schwartz", "Quentin Stephens", "John David Baxter", "Ludwig Nijholt", "Edward Smith", "Eliot Steele", "Jamie Cawley", "Ida Reeve", "Leslie Dellow"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "365": {"ans_list": ["Yes.", "Sort of, the Allies had access to plenty of it, the Axis didn\u2019t. Oil is an important part of the \u201cindustrial base\u201d component, but wasn\u2019t the single decisive factor.\nIf there was one decisive factor, it was the campaign objectives.\nThey would have been about 50% likely to win if the objectives had been limited to \u201cCreate buffer states on current Soviet territory\u201d. If they had created, and crucially, armed an independent Belarus and Ukraine, along with the Baltic states for good measure (and to limit Soviet access to the Baltic), setting them up as anti-Communist allies but otherwise essentially stayed away\u2014then yes, this could have been done. Combining their manpower and industrial base with Belarus and Ukraine, it\u2019s suddenly a toss-up.\nIf the objectives had been the considerably more ambitious \u201cDestroy Soviet Communism\u201d, in effect adding Russia to the above-mentioned states, their chances would have dropped, but not to zero. If Belarus and Ukraine had been obviously \u201cliberated from Stalin\u201d\u2014but not at the price of just replacing him with Hitler; instead, gaining actual, real freedom\u2014then it might have been possible to marshal enough discontent in Russia to have, in effect, a counter-revolution.\nBut that was never the idea. The word \u201chospital\u201d is derived from the Old French hospital (modern French h\u00f4pital), which in turn is derived from hospitalis, which is attested to in ancient sources, but they mean something somewhat different from the modern word \u201chospital.\u201d A modern hospital is a facility expressly dedicated to caring for the sick and injured, regardless of their need for long-term care; however, a pre-modern hospital fulfilled the role of homeless shelter as much as it did a modern hospital. The Ordo Fratrum Hospitalis Sancti Ioannis Hierosolymitani (Brotherhood Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, or Hospitallers) was a military order that originated around a Benedictine community that maintained a hospital built at a monastery dedicated to St. John the Baptist that had been rebuilt by Italian merchants in 1005.", "The latter."], "topic_list": ["Phrase Origins", "History of Europe", "Catholicism", "Hospitals", "Etymology", "Ancient History", "History", "Medicine and Healthcare"], "view_list": [44, 3], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Fluf Lvp", "upvote_list": [1, 0], "question_title": "Did the term hospital come from the Ordo Fratrum Hospitalis Sancti Ioannis Hierosolymitani or the other way around?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "404", "name_list": ["Erika Whelan", "Mil Yak"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "442": {"ans_list": ["Read \u201cWings over Ogaden\u201d, it's only $3 on Amazon kindle and 40 pages long. Raw unrefrigerated meat pretty much has to be eaten fresh. Cooked unrefrigerated meat will last several hours.\nBoiling, on the other hand, is a more recent development. That required a vessel that you could put in the fire that would hold water. However, before that, foods could be cooked by putting them in a skin, pottery or basket that was watertight and adding hot stones. This could get water up to 60 Celsius. Unlike the Anglo-Nomans and their descendants, the Anglo-Saxons did not number their kings. If so, what animal?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "115", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "78": {"ans_list": ["Calvin = male Latin name which means \u2018bald\u2019 example: Calvin Coolidge (1872\u20131933), 30th President of the United States \u2014 variations: Cal, Calv \u2014- family name in France: Chauvin", "In which country did the name Calvin originate?\nCalvin is a form of the French surname Cauvin, which was derived from chauve meaning \"bald.\" The form is used in Picardy and in Meridional France. The surname was borne by Jehan Cauvin (1509-1564), a French theologian born in Noyon, Picardy, who was one of the leaders of the Protestant Reformation. His surname was Latinized as Calvinus (based on Latin calvus \"bald\") and he is known as John Calvin in English. It has been used as a given name in his honour since the 19th century.\nThe surname Chauvin appears in the possibly apocryphal tale of a French soldier named Nicolas Chauvin, who was a diehard, devoted soldier famously loyal to Napoleon Bonaparte even after Bonapartism had become unpopular in Restoration France. His extreme love for the former Emperor earned him derision and mockery. His name is the eponym of chauvinism, originally a term for excessive nationalistic fervor, but later used to refer to any form of bigotry or bias, as in male chauvinism.\nThe name Calvin has been popular among American Protestants. However, in the judgement of the Oxford Dictionary of First Names, the modern given name \"owes its popularity as much to the New York fashion designer Calvin Klein.\u201d", "It\u2019s Latin - Calvinus means \u201cbald one\u201d\nSeriously! That\u2019s what my book says!", "It\u2019s Latin. The man who made the name famous actually had the surname Cauvin. It was common to Latinize the names of scholars during that time. It\u2019s mostly common among those who are French, English/Great Britain and American. More common among Reformed/Presbyterian people. The name appears frequently in my own family as we are descended from French Huguenots from Normandy and Scots among others.", "France. Jean Cauvin was one of the leaders of the Reformation; as he wrote in Latin, he latinized his name to Johannes Calvinus, and became known as Calvin. Because of his importance among Protestants, he family name was adopted as a Christian name.\nCauvin is actually the Picard (northern France dialect) form of Chauvin, which gave rise to the word \u2018chauvinism\u2019. Its Italian form is Calvino, and is a diminutive of calvo (French chauve), meaning \u2018bald\u2019."], "topic_list": ["Country Names", "Name and Naming", "Name Etymology", "Origins", "Given Names", "Surnames", "Etymology", "Countries of the World", "History"], "view_list": [58, 30, 4, 58, 87], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "C Elizabeth Blocher", "upvote_list": [1, 1, 0, 2, 3], "question_title": "What country did the name Calvin originate?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "809", "name_list": ["Axel Brosi", "Halina Minadeo", "William Uchtman", "Robert Cuminale", "Angelos Tsirimokos"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"]}, "90": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["San\u0101tana Dharma (Hinduism)", "Ancient India", "Vedas", "Ancient Hindu Epics and Literature", "History of India", "Ancient History", "Hinduism", "Religion", "History", "India"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Sameer Suman", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "How much loss has occurred to ancient Sanatana-shruti and Smriti texts from the time being written till date due to foreign influence and invasions?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "344", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "868": {"ans_list": ["Primarily it's Hitler's fault. Places became \"closer\" and more accessible. Also, the Ford Model T could go up to 40-45 mph making it easier to chase outlaws.\nWhen cows were being moved, crops were being trampled. Some farmers couldn't gather the materials for wooden fences, so barbed wire was used instead. It stopped unwanted intrusions. It became more popular and soon there wasn't very much space for settlers moving. Why did the Wild West end so quickly?", "Because most people didn\u2019t want to live in that kind of society. Technically the Wild West begins with the first traders arriving on the Atlantic Coastline back in the 1500\u2019s and carries on into the 1950\u2019s so easily 400 years. Most of it\u2019s end dates are for the convenience of historians wrapping up a chapter, theme, or entire book, i.e. the Battle of Wounded Knee in 1890, the Wisconsin history professor declaring at an 1894 conference that the West was settled, the last Western territory becoming a state in 1912 (which of course forgets Wild West Alaska which didn\u2019t become a state until 1959), and ignores the wild oil booms, the 1950\u2019s uranium boom, the 1930\u2019s outlaw gangs like Bonnie & Clyde, the Mexican Revolution from 1910\u20131923, Prohibition, Rosewood massacre by white neighbors, etc\u2026\nJust because movies mostly focus on 1865\u20131885 doesn\u2019t mean that\u2019s the real timeline.\nIf you need a laconic John Wayne answer, \u201clawyers, too many lawyers\u201d", "Duh, the Pacific Ocean, it was simply a matter of geography, no where else to go.\nOh, you weren\u2019t talking about that\u2026Oh I see, I think they killed each other into historical oblivion - things had to change, too many other things going on. There were isolated pockets where it lasted well into the Twentieth Century.", "It really didn\u2019t end all that quickly. It went through phases that started when Daniel Boone first defied British authority by exploring through the Cumberland gap.\nThe classic Wild West period about which most people think started around 1840 with wagon trains and LDS settlers heading west. It took a break for the Civil War and then had a hot period for about 35 years after, probably fueled by veterans of that war which had trouble adjusting to civilian life. Around 1900, the West started to become less wild in most parts. However, Pancho Villa was still running around until almost 1920, the last Wild West posse shootout happened near Tucson in the 1920s and the cattle drives kept going until the 1950s in some areas.\nSo that is a length of 80 to 110 years, with 35 years of hot action like the James/Younger gang, the Indian Wars (Geronimo surrendered in 1886), the Gunfight at the OK Corral, the Wild Bunch (Butch Cassidy died in 1908), The Pleasant Valley War (1892) and the rest of the cliches associated with that time period.\nTo compare the period with a more recent historical period, the Space Race really lasted less than 15 years, starting with the first Soviet satellite and ending with the moon landing. They don't get treated as 2nd class citizens.\nRacial Discrimination and Miscegenation: The Experience in Brazil | United Nations\nBrazilian and United States Slavery Compared", "This isn\u2019t a complete answer, but I think it\u2019s important to put it out there: when people say things like \u201crace isn\u2019t a biological fact, it\u2019s a social construct\u201d Brazil vs. the US is more or less the perfect case example.\nRace in the USA has changed over the years to broaden what counts as \u201cWhite\u201d or unmarked/default, but Whiteness is in many ways construed in opposition to Blackness. A generation or two ago Jews weren\u2019t considered White, but today they are. Go back a generation or two further and Irish weren\u2019t considered White, but today they are. There\u2019s some evidence that the category of Whiteness is expanding to encompass people of Latino ancestry (traditionally seen as separate from White) and even Asian ancestry. Meanwhile, even today a relatively small amount of Black ancestry causes someone to be categorized as Black by society. For example, someone with one Black grandparent and three White grandparents is likely to be categorized and identify as Black and/or mixed-race, whereas someone with one White grandparent and three Black grandparents would never be categorized as White and is even relatively unlikely to be categorized as mixed-race. Race is also seen as something genetic, heritable and immutable.\nIn Brazil, race is more fluid. It\u2019s a more based on what you look like and how you are perceived, rather than being seen as something genetic and immutable. I remember seeing a study where something like 1/8 of people changed their self-reported racial classification over the course of a few years. There\u2019s a saying that goes something like \u201cmoney makes skin Whiter\u201d \u2014 your social class impacts your perceived racial classification. There is also a bit more subtlety in terms of degrees of racial classifications. Rather than Black and White, the government officially classifies people as Black, Brown, or White (plus a few others) and most people identify as either White or Brown (roughly even split). But there\u2019s a huge richness of vocabulary and gradations of color that people use to talk about race that just dwarfs the simplistic categories used in the USA.\nAnyway, so what does this have to do with racial resentment? One major factor is that Brazil has created a national myth around the idea of being a sort of post-racial, racial democracy type of place. There\u2019s a famous book from the 1930s, Casa-Grande & Senzala (in English usually translated as The Masters and The Slaves), that was really influential in creating this type of thinking. It promoted the idea that just as Brazil had far more gradations of race due to \u201cmiscegenation\u201d, Brazil also has mixed the ancestral Portuguese, African, and Amerindian cultures into a distinctly Brazilian culture.\nBrazilian World Cup Gambling Party\nCompare that to the USA where as a society or at least in certain parts of society, there\u2019s still a lot of discomfort around accepting Black people as an integral part of the American fabric. And it is really specifically around Blackness too \u2014 remember that the \u201che\u2019s not American\u201d paranoid rhetoric around Obama wasn\u2019t due to him growing up in Indonesia, but due to him having a Kenyan father.\nGeorgia bar owner calls Obama the N-Word on a road sign again and still claims he isn\u2019t racist\nIn Brazil, discrimination against Blacks has also tended to operate at a sort of subconscious level whereas in the USA it was much more institutionalized and visible. The USA had redlining, sundown towns, poll taxes and poll tests, explicit segregation, bans on inter-racial marriage, and Jim Crow laws; most of these lasted until the 1960s de jure or even longer de facto. Brazil isn\u2019t quite the utopia of racial harmony that it is sometimes made out to be, but it has had far, far less in terms of legally enshrined discrimination.\nRace is more complicated than your question implies & Brazil has a national image around racial inclusiveness whereas whites in the USA have often enforced racial discrimination", "There\u2019s probably no chance of free money ie \u201creparations\u201d in Brazil vs the USA. This is a map of the Eastern Hemisphere c. 500 BC:\nMost of civilization was yet to develop, and the vast majority of \u201cstates\u201d were generally tribal monarchies controlled by a chieftain. The largest states were the Achaemenid Empire, an absolute monarchy controlled by the Achaemenid clan; the Zhou Dynasty in China, an other monarchy; while India and Arabia were generally made up of small kingdoms.\nThe only exceptions to this were the states of the Mediterranean basin, but there were certainly several monarchies. We like to think of Greece as a democratic civilization, but this was far from the truth. There were several monarchies in Greece- Sparta had two kings, Macedon was a monarchy, and Epirus was ruled by a king as well. A large number of \u201cdemocratic\u201d Greek city-states were really controlled by tyrants, like in Syracuse and other Sicilian city-states.\n(The Aegean sea, 450 BC)\nAnd many the so-called \u201crepublican governments\u201d in the Mediterranean basin weren\u2019t really republican. Athens and other city-states in the Delian League were the exception in that all free males held power. The others were more oligarchic in nature- the vast majority of the population had little power, and power was constricted around a ruling elite (i.e. Corinth). Carthage, for instance, was ruled by a small group of families of Phoenician descent. Even Rome, which we like to think of as democratic, was really controlled by a very small and selective group of citizens of whom a small minority (the Patricians) held equal - and later on, more - power than the majority plebeians.", "I\u2019m not sure this question is based on a sound assumption. We tend to think of Athens and the Roman Republic first and foremost because they have had such a strong influence on subsequent European culture, which has in turn exerted an out-sized influence on the entire world. In reality, kings and \u201ctyrants\u201d were the norm as far as leaders of early Greek and Italian polities were concerned. When you think of Rome\u2019s early wars, most of them are named after the kings who led the opposing forces (e.g., Mithridates, Pyrrhus, Jugurtha). The exceptions are the Punic Wars, which were waged against an empire, or the Gallic wars, which were named for their location, but involved a series of struggles against Celtic-speaking peoples, led by kings."], "topic_list": ["Republican Party (US politics)", "Government", "History"], "view_list": [188, 22], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Vineeth Bharadwaj", "upvote_list": [2, 1], "question_title": "Why were there so many republican governments during the early classical period?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "328", "name_list": ["Joseph Ward", "Richard Hurley"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"]}, "485": {"ans_list": ["Because they were arrogant, had the British gone along with some of the demands of the colonialists it is likely there would have been no revolution. Tidal effects eventually caused the Moon\u2019s rotational period to match its orbital period, a condition known as tidal locking. Those tides affected the Earth, too, slowing its rotation rate.\nEven now, the Earth\u2019s rotation rate continues to drop. Every now and again, we need to add a leap second\nto compensate for that. You might expect this would mean that the Earth would someday become tidally locked as well. It will, but by the time that happens, the Sun will be well on its way to transforming into a red giant. There\u2019s a very good chance that will mean the Earth will spiral into the enlarged Sun.", "I am going to take a SWAG at this (Scientific Wild Ass Guess), So if it is wrong, sorrryyy (Canadian here, eh :-)).\nEarth orbits sun, and of course spinning also on its axis (in the direction of orbit), once a day. Consider how random space debris affects things as they bang into the earth as it goes about its orbit(s).\nIf you fire a rock/bullet/something at the earth against its direction of motion, but hit it on the forward spinning side, and fire another the same way, but hit it on the trailing (the other) side, the amount of energy transferred will be different, due to the earth\u2019s spin. The rock hitting the earth as the earth spins into it will hit harder than the same (size, speed) rock hitting on the other side, as it is spinning away, because the collision speed will be (rock speed) + (earth spin speed) on one side, and (rock speed) - (earth spin speed) on the other, and energy is proportional to mass x speed (not getting into vectors and velocities, as that is an unnecessary complication, here).\nSo, over millions of years, random space junk hitting the earth will act to slow the earth\u2019s rotation, simply because it will hit harder on one side than the other, always acting to slow rotation. There may be (are) other factors too, but this might be the main one..\n(Would not be surprised if those sailing boats with spinning cylinder sails \u201cwork\u201d similarly, with air being the little rocks)\u2026", "The Earth\u2019s rotation is constantly being slowed by \u201ctidal drag\u201d - influence of the Moon on the Earth\u2019s rotation. This slowing process has gone on ever since the formation of the moon, and will continue until the Earth is \u201ctidally locked\u201d with one side facing the moon, as the moon is already locked with The fact is that she designated him a living of one thousand pounds per annum for the rest of his life. He was the right man at the right time, getting in on a new, booming entertainment sector that stood to profit from noble patronage. Where players before collected coins from the common folk or were pets of the castle-folk, Shakespeare's company was able to reach both markets effectively and profitably. He was able to retire and live in comfort in his home town from his work as a writer and performer, which was virtually unprecedented in his time and place. One of the key points of the book is that the fate of Rome was tied inextricably to fluctuations of the climate and to outbreaks of disease. For example the battle of Adrianople in 378 AD is regarded as one of Rome\u2019s worst military defeats ever. At Adrianople the Romans lost an estimated 20,000 men and the Goths pushed their way into the Empire. It was a disaster for Rome that it never recovered from, but it came at the end of two centuries of plague, deteriorating climate, and economic contraction.\nThe Antonine Plague:\nThe Antonine Plague was the first pandemic in history and it happened because the Romans created a world in which pandemic became possible. Cities with dense populations connected by highly trafficked trade links bringing in goods and people from all over the world made the Mediterranean a vast petri dish waiting for something deadly to fall into. In 165 AD something did.\nStarting in 165 AD the Antonine plague is estimated to have killed 7,000,000 in the first years that it hit the empire (165\u2013180 AD). It could have been measles but it was probably smallpox. It showed up in the cities of the Middle East and was probably carried by the Roman Army and by merchants throughout the Empire.\nAccording to the Roman historian Dio Cassius\n(155\u2013235), when the disease returned to Rome in 177 AD it caused up to 2,000 deaths a day in Rome and had a mortality rate of about 25% The total number of deaths in this first wave have been estimated at 15 million. With the disease killing as much as one-third of the population in some areas and devastating the Roman army.\nWhat's worse, is that there wasn\u2019t just one hit and then it was over. The plague would burn through one location. Then radiate out from there to other cities and the countryside as people tried to flee from it and carried it with them. Because of the slower travel times this dispersal and radiation of the disease took decades to play out.\nAfter 165 AD there was always plague going on in the Empire. Including an outbreak that was especially severe known as the Plague of Cyprian\nthat ran from 251\u2013ca. 270. The severe devastation to the European population from the two plagues may indicate that people had no previous exposure to this disease, so they were in essence \u201cvirgin field\u201d epidemics.\nFinally in 541 AD, the first great pandemic of Yersina pestis, or bubonic plague struck the Mediterranean. It too was devastating and it would linger for more than two centuries. Three major waves of plague that over a 500 year period caused a decline in population of about 50%.\nClimate Change:\nThe Empire\u2019s most prosperous period, it is generally agreed, was between 96 and 180 AD. That period, when the Roman project was at its most healthy \u2014 also coincided with the Roman Climate Optimum, which ran from about 200 BC to 150 AD. This was a period when the weather warmed up.\nPliny the Elder, writing in the first century AD, described how beech trees, which used to grow only in the lowlands, started climbing up mountains as the temperature rose. Olives and vines were grown further and further north. The Empire became a giant greenhouse. Agricultural output was high, food was plentiful and cheap, the population increased rapidly and reached a high in the Mediterranean basin of around 75 million during this period.\nThis period ended around 150 AD when climate conditions started deteriorating. Known as the \u2018Roman Transitional Period\u2019 the climate got progressively cooler year after year for the next 250 years. Culminating in the \u2018Late Antique Little Ice Age\u2019, from 450\u2013700 AD, when the Empire fell apart.\nThis stressed the Empire as it was being hit by the pandemics mentioned above. The changing climate increased the frequency of droughts and crop failures throughout the Empire. Which, in a vicious feedback loop, naturally increased the numbers of hungry malnourished people vulnerable to disease.\nIn Egypt in 244 AD, the Nile, a crucial agricultural source, failed to rise and irrigate neighboring fields, and was weak in the following two years. A population weakened by widespread malnutrition was vulnerable to disease and in 249 AD the Plague of Cyprian struck. Political instability fueled by hunger and depopulation led to a mini-collapse sometimes called the \u2018first fall\u2019 of the Empire.\nThe double blow of bubonic plague (541 AD) and the mini ice age, triggered by a huge volcanic eruption in the northern hemisphere, in 536 AD did the rest. By 650 AD the population of the Mediterranean basin, which had been 75 million in the 2nd century AD, collapsed to half that; Rome, once home to 1,000,000 people at its height in 150 AD, was now inhabited by only 20,000.", "Quite a few.\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_epidemics", "Disease was endemic to the empire and epidemics regularly occurred.\nSee here: Disease in Imperial Rome - Wikipedia", "The Roman Empire was frequently impacted by epidemics. Livy describes and epidemic in Sicily during the Second Punic War which decimated the armies of both the Romans and the Carthaginians.\nThe Roman Consul Lucius Aemilius Paullus conquered King Perseus of Macedonia in 168 B.C. When he returned he had a Triumph, but his joy was marred by the deaths of both of his youngest two sons in a plague that was ravaging the city. We don\u2019t know whether his returning soldiers brought it back from Macedonia.\nPerhaps the most significant plague in ancient times was the Antonine plague during the late second century A.D. It was highly contagious and destroyed both legions and mining camps. The effect on legions weakened Rome military and the inability to mine precious metals weakened her financially. This plague was a significant factor in the subsequent political instability and ultimate decline of the western half of the Roman Empire. We don\u2019t know what the disease was, but historians speculate that it may have been either small pox or measles.", "Yes, definitely. Most damage was done during the bombardments on 22 and 23 November 1943. In less than 15 minutes, 30% of the zoo population was killed on the first day. On the second day the aquarium building was completely destroyed by a direct hit. Of the eight elephants only one survived, the bull Siam. 2-year-old hippo bull Knautschke was saved from the fire in his animal house. Most damage was done during the Battle of Berlin. From 22 April 1945 onwards, the zoo was under constant artillery fire of the Red Army. Heavy fighting took place on the zoo area till 30 April. Because of safety measures, some predators and other dangerous animals were killed by the zoo keepers.\nBy the end of the war, the zoo was fortified with the Zoo Tower, a huge flak tower that was one of the last remaining areas of Nazi German resistance against the Red Army, with its bunkers and anti-aircraft weapons defending against Allied air forces. At the entrance of the zoo, there was a small underground shelter for zoo visitors and keepers. During the battle, wounded German soldiers were taken care for here by female personnel and the wives of zookeepers. On 30 April, the zoo flak bunker surrendered.\nA count on May 31, 1945, revealed only 91 of 3,715 animals had survived, including two lion cubs, two hyenas, Asian bull elephant Siam, hippo bull Knautschke, ten hamadryas baboons, a chimpanzee, and a black stork. After the battle, some animals disappeared or were eaten by Red Army soldiers. Following the zoo's destruction, it and the associated aquarium was reconstructed on modern principles so as to display the animals in as close to their natural environment as feasible. The success in breeding animals, including some rare species, demonstrates the efficacy of these new methods. Salt has been a trade item since ancient times so most areas without a local source would still have access to it. History of salt - Wikipedia\nBut with or without salt there are other preservative methods. Drying, smoking, pickling, freezing, fermenting, are examples.\nHow was food stored and preserved before the invention of refrigerators?\nThen there are foods like grains and nuts that can be kept for long periods without special preservation methods other than safe storage. Probably why the first crops were grains.\nGranary - Wikipedia", "The appropriately named Hallstatt culture of late Bronze Age, early Iron Age Europe was based in part on salt mining in the Austrian Alps.\nThe salt was mined with picks and placed into backpacks to be carried out.\nA backpack was discovered in an old collapsed mine from the region:\nThe Hall part of the name means salt and a neighbouring town is called Hallein. The German placename element Salz also means salt. The surrounding region was known as the Salzkammergut (salt producing region under direct control of the crown) during the middle ages and up to the modern period because of the all the salt mining. The Salzach river, itself meaning salt waterway, was where the salt was barged down to markets elsewhere. In 1967 the musicologist Peter Yates in his \u201c20th century music\" asserted: \u201cOur own system of fixed pitches, equal temperament, has lasted only 150 years and is already in advanced disintegration\" (page 5). The context reveals that Yates is really thinking of harmony because in the previous paragraph he says: \u201cThis intervallic system of fixed pitches governed the harmonic grammar of European music for more than 200 years, roughly 1600\u20131800.\u201c\nIn other words, from his perspective of writing about classical music in 1967, he saw tonality of whatever description going down the plughole. What he couldn' t have foreseen is that tonality in the latter part of the 20th century, and yes, using that system of equal temperament \u201cin advanced disintegration\", would gain a whole new lease of life in Minimalism and with some composers returning to \u201cromantic\" means of expression (film music having been especially influential).\nIf there's any \u201cdegeneracy\", from a purely personal point of view I would see it in the contemporary obsession with celebrity as a virtue rather than intrinsic worth. Any art that is the product of that kind of motivation is innately degenerate as far as I am concerned.", "i was listening to this when......", "It never did. It just got different.\nI mean, you could say that Mozart\u2019s musical idiom degenerated the moment Beethoven came along and thought, \u201cThat\u2019s great, but I\u2019m not going to do that. I\u2019m going to make the music I need to make.\u201d And he did, and the music he wrote was different from Mozart\u2019s. But it stuck, and it changed things, and all music after Beethoven was different from Mozart\u2019s, and it stayed being different.\nReally, every good composer does that, although only with the great ones does it stick, and change things. So look at 200 years of that process, and you get Chopin, and Wagner, and Brahms, and Mahler, and Debussy, and Stravinsky, and Bartok, and Shostakovich, and Schoenberg, and Webern, and Boulez, and Lutoslawski, and Reich, and Adams. All different, and sometimes representing opposing contemporaneous artistic schools, but all connected to their forebears, and identifiable as to where they came from.\nWithout knowing your tastes, I couldn\u2019t guess when you would say it \u201cdegenerated\u201d. But Wagner is the big tough-nut of the 19th Century - some of his music is not easy to listen to. In the early Twentieth the tough-nuts were probably Stravinsky and Schoenberg, who created different visions, different schools of music that wasn\u2019t easy to listen to. After them, classical music continued to mostly be not easy to listen to, with a few exceptions like Aaron Copland\u2019s middle period, or most old-school orchestral movie scores.\nWhat you really need to do is find an online site that covers music history, and read up on the subject - this answer doesn\u2019t even approach being an adequate summary.", "At what point in history and why did the music degenerate (no more Mozart or Beethoven)?\nThe premise shows a lack of understanding of the role and production of music. There are good and less good producers of music in all time periods, but to suggest that one time period produces only good stuff and another period produces only degenerated stuff ignores the facts.\nMusic is a reflection of the time it is made and the people who listen to it. No one period or type is to be treated with idolatry. Among other things, every generation (including that of Mozart and Beethoven) has its own music which represents its growing identify and its rebellion against authority.", "Mozart and Beethoven are part of the degeneration. Consider the complexity of the High Renaissance.", "I disagree with the premise of your question. Music has always been a reflection of the time and place in which it was created. During the time of Mozart and Beethoven society was much more formal and composers were dependent upon the patronage of the nobility. Hence, music reflected their tastes.\nThe situation is much different today. It would take a book(s) to delineate the differences between the world of Mozart/Beethoven and today\u2019s musicians. Among the most important is the impact of technology. Think for a moment how victorlas, radios, televisions, cds, and online services have changed the music industry. Musicians are now able to take their music directly to a widespread audience.\nSo I return to my original thought: music is always a reflection of the time and place in which it was created. Music has not degenerated. It has evolved and surely will continue to witness the changes to our world.", "When? As a male name it fell out of fashion with the demise of House of Wessex, as there were no more aethelings - princes of the Saxon royal house - left to name."], "topic_list": ["Middle Ages (era)", "History of Great Britain", "Given Names", "History of Europe", "Great Britain", "The United Kingdom", "History"], "view_list": [130], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 4, "question_author": "Nicole Da Costa", "upvote_list": [2], "question_title": "What happened to the \u201cAethel\u201d part of so many pre-Middle Ages names in Britain?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "1,807", "name_list": ["James Calbraith"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "895": {"ans_list": ["Chanakya is often called the Machiavelli of ancient India. Chanakya (311 BC to 283 BC), born in Pataliputra in eastern India, was the genius behind the establishment of the first pan-Indian empire.\nHe was an acharya (professor) of politics and economics in the ancient university of Takshashila. Chanakya\u2019s Arthashastra and Chanakya Neeti are more comprehensive works of statecraft and politics since the Mauryan times. He then spent the few years trying to unite Indian kingdoms against the foreign invader mainly Alexander.\nIn the two books attributed to him, Chanakya Neeti and Arthasashtra, Chanakya covers all aspects of administration. The Arthshastra is a concept of saptanga or elements of state apparatus which are as follows:\nSwami (lord/king), Amatya(ministers), janapada(territory), Durga(fortified capital), Kosha(treasury), Danda(punishment/justice) and Mitra(ally).\nChanakya/kautilya gives detailed instructions on how the palace should be provided with multiple secret emergency exits and how all things going in and out of the palace complex must be carefully examined. All good and drinks consumed by the king must be first tested. A king should have a personal guard of female archers and must surround himself with the people wh he trust. Elaborate arrangements were made to guard the king against poison, fire and snakes.\nThe Artshastra also emphasise the moral obligations of kingship by elaborating king's duties. He asks the king only to forego ethics in the times of war and against enemies. Chanakya lays strict ethical codes for administration during peace, along with an elaborate structure for social security of the weak and oppressed in Arthashastra. His morality is based on the apad dharma or the moral code during the time of crisis.\nThe paternalistic rule is reflected in Arthshastra which states that the king should behave like a father and ensure security and prosperity for his subjects. These arrangements that were made in the Mauryan statehood are the best examples of Machiavellianism.\nTherefore Chanakya was a successful politician of ancient India. "Around 1865, as the American Civil War drew to a close, the French historian Edouard de Laboulaye proposed that France create a statue to give to the United States in celebration of that nation\u2019s success in building a viable democracy.\nFrench sculptor Frederic August Bartholdi was commissioned to design the Statue of Liberty. Legend has it that the statue\u2019s face was modeled after Bartholdi\u2019s mother. Alexandre-Gustave Eiffel (designer of Paris\u2019s Eiffel Tower) was called on to design a framework on which to hang the hand-hammered copper sheets that make up the statue. Eiffel, along with Eug\u00e8ne-Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc, built a skeleton of iron and steel to support the statue. The English eventually lost the Hundred Years\u2019 War against France.\nWhether a nation is to the north or south of their opponent isn\u2019t the determinant of who will win the war, unless there are geographic factors that help or hinder the plans of one of the combatants (i.e, the English Channel preventing several invasions of England over the centuries). Class B defendants were accused of having committed such crimes themselves; class C defendants, mostly senior officers, were accused of planning, ordering or failing to prevent them.\nThe judges\npresiding came from the United States\n, China\n, the United Kingdom\n, Australia\n, the Netherlands\n, France\n, the Soviet Union\n, New Zealand\n, India\nand the Philippines\n. Additionally, the Chinese Communists\nalso held a number of trials for Japanese personnel. More than 4,400 Japanese personnel were convicted and about 1,000 were sentenced to death.\nThe largest single trial was that of 93 Japanese personnel charged with the summary execution\nof more than 300 Allied POWs, in the Laha massacre\n(1942). The most prominent ethnic Korean convicted was Lieutenant General Hong Sa Ik\n, who orchestrated the organisation of prisoner of war camps in Southeast Asia. In 2006, the South Korean\ngovernment \"pardoned\" 83 of the 148 convicted Korean war criminals.\nOne hundred-sixty Taiwanese who had served in the forces of the Empire of Japan were convicted of war crimes and 11 were executed.", "Because only white people are bad", "Well they did. Some few years after that, the Danish Privy Council declared Norway to be a part of Denmark, thus ending the personal union.\nIt\u2019s a bit hard to tell how it affected Scandinavia, because in many ways it was a failed project that could have had great consequences, uniting the whole region effectively if the king had been a bit more laid back and more forgiving towards the nobility.\nLooking at the map above, you can see that Norway/Denmark constitute the western side of the Nordic countries, whereas Sweden and Finland make up the eastern. That was the pattern of geography and interest inherited since the viking era, and trying so quickly to unite east and west under a common, strong monarch, was probably a fool\u2019s errand. In light of that, it seems inevitable that Sweden would be independent, either by chance or by design.\nOn the other hand, the Kalmar Union probably catalyzed the political will in Sweden, and without it there might not even have been a Swedish king to speak of. Gustav Eriksson (Vasa) was quick to unite the country and break down his opposition, and on the whole seems to have modeled himself after his contemporary Henry VIII of England, even separating the country from the Roman catholic church.\nIf the Swedish nobility was the structure resisting the pull of money and power from the south and west, Gustav was the strong man of history shaping that resistance.", "Negatively, too few people making decisions for too many", "The Kalmar Union was ruled from Denmark and lasted from 1397 until 1523. It included the today Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Norway, Iceland, Greenland, Far\u00f6 and other islands and region in the north of the British isles.
