The name is merely a perspective point of view based on the continuity of identities.\nAnd while that is true, that doesn't make the name wrong, people are quick to jump and make such simplistic conclusions. The name reflects a shared identity of the Catholic Latin kingdoms of northern medieval Spain, and that identity is true.\nThe king Alfonso VI of Castile called himself \u201cEmperor of Spain\" after conquering Toledo and re-uniting Castile, Le\u00f3n and Galicia (which had briefly split). He called himself emperor of Spain, because there was a Spanish identity, you don't call yourself the emperor of a concept that doesn't exist or you don't identify with. And Spain is the Latin name of the place. So the claim that the shared identity of the northern kingdoms is a modern fabrication is completely false.\nAlfonso VI calls himself Emperor of Spain after taking Toledo and reuniting Castile, Le\u00f3n and Galicia from his brothers\nAnd there was a conflict between north and south, Latin Catholics and Muslim Moors, and the proof is the fact that the movement of the borders was north and south, not east and west. The gains and losses, the wars, were north and south. If the conflict had been in all directions, wars and borders would have moved in all directions. But every northern kingdom expanded in a vertical column south.\nThere were of course conflicts among Latin and Moorish kingdoms, because raw interests are the pulling force of politics, but that was molded by the 2 identities shared north and south, and that is shown by the fact that virtually all conflicts and border movements were in the same direction.\nIn fact, when the Caliphate of C\u00f3rdoba falls and Muslim Iberia splits into several small kingdoms, the stronger northern kingdoms start to gain ground against them. As they say \u201cunion makes strength\" and when the Muslims split the Catholics gained power against them, Castile specially emerged as the leading Latin-Catholic power in the peninsula for the first time.\nWhat happened? The Muslims called North African forces for help and re-united them as one kingdom under the Almoravid dynasty. The Iberian Muslim rulers were horrified by Alfonso VI conquering Toledo. The Almoravid Caliphate took over Muslim Iberia and western North Africa and launched a strike back against Castile. And Castile was pushed back and entered a deep internal crisis.\nAlmoravid Caliphate\nBut at that moment Aragon and Portugal which had remained mostly inactive during the previous period launched large scale attacks, Aragon conquered Zaragoza going from a small kingdom on the Pyrenees to one of the 3 main Catholic Iberian powers, and most importantly creating a crisis in the Almoravid Caliphate whose sole reason to exist was defeating the northern kingdoms and it was failing.\nOn top of that the Almohads in north Africa used this moment of weakness to gain power against the Almoravids, taking over their caliphate and attempting another attack back at Catholics in Iberia.\nAlmohad Caliphate\nBut this time the Catholic kingdoms also united, except the Portuguese, but Aragon, Castile and Navarra (the ones that would form Spain later) united against the Almohads. In the battle of Navas de Tolosa in southern Castile, the 3 Latin kingdoms fought the Moorish alliance in the largest battle of the Reconquista. The Muslims lost while having a big size advantage, largely thanks to the sacrifices of the orders (the Order of Santiago lost its leader fighting himself in the front), and the Navarrans who having the least to gain risked the most of the 3 kingdoms.\nPainting of the Navas de Tolosa battle\nParade of the Pend\u00f3n of Navas de Tolosa in northern Castile\nCelebrations for the Navas de Tolosa in northern Castile\nMilitary parade of the Spanish land forces in Santa Elena, the village located in the battlefield in Andalusia\nAfter the defeat of the Muslims, Castile conquered all of southern Spain except Granada, which was allowed to exist as a vassal paying money yearly to Castile. Until the sultanate of Granada attacked Castile 2 centuries later tired of the vassal status. Portugal also went on to conquer the land south of their border as the Muslim powers were collapsing.\nIberian Peninsula after the defeat of the Almohads\nAt that time Castile was in a union with Aragon through the marriage of Isabella and Ferdinand, and that was the perfect excuse Isabella needed to invade Granada. Castile and Aragon conquered Granada for Castile. Later Castile and Aragon conquered Naples for Aragon, and with that and the annexation of Navarra, Castile and Aragon acted as one for the rest of history later forming Spain.\nFerdinand of Aragon (red) and Isabella of Castile (white) in the Take of Granada the 2nd of January of 1492, Ferdinand reaches for the keys of the city handed by the sultan Boabdil, Granada becomes part of Castile after that\nThe alliances and blocks between Latin Catholics and Muslim Moors are the clearest evidence of the existance of shared identities north and south, and the northern one was inherited from the Romans, which the Visigoths themselves had borrowed. And so it is \u201creconquering\" from that Latin Catholic identity's POV.", "You may consider that the land before the Muslims invasions had at least a religion unity, besides linguistic and cultural common roots.\nMuslim war had a different religious ground, which undervalued Christians and considered them subjects of tribute.\nAbove all, before a Reconquest there must be a conquest.\nA) THERE IT WAS A CONQUEST?\nIt is quite obvious there it was an invasion from people from another continent that have had an expansionism based on military activity and religion/government imposition, and tax imposition.\n1] INITIAL INVASION:\n\u201c The Islamic advance\nAfter the death of the Prophet Muhammed in 632 AD the speed of the spread of Islam was extraordinary, and by 711 Islamic armies were poised to invade Spain from North Africa. Defeating the Visigothic kingdom of Spain was a prelude to increasing raids into Gaul, or modern France, and in 725 Islamic armies reached as far north as the Vosgues mountains near the modern border with Germany.\u00bb From: What Was the Significance of the Battle of Tours?\n\u201c The Muslim conquest of Spain\nThe death of the Visigothic\nking Witiza\nin 710 left Spain in disarray. The Gothic nobles refused to recognize his young sons and elected Roderick\n, dux (duke) of Baetica, to succeed him. Gothic Gaul\nfollowed Witiza\u2019s son Akhila, and the Basques\nrebelled. As Roderick marched north to quell the Basques, his rivals appealed to M\u016bs\u0101 ibn Nu\u1e63ayr\n, the Umayyad\ngovernor of the Maghreb\n. M\u016bs\u0101 dispatched an army under \u1e6c\u0101riq ibn Ziy\u0101d\nin late spring 711. The force landed at Gibraltar\n, crossed to mainland Spain, and in July 711 defeated Roderick\u2019s army.\nInstead of returning to North Africa\n, \u1e6c\u0101riq marched on the Visigothic capital of Toledo\nand took the city with minimal resistance. \u201c From:: Battle of Tours | Facts, History, & Importance\nDo the invaders made alliances with some locals when convenient? Yes, they did. But that does not gave them rights over other their land. Further, that was not enough for them: they wanted all. The Basques rebellion seeded the invasion. This has happened often in history, rebels become traitors in order to succeed.\nDo the invaders brought cultural values? Yes, specialty technical and artistic. Greek knowledge survived more between the Muslims than in first centuries in Europe, and they have refinement in luxuries and art, even mathematicians an astronomers. The price: they wanted to be the owners and lords.\n2] ISLAMIC ADVANCE INTO EUROPE THROUGH SPAIN:\nAs I told before, they wanted dominate all.\n\u201c Ever since their arrival in Spain\nfrom Africa in 711, Muslims had raided Frankish territory, threatening Gaul\nand on one occasion (725) reaching Burgundy and sacking Autun\n. In 732 \u02bfAbd al-Ra\u1e25m\u0101n al-Ghafiqi, the governor of C\u00f3rdoba\n, marched into Bordeaux\nand defeated (Duke) Eudes. The Muslims then proceeded north across Aquitaine to the city of Poitiers. Eudes appealed to Charles for assistance, and Charles managed to defeat a significant Muslim force at the Battle of Tours\n. Although Tours is sometimes presented as a decisive check on Muslim expansion into Europe\n, it was, in reality, a single engagement in a decades-long conflict between the Franks and the armies of Muslim Spain\n\u201d (rather Muslims in Spain): From: Charles Martel | Biography, Accomplishments, & Facts\n3] MUSLIM ADVANCE STOPPED From: Battle of Tours (732 A.D.)\n:\n\u201c Battle of Tours (732 A.D.)\nThe Battle of Tours (often called the Battle of Poitiers, but not to be confused with the Battle of Poitiers, 1356) was fought on October 10, 732 between forces under the Frankish leader Charles Martel and a massive invading Islamic army led by Emir Abdul Rahman Al Ghafiqi Abd al Rahman, near the city of Tours, France. During the battle, the Franks defeated the Islamic army and Emir Abd er Rahman was killed. This battle stopped the northward advance of Islam from the Iberian peninsula, and is considered by most historians to be of macrohistorical importance, in that it halted the Islamic conquests, and preserved Christianity as the controlling faith in Europe, during a period in which Islam was overrunning the remains of the old Roman and Persian Empires. \u201c\n\u201c\u201d Contemporary analysis\nHad Martel fallen at Tours the long term implications for European Christianity may have been devastating. His victory there, and in the following campaigns, may have literally saved Europe and Christianity as we know it, from conquest while the Caliphate was unified and able to mount such a conquest. Had the Franks fallen, no other power existed stopping Muslim conquest of Italy and the effective end of what would become the modern Catholic Church\u2026\u2026. But had Martel failed, there would have been no Charlemagne, no Holy Roman Empire or Papal States. \u201c\u201d\n4] Conclusions: There is not doubt there was a Conquest. Perhaps it would be better they have called the liberation war a Retrieval, or just Liberation war. Of course, after eight centuries of domination, there was enough unavoidable mixing. Therefore, some inhabitants suffered a mentality change, because that was in part the Muslim goal, a mentality change through dominance, and this happens even today. Therefore, even today there are Islamist in Spain, sort of Stockholm syndrome. Personally, I admire those who fought through 8 centuries, through generations, against the imposition of a religion opposite to Catholicism, the Muslim mentality and the submission to caliphates. And I am afraid the history could repeat.", "History, like some people, sometimes has a selective memory. In the case of Spain, The Muslims \u201cconquered\u201d it from the Goths, I believe it was, who conquered it from the previous occupants who conquered it from the previous occupants.\nA similar situation occurred many times in the United States. Many of the tribes who had their land \u201cstolen\u201d by white Europeans had acquired \u201ctheir\u201d land by the same methods; theft by conquest.\nIn Spain, the Christians \u201creconquered\u201d land that they themselves had stolen initially.", "It\u2019s complicated.\nIn the early 8th century, a small army of Muslim Berbers invaded Spain and took over, deposing Roderick, the final Gothic king of Spain, in the process. In this, they were aided by a lot of local allies, who hated the king. It was partly an invasion and partly a native uprising.\nFor centuries thereafter, Spain was mostly ruled by Muslim leaders, several of immediate or recent foreign extraction, though many natives converted for better access to power and constituted part of the ruling class. The Reconquista was an effort largely on the part of the few Christian-ruled territories of northern Spain, which had not been conquered, to conquer Iberia themselves, motivated to a considerable extent by the change in dominant religion. And eventually they succeeded. Christian rulers drove out Muslim rulers.\nIn a way, the Reconquista was something of a return to the status quo ante. Spain had been ruled by Christians before, and then it came to be ruled by Christians again. On the other hand, it\u2019s difficult to characterize Ferdinand, who finished the job, as recovering anything which was rightfully his. He was no heir to Roderick. Nor was Spain \u201cstolen\u201d any more than in any other invasion and probably less than in others. To reiterate: the Muslim invasion had local support. Muslims didn\u2019t come in and slaughter or enslave all the Christians. Muslims came in and established themselves as a ruling class with the aid of other Christians. And, of course, neither Christianity nor the Church owned Spain, so they certainly couldn\u2019t have it stolen from them or recovered. In doing so they created the working class. The Industrial Revolution also helped build the British Empire."], "topic_list": ["Industrial Revolution", "History of Great Britain", "Great Britain", "History"], "view_list": [30], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Efrayim Bulka", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What were the consequences of the Industrial Revolution in Great Britain?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "31", "name_list": ["Richard Stephens"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "513": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["History of Sports", "Comebacks (triumphs)", "Athletes", "Athletics", "Professional Athletes", "Accidents and Injuries", "Professional Sports", "Sports", "History"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Sridharan Subramaniam", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What are some of the greatest injury comebacks in the history of athletics?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "34", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "305": {"ans_list": ["Neither hoax nor a plan to wage a war against the Soviet Union. The Operation Unthinkable seems to have been very much a cautionary tale, to sober anyone - and there were such people in the UK - who wanted to continue WWII but against the Soviets.\nBy the end of WWII in Europe, by the end of the Yalta conference, there was considerable thought that the Soviet Union was not going to be a civilized and friendly power with the UK and the US and the rest of the world in the post-war world. These people were not entirely wrong, as Soviet post-war actions would show.\nThe Soviet Union, recall, had not been a friendly place between the wars, but had worked to sponsor revolutions in Europe and had worked to subvert Western governments. Soviet spies were active, and in subversion, not just intelligence gathering. Even the Soviet participation in the Spanish Civil War had been marked by brutality and activity against other parties supporting the Republic against Franco. And many people knew just how Stalin\u2019s government ran the Soviet Union.\nSo there were quite a few people in the UK before 1939 who were in favor of rapprochement with Nazi Germany to oppose the Soviet Union, even to the point of armed attack. Remember the UK had supported armed action against the Soviet government during the collapse of the Czarist government and after WWI; the adventures of Sidney Rielly were not all fiction.\nThe UK was not alone in this opposition. The Poles, who had fought a Russian attack after WWI - that is how Pilsudski came on the scene - hated and feared the Russians so much that Poland would not agree to allowing Russian troops to cross Poland to fight Germany. The Russian actions after their non-aggression pact with the Germans showed the Poles were at least partly right - the Russians occupied part of Poland, in cooperation with the Nazis, and murdered thousands of Polish officers and otherbZpoles in the Katyn Forest. The Soviet treatment of the Polish government in exile was further example of Soviet policy continuing Imperial Russian policy of imperial control of Poland. The Baltic states were of the same mind, as they, too, had been parts of the Czar\u2019s empire. And they all had the example of Finland, another part of the Czar\u2019s empire, before them. The Soviet Union wanted (and after 1945, mostly got) the real estate back.\nBeing anti-Soviet was the idea of the Hungarian regime, and of Romania, too. The Austrians were not unhappy about joining Nazi Germany in a opposition to Russia. They had all seen a Communist uprising in Bavaria in 1919 - and Hungary had seen Bela Kun.\nHow many people from Nazi occupied Europe and neutral nations joined the SS and went to fight the Russians ? Do you remember who the SS troops defending the Furher bunker in Berlin in 1945 were ? They weren\u2019t German - they were French.\nThe Catholic Church agreed with the Nazis about opposition to the Soviets. Pope Pius had been the legate in Bavaria, and had seen the same Communist uprising everyone else in the area had - but he had been ringside. Anti-Soviet unity was the idea of the German-Vatican Concordat; you might note, the silence of the Vatican about Nazi Germany during the war. Hitler paid his church tax to the Catholic Church throughout the war (and the Church took the money), and the Church never moved to excommunicate Hitler or any other Nazi.\nThere were, in the UK and before 1939, people, some very influential, who agreed with these Europeans that the Soviet Union was an enemy, one to be opposed and possibly fought, in alliance with Germany, Nazi or not. This was, if I understand correctly, the view of the Cliveden set, and maybe more than a few in Parliament and maybe the view of the abdicated King, now the Duke of Windsor.\nRemember that Churchill had been one of the forces behind the British intervention against the Soviet regime in 1919. The Churchill joke about allying with the Devil and making favorable remarks in the House of Commons about him if Satan would fight Hitler was not exactly complimentary to the Soviet Union.\nThese people in the UK did not change their minds about the Soviet Union because of the trivial matter of WWII.\nRemember, too, that making peace with England and turning the war against the Soviet Union in alliance with England was a chimera that the German opposition to Hitler had and, within the German Army, continued to have until the very end of the war in Europe. Exactly that idea was not confined to the German opposition to Hitler. Hitler himself thought the alliance between England and Russia was preposterous and impossible as a lasting one, and that the death of Roosevelt could be the catalyst for breaking the Allies up - and turning them against the Soviet Union by the side of the Germans.That idea seems to have been on Rudolf Hess\u2019 mind when he flew to England, and was the idea both Himmler and Goebbels had for their peace overtures in 1945.\nSo, with such an idea having swirled around for so long, Churchill, who knew the British could not stand to continue any Continental war much longer, asked what making an anti-Russian alliance with Germany and joining the war against the Soviet Union and winning that war would actually cost and require.\nSo he asked, and asked for a military plan for doing so, fighting and defeating the Soviet Union in 1945, with at least part of his reasons for doing so being able to show it in case someone who had to be answered (Lord Halifax, for example) raised the question.\nShowing the plan would enable Churchill to reply \u201c\u201cDo you think we can do this ? This is the best plan we have to fight the Soviet Union and winter. Do you think we have the strength to do this ? Do you think the British people, having been at war since 1939, have the strength and will to do this ? Do you think the Canadians will go along with this ? of two groups of power that were in dispute and without harmony between them to coordinate in the direction of both parts of the Empire. Most of all, he was aware of how difficult and absorbing it was to lead the Empire, the internal struggles that took place between groups of power and the relative ease with which emperors could be proclaimed by the army in the absence of a strong and powerful central power. He could have followed the example of the Antonine emperors, sought out one or two capable adult men within his circle of power, and appointed them heirs to the imperial throne, in order to provide stability and strong and capable leadership to the Empire. The dynasty Theodosia was the one that attended the end of the Western part of the Roman Empire, Honorius son of Theodosius witnessed the barbaric irruption of the Rhine in 407 and the capture of Rome by the Vandals. Valentinian III the last member of the Dynasty in the West, was the one who executed General Flavius Aeccio with his own hand, signing his death sentence and the dissolution of the Western part of the Empire. You can call the emperors of the Theodosia dynasty, the Lazy Emperors.", "None of them. Despite the theoretical absolute power of the Emperor, this was not de facto true since men who went beyond what the aristocracy were ready to accept tended to be assassinated. If this was not so, any unpopular reforms would be repudiated when a new Emperor ascended the throne. The reforms of Sulla and Diocletian are examples of this.\nThe problem in Rome was not the individual merits of Emperors or Dictators, but rather the inherent greed and corruption in the ruling class. The first death blow of Rome was the Marian reforms, changing the army from landed citizens serving in a militia capacity, to that of a professional army paid by the State and populated by the landless poor and foreigners. Before this change it would scarcely be possible for a general to usurp the Republic and proclaim himself absolute ruler, as Sulla and Caesar did. And the main reason for that change was the continuous campaigning in the Late Republic, impoverishing the farmer citizen who made up the bulk of the army, forcing their families to sell their properties to the aristocracy. The attempt to enact land reform to solve this problem was met with fierce resistance from the Senatorial class. The Gracchi brothers and Julius Caesar met their deaths due to these confrontations.\nLater this same tendency started to jeopardize the taxable income from the provinces, since the landed elite bribed the governors to avoid paying their fair share of tax. To meet their quotas, the pressure instead fell on the regular farmers, which impoverished them also and causing a decline in State income. Diocletian tried to counteract this by creating a system which later became the Feudal System, forcing the son to continue the line of work of his father, and setting fixed amounts for the amount of tax and produce to be paid by region. This meant that the combination of corruption and the occasional bad harvest would bankrupt the farmers, and if their sons had sense, to simply flee their stipulated duty to work. Draconian measures to uphold the system using the sword had little real effect for this reason. You can not force a man to do a job he knows will cause his doom long term.\nJulian the Apostate demonstrated that the necessary funds could easily be collected if the governor was conscientious and thorough in his work, but rulers like him were extremely rare, and ultimately the endemic corruption and decline in production and income meant that a professional army of sufficient size could no longer be maintained. The majority of the Old Testament is a history of the Jewish people. It is the primary chronicle explaining their origins and history for about the first thousand years before Christ. Among books that age, that portion of the Old Testament is about as accurate as books of that age get. However, the Old Testament makes some fantastic claims. Throughout the history of Christianity disbelief in the veracity and the literality of these stories has been relatively common in Christianity.\nHistorically there have been two schools of thought on the subject that date back to the inception of the Church. The Antiochian school held that the Old Testament was a literal document, and Adam and Eve were historical people. St. John Chrysostom was one of the most famous figures in this school. The Alexandrian School, on the other hand, took a more allegorical approach to the Old Testament. Questions about the literality and the veracity of the bible are as old as the bible is itself. A lot of descriptions contained in the Old Testament are anachronistic and reflects the view of the world as from the 7th century BC.\nFor example what concerns YHWH, these archeologists discovered that YHWH had a wife goddess and, therefore, Jerusalem was polytheist before this period of redaction. Another example is the use of camels for transportation: according to the old testament, they were always part of the history of Israel while archaeological evidence shows it was a recent introduction at the time of the writing of the Torah. In other words, those writers were not telling history but stories in the context of their own time.\nIn conclusion, the Torah gives extremely good information on the historical context around the time of their writing ( from the 7th century BCE) but what is described as historical before that time is just fables, around some maybe existing old figures as David who was just a tribal leader ( and no king).\n\nReference: The Bible Unearthed: Archaeology's New Vision of Ancient Israel and the Origin of Its Sacred Texts by Neil Asher Silberman and Israel Finkelstein", "Hardly. Let's take one of the most well-known and archaeologically searched for stories - the story of the Exodus from Egypt.\nThere is not one single shred of archaeological evidence to this myth.\nThe pyramids were built by professional builders, not slaves.\nThere is no record of such a large population suddenly leaving Egypt.\nThere is no record of the travel in the desert (and 40 years would take you around the whole Sinai peninsula a few times)\nThere is actually no evidence of conquest of the land of Israel, more like gradual settlement.\nSee more scholarly replies by Hillel Gray:\nHillel Gray's answer to What archaeological evidence exists to show that the Hebrews were ever slaves or even just lived in Egypt?\nHillel Gray's answer to If the Bible is the word of God then why are there so many mistakes and contradictions in it?\nHere is some fun reading material:\n[1] The Exodus\n\n[2] Great Pyramid tombs unearth 'proof' workers were not slaves", "I answer that question here: Nathan Ketsdever's answer to What evidence is there that the Bible is a reliable historical document?\nThis book should also help answer your question: On the Reliability of the Old Testament: K. Really.", "A2A by Barry Hampe.\nHey Barry, thanks for the A2A.\nFew outside of a few rather foolish Sola Scriptura christian literalists would make any such assertions.\nThere is accurate historical information about various Jewish historical periods within it, but even in the narratives that are most evidently historical the purposes of these texts is not to make socioreligious commentary and not to make an accurate recording of past events.\nThen again, most history books are not strictly speaking accurate historical texts either as history is written by the winner. From those struggles comes the fundamental ideas of liberalism and its championing of the supreme political value, liberty (which can actually mean a lot of different things to different people). So, with this, people are not the monarch\u2019s property, nor does he (or sometimes she) therefore possess a divine right to rule over them and, as under the divine right of kings, accountable only to God in the manner of this rule. Instead, the monarch rules through the people\u2019s consent as obedient to the rule of law.\nAnd from that came the affirmation of those principles of individual liberty and rights: individual rights to trial by jury, due process, and equality before the law, including that sense of individual autonomy defined by non-interference by the ruling authorities\u2014this is the classical liberalist definition of liberty: freedom from coercion or interference in acting (i.e., negative liberty), and as esp. linked to, therefore, to the commitment of private property ownership under two rationales: 1.) as the means to live your own life (the \u201ca man\u2019s home is his castle\u201d defense\u2014a legally inviolate place of privacy, at least not without strict legal proceduralism otherwise) and 2.) as the dispersing of power relations as defending a growing free-market, capitalist economy. This is Adam Smith\u2019s famous adage that England was a \u201cnation of shopkeepers\u201d in the sense that it is \u201ca nation whose government is influenced by shopkeepers.\u201d (Wealth of Nations, Bk. 4, ch. 7).\nThis conception of liberty as private property secured by a market order began to be challenged starting in the later 19th and into the 20th centuries as capitalist economies came to be dominated by large corporations with the resultant increase in concentration of economic, market and financial power (Smith\u2019s own adage about shopkeepers was also meant to be a bulwark against accumulations of private power as well. Smith was not well-disposed toward corporations, in his day the \u201cjoint-stock company\u201d\u2014and its monopoly power).\nThe American economic landscape was no longer (as) supportive of the dominant ideal of the smaller commercial entrepreneur, let alone the Jeffersonian ideal of the yeoman farmer whose material self-sufficiency could inform a true republican polity, as too many peoples\u2019 material livelihoods were now dependent on this now dominant form of capitalist employment and what was seen as growing inequality of private power. This is all the more problematic when this capitalism, given its inherent dynamical quality, enters into one of its periodic difficulties or crises that produce high levels of unemployment with its resulting negative social consequences\u2014and made more problematic by the spread of mass democracy and the spread of political enfranchisement. Classical liberalism\u2019s ability to secure a stable and free society is now under doubt as negative liberty of non-interference doesn\u2019t mean much here with mass unemployment and as having no income severely erodes one\u2019s autonomy. What you want is positive liberty\u2014the actual ability to act and accomplish positive goals (like feeding and housing yourself) and not just to be left alone.\nThis had become palpable with the Great Depression and this is where FDR comes in and why he is seen as the embodiment of this redefined liberalism that had been building since the later 1800s. What the New Deal enacted from this massive economic fallout was this transition from the earlier classical liberalism to a greater social welfare liberalism that is still with us today, though its greatest dominance and influence was from the 1930s through the 1960s. This liberalism extended various protections of individual autonomy through things like Social Security, the FDIC, the minimum wage, unemployment insurance, etc.\u2014including the right for workers to form unions (i.e., collectivizing labor as a countervailing measure against those large collectivizations of capital known as corporations)\u2014and as part of that tradition, later Civil Rights. Even prior to the Reagan Revolution, the government\u2019s own economic policies as expressed through the Federal Reserve and the 1946 Employment Act was in this social liberalism direction: to prioritize full-employment in the goal to promote employment and fight inflation\u2014though the act fell short in asserting that people have a right to a job (with the Reagan Revolution these two principles\u2019 priorities are reversed giving us the neoliberal capitalism of today).", "He introduced \u201cNew Deal\u201d which guaranteed four freedoms, one of which is freedom from hunger. He had taxed the rich capitalists and tried to redistribute the wealth equitably.", "In my opinion classical liberalism promoted Individual Freedom to pursue personal objectives, and nothing more.\nFDR added to this with support systems as public goods and services: Social Security, Minimum Wage, Protected Unions, Workmen\u2019\u2019s Comp, etc. FDIC insurance to make banking safer, Government home loan mortgages, and rural electrification. (Eisenhower added government subsidized SBA loans, Johnson added Medicare, and somewhere along the way, government guaranteed student loans and grants.)\nClassical liberals and libertarians disparage these programs as \u201cthe nanny state,\u201d and believe these programs somehow reduce freedom.\nFDR also pledged America to create a world of The Four Freedoms. Classical liberals and conservatives take issue with two of these freedoms: Freedom from Want, and Freedom from Fear. They do not believe such freedoms should exist at the Government level. Classical Liberals and libertarians also take issue with America Guaranteeing these Freedoms everywhere in the world because \u201cFreedom is not Fee.\u201d\n\u201cIn the future days, which we seek to make secure, we look forward to a world founded upon four essential human freedoms.\nThe first is freedom of speech and expression\u2014everywhere in the world.\nThe second is freedom of every person to worship God in his own way\u2014everywhere in the world.\nThe third is freedom from want\u2014which, translated into world terms, means economic understandings which will secure to every nation a healthy peacetime life for its inhabitants\u2014everywhere in the world.\nThe fourth is freedom from fear\u2014which, translated into world terms, means a world-wide reduction of armaments to such a point and in such a thorough fashion that no nation will be in a position to commit an act of physical aggression against any neighbor\u2014anywhere in the world.\nThat is no vision of a distant millennium.\nIt is a definite basis for a kind of world attainable in our own time and generation.\nThat kind of world is the very antithesis of the so-called new order of tyranny which the dictators seek to create with the crash of a bomb.\n\u2014\nFranklin D. Roosevelt, excerpted from the State of the Union Address to the Congress, January 6, 1941"], "topic_list": ["Franklin D. After the Munich Agreement, Mussolini requested Czechoslovakia to resolve the minority question with Hungary through bilateral negotiations. The negotiations were held between October 9 and October 13, 1938, in Kom\u00e1rno on the Slovak northern bank of the Danube River. The Czechoslovak delegation offered Hungary the creation of an autonomous Hungarian territory within Czechoslovakia, offered to cede Great Rye Island (Zitny ostrov / Csall\u00f3k\u00f6z, 1838 km\u00b2, with 105,418 inhabitants of whom an overwhelming majority were Hungarians), the creation of a free Danube port in the town of Kom\u00e1rno, and a population exchange in the remaining frontier regions. The Czechoslovak delegation declared that it was open for further discussion about minor border corrections in eastern Czechoslovakia, too. The leader of the Hungarian delegation, K\u00e1lm\u00e1n K\u00e1nya characterized the proposal as a \"bad joke\", refused the proposal without a deeper study as a \"humorous border\" and that Hungarian delegation \"analyzed the map only to be polite\". Hungary demanded a territory of 14,000 sq km where at least 50% of Hungarians lived, according to the 1910 census. K\u00e1nya also requested immediate annexation of two border-crossing towns from Czechoslovakia as a \"goodwill gesture\" (both were occupied by Hungary on October 12). The Hungarian delegation presented the 1910 census figures while Czechoslovakia presented the latest 1930 figures and contested the validity of the 1910 census. For instance, the Hungarian delegates argued that Kosice was a \u201cpure Hungarian town\u201d, although its population numbered 42,245 Slovaks and 11,504 Hungarians, according to the 1930 population census. Some delegates proposed to use the Hungarian census from 1880 as a compromise, but it also showed a Slovak majority in the aforementioned town, and the proposal was turned down. Hungary also requested a plebiscite for Slovaks and Ruthenians about rejoining Hungary which would be a violation of Czechoslovakia\u2019s sovereignty. A few days later the Hungarian delegates declared that the negotiations had failed and asked Germany and Italy to be the adjudicator. On the same day, Horthy ordered partial mobilization. Germany and Italy eventually pressured Czechoslovakia into ceding the requested territories to Hungary, and Hungary later invaded and annexed Subcarpathian Rus, too.", "In interwar period, hm not much, but definitely not again, connecting with Germany and Austria that bring catastrophe to Balkans and to Hungary also, leading some new politics, together with Serbia, Romania, Slovakia, Czech republic and Russia or Poland would make some difference, the best thing would b to avoid WWI\u2026.", "I think the day Quora eliminates Anonymous questions and answers the quality of both the questions and answers would markedly increase.\nThat being said, the answer is: Nothing.\nIn the case of Slovakia, the strip along the Hungarian-Slovak border was providing some minimal strategic depth necessary for the defense of Slovakia\u2019s main cities. For instance in the case of the defense of Bratislava, having the Danube river as a border made a big difference compared to not being separated from Hungary by a river.\nIn the case of Romania, the small area of Transylvania (10% of the territory of the province) where most of the Hungarian speakers were concentrated is some 500km away from the Romanian-Hungarian border.\nContrary to what the Hungarian propaganda claim, the members of the commission who decided the borders of Hungary thought very carefully about all the factors involved (demographic, economic, military) before making that decision. As a result there was nothing to be changed which could improve the stability of the area instead of making it worse.\nThis is why the same borders between Czechoslovakia and Hungary and between
